column1: The Rose☃"John W Wells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃""The Rose" is a unique game. Whatever its flaws

column3: which was apparently influenced by the author's daily life
column4: television viewing habits
column5: and general oddness
column6: "The Rose" manages to maintain a coherent
column7: but utterly surreal
column8: plot
column9: a story of superheroes and heated chains covered in Drano

of schoolyard friendships and bank robberies.

The gameplay - what there is of it - generally consists of walking through passages to view cutscenes. A bit of actual play occasionally pops up to spice things up
column11: but this is only an interactive movie in the loosest definition of the word "interactive." There are almost no choices
column12:

That ending is sentimental
column13: clumsily written ("every rose has is thorn")
column14:
and oddly haunting - much like the rest of the game. The music is probably the key factor here - it's probably the most effective thing in the game.

Is "The Rose" worth playing? Yes. Is it the best game out there? Not by far.

Is it good?

I guess it depends on your tastes. "☃"1030653172"☃"therose.zip"☃"4"☃

in addition to its aimlessness:

said player is expected to _care_ when he finds a treasure trove of gems.

2: One character tells the player to keep to the honest path unless sure of himself and the morality of his actions. Later
column23: it is necessary to contradict this advice and do something amoral (at best) to advance

unless I missed something.

column25: unless I missed something

it came out of nowhere.

column1: Edible Vomit☃"MadTom"☃"madtom@comic.com"☃"Edible Vomit endures as my favourite ZZT game of all time. It has a depth which one generally does not come to expect from drac0
column2:
taking Teen Priest and other such games as an example.

You are Freddy the Ferret
column3: a rodent heroin junkie on the quest for the perfect drug
column4: wandering through a trippy (and superbly drawn) ZZT world. Along the way you will administer marijuana to a rabbit
column5: steal a toke from a nine-year-old
column6: yell at a 'wounded wanker
column7: ' and bash hell out of a statue of a child
column8:
using a hammer.

Typical drac0ism? Not so. As you near the end of the game it becomes very clear that there is some very deep meaning here. Whilst not exactly subtle it is nevertheless very effective; the use of drugs is finally called into question.

With basic but appropriate and effective music
column9: superb (and in my opinion anachronistic) graphics
column10: and a very emotive storyline interwoven with the drac0isms we all know and hate/love
column11:
Edible Vomit is without a doubt one of the greatest ZZT games ever made.

And
column12: hell

column1: Operation: GAMMA VELORUM☃"John W Wells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"Operation: Gamma Velorum
column2: Part 1
column3: is essentially an interactive movie with a few gameplay sequences thrown in for good measure. Two RPG battles
column4: a Wak-a-Mole style arcade sequence
column5: a very good rendition of Pong
column6: and a well-done endgame action sequence serve to prevent boredom from setting in. These sequences are all well-executed
column7: but the experience of playing OGVP1 is mainly one of watching cutscenes
column8: following characters around
column9: and bumping into people. This isn't necessarily a problem; an interactive movie game can be a good ZZT game
column10:
provided that it works as an interactive movie.

In a ZZT game
column11: having any coherent storyline at all is a considerable merit. In an interactive movie
column12: the plotline is obviously crucial. Even when
column13: as in the case of OGV1
column14: the storyline is overused
column15: predictable
column16: and unlikely
column17: it still lends some enjoyment to a game by providing a general goal for the player and a driving force for the action. The plotiline of OGV1 serves its purpose of keeping the show going
column18:
and is moderately entertaining in a "watch the Death Star explode" way.

What does OGV1 do wrong? Well
column19: not much
column20: as ZZT games go. There are annoying spelling errors
column21: and the storyline requires a very heavy dose of suspension of disbelief due to its internal inconsistency
column22: but this sort of thing is expected. The real problem is not what OGV1 does wrong
column23: but what it could have done right. It could have done something unpredictable with the story. It could have added some interesting twist to the mechanics of the RPG battles. It could have given us truly interesting characters
column24: or some clever humor
column25: or a bit of real drama
column26: horror
column27:
or excitement.

In short
column28: OGV1 could have been a really good game
column29: as opposed to being "very good as ZZT games go." It has its moments
column30: certainly
column31:
but it could have been better.

This review might seem extremely negative
column32: but I'm only concentrating on the negative aspects of OGV1 because it could have been much better. OGV1 does get a lot of things right
column33: like its well- animated cutscenes
column34: its attempts to make the environment seem extensive (it really looks
column35: at times
column36: as if the stark environments are being used as more than set pieces)
column37: and its avoidance of pointless "filler" material. It's better than 90% of the ZZT games out there
column38: if not more. It's cleanly executed
column39:
and it's very workmanlike.

Again
column40: though
column41: it could have been much better with a little more polish and a bit of originality. "☃"1030654703"☃"oprgv1.zip"☃"4"☃

column1:
On the Wire☃"Commodore"☃☃"One of the first games I downloaded from this site. Draco originally came up with the concept and the first few boards. Then he left. Nadir picked it up from where he left off. He did a good job imitating both his graphical style and his comedy. I honestly can't tell when he picked up.

But less about the history of the game and more about the story. The game takes place in a town where for many generations its inhabitants have tourmented by a demons and beasts flowing out of a crypt. You
column2: the stranger
column3:
have come to save them for some reason.

The game quickly cuts to the chase with no unnecessary cinimatics or boards. The game is a dungeon game. Some people are turned off by simple exploratory games with very little dynamic. Sure you do the same things: shoot the demon
column4: search the body
column5: grab a arrow
column6: light a torch
column7:
and contuinue on. But what makes this game stick is it is able to create a mood. The widespread use of the colour red really makes the game feel cool. Adding to that are the tons of mangled bodies you find and their darkly comic discriptions.

The ending is a bit thin

column3: but seriously

column5: and when there are more colours

The gameplay seems to play the secondary to the plot. It seems as though Liver had this idea in his/her head for a game and wanted to get it all down as quickly as possible before he/she forgot. column1: Psyche☃"MadTom"☃"madtom@comic.com"☃"Vies with Chickenwire as my favourite Zenith Nadir game. His impeccable skill adds a real finish to the game
column2: with clean
column3:
crafted graphics and carefully arranged text.

Psyche is a dungeon crawl with a difference. At the start of the game a random choice is made ... will you be given the Nadir path
column4: the serious and TEEN ANGST course
column5: or the Zenith path
column6:
with Zenith the showman as we all know him in Chickenwire? It's all up to chance. But whichever way you go first doesn't matter.

The Nadir path presents the third-person past tense narrative of a girl named Mir
column7:
struggling through a dungeon marked with many dead and gruesomely mutilated bodies. A picture of inner turmoil is painted here. Yet with the odd reflection of Mir's we see a slight hint of Zenith ... a tad of humour.

The Zenith path is completely different. Your nameless character is flung into an abyss of complete and utter happy-go-lucky chaos and hilarious disarray. You battle such fierce and fearsome beasts as fleas and tamagochis
column8: and my personal favourite
column9:
Incontinence Man (prone to losing control of his bladder when kicked in the appropriate area).

At the end of each path you meet its creator ... either Zenith or Nadir. Both end your game ... but in decidedly different ways.

The depth of Psyche is something I believe not usually seen in ZZT games. Zenith's characteristic tidy style and amusing insights add a curious charm to the whole game
column10: and it seems very complete. It reveals something about his personal nature

On to the game then. In living dead you play a man called John Williams

the sound effects and graphics really came together for the first (and only) time.

Graphics wise
column16: the game varies in skill from the rather primitive shading of the interiors to the pretty object drawn stain glass windows of a church. There's a lot of a path and a lot of trees that seem to look like a scene from SPRG after a while. The sound is also eclectic
column17: ranging from the awful title screen music to the creepy music in the shed
column18:
it's not a good idea to keep it on all the time.

Gameplay wise
column19: there isn't really much here
column20: unfortunatly. Long walking scenes serve to extend the playing time
column21: but battles for the most part use ZZT's shooting engine and offer nothing new or exciting
column22: and only just keep you away from plot long enough to keep going. Bosses are annoying but bareable
column23: and have the appopriate attacks. The talking scenes are more fun
column24: with the dialouge as cheesy as the plot itself and the game moving at a nice pace. While Commodore lists Romero as an influence
column25: I feel it plays more like 'Evil Dead' than 'Night of the Living Dead. It didn't have such a huge scale as the latter
column26:
and the more blunt comedy was also evident.

The only two things to really complain about was the way you swapped characters without being told
column27: which confused me a little to begin with
column28: and the way the people followed behind you. In a normal RPG
column29: a char will just #die and a flag will be set they are in the party
column30: but in TLD your partner follows you around
column31: making for buggy walking and annoying times when they get stuck. There's no real reason for it
column32:
and it ruins the flow of the game to shoot your partner and have him re-appear on the next board.
It's not enough to stop playing
column33:
but it is enough to annoy very quickly.

In summary
column34: Commodore is destined to go far once he Hones his skils a little. I see in him a young Madtom
column35: and like Madtom
column36: his skills are improving very rapidly
column37: but he still has a long way to go from his rather horrible 'Ghostbusters Demo' to making a renowned game like Burgular. However
column38: I don't wish to hype him as the NEXT anybody
column39: and his future in the community is what he makes it. I wish him the best of luck and hope he continues to improve and make more ZZT games. "☃"1030659156"☃"livedead.zip"☃"3"☃

column16: wake up

column1: Sim: Life☃"John W Wells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"Master Raze's Sim: Life provides an unflinchingly stark look into the life of a promiscuous
column2: drug- addicted
column3: perverse idiot. A welcome departure from Raze's usual themes of sex and death
column4:
S:L carefully explores the grimy worlds of sex and drugs.

The goal of the game is simple - you must accrue 300 "creativity points" and 300 "experience points" to marry the girl of your dreams. To gain these points
column5: you must take up odd jobs
column6: such as impersonating a priest and giving a supposedly funny (and very derivative) confessional
column7: and engage in intercourse
column8: social and otherwise
column9:
with a variety of women.

There's a catch
column10: though. Every few seconds
column11: you lose a bit of health due to hunger. So you also need money to pay for food; standing still for five minutes is a recipe for disaster. That's right. Sim: Life is every bit as hectic
column12: stressful
column13:
and repetitive as real life. Talk about realism!

What money you don't spend on food you can use to buy drugs
column14: which grant creativity points (crack: it does a body good)
column15: purchase pornographic magazines
column16: which apparently disintegrate after a single reading
column17:
or trade in firearms. The net result of this slew of transactions is that the game boils down to a complex math problem.

"Let's see... I have 30 creativity points
column18: so I can do some stand-up comedy and get 45 dollars
column19: which I can use to buy a pistol to sell for a 5 dollar
column20: 2 exp
column21: and 2 creativity point profit. Then I can go and buy a pornographic magazine
column22: return home
column23: and get more experience
column24: but oh
column25:
man. I can't buy food then. Maybe if I go to the prostitute who trades 25 money for a bit of EXP first... "

The above sort of thought sequence repeats over
column26: and over
column27: and over
column28: as it takes a long
column29: repetitive time to get 300 EXP and creativity points. You can speed the process by taking a few "errand boy" jobs
column30: but it doesn't help much. Perhaps I'm missing some way of getting 200 creativity points in one go
column31:
but I don't see it.

What
column32: then
column33: is good about Sim: Life? Well
column34: it does have a few funny moments - although one would hope for more
column35: given that Raze doesn't pull any punches here
column36: and it does have an interesting concept
column37: a few nice sequences
column38: and a decent premise. My recommendation: Play until you have 100 EXP and creativity
column39: and you'll probably have seen the best of what there is to see. "☃"1030659512"☃"simlife.zip"☃"3"☃

column1: About as good as he next game. So long as the next☃"Funk"☃"Wilko_3000@yahoo.com"☃"After the entertaining Wartorn and the tremendous Burger Joint

you know.

column1: The best-- of the BEST!☃"david lover"☃"kisses@david.plz"☃"It is tempting
column2: when writing this review
column3: to rate it on David's looks alone. His hair is soft and fragrant
column4: like mice dipped in Chanel no. 5. His skin is the most delightful chamois one could hope to touch. Looking into his eyes is like looking into deep
column5: unfathomable pools of ocular jelly
column6:
and his teeth are whiter than his audience.

But no! To talk any longer on the dreaminess of David is folly. For here on this CD is a collection of music so divine that it brings tears to my eyes and a lump to my trousers. David's singing skills are so expansive and so experimental that he eschews mere "notes" and "keys" and instead rockets into whole new realms of sound. One minute he sings with the manly grumble of an ox crushed by a pneumatic piston - the next he has the graceful strength of someone sledgehammering blowfish. Soaring vocals go higher than any mountain climber could
column7: even if he had wings and was in a space shuttle. Then just as quickly they swoop down like a suicidal Japanese businessman
column8: hitting the sidewalk with a biological thump. Beats swirl around like kittens in a washing machine as a series of dancing mosquitos tinkle like triangles stapled to a dormouse. Crumbling walls become dirt-trodden werewolves and the flitting
column9:
spritely air of a gibbon can be heard in the distance. And then track 2 begins!

Just look at his experimental titles too - "Du" (you)
column10: "Je T'Aime Means I Love You" (I love you means I love you)
column11: "Wir Zwei Allein" (I am two Alans) and "Danice Dance d'Amour" (Dennis and his Dancing Armour). David is a multicultural icon
column12:
and one to be cherished.

"Hot Shot City" (¡Policía! ¡Él ha robado mi pierna!) is particularly good."☃"1031001440"☃"knight.zip"☃"5"☃"146.229.184.78"

column1: Warning: spoilers for "Apud" and "W☃"Funk"☃"wilko_3000@yahoo.com"☃"I dunno. Maybe it's just me
column2: but Wayward's games always seem vastly overrated. His plots are melodramatic where plain drama would be preferable
column3:
and though they're usually based around a solid central concept they always feel like missed opportunities.

Take Within
column4: for example
column5: which almost everyone creamed themselves over - the basic idea (dreams and reality bleeding into each other) was great
column6: but the characterisation was lame and the actual plot just ambled around until the sudden and preposterous ending. I'd hoped with Apud that Wayward would have developed a little
column7:
but sadly no.

Basically
column8: you play Wayward ( a little self-obsessive don't you think?). Having committed suicide
column9: you float between heaven and hell
column10: and your actions in the game - good or evil - determine which ending you get. Basically this amounts to walking left and right around a looping playfield
column11: using objects in basic fetch-and-retrieve quests until you just can't be bothered
column12: or find anything else to do. Then you just "ascend" and watch your fate be decided. You can actually ascend at any time in the game
column13:
though obviously you stand a better chance of going to Heaven if you play properly.

The graphics are pretty damned nice
column14:
and certainly an improvement on Within. There are also quite a few nice touches - the subliminal message gag and the aging house occupants being just two - but none of these distract from the pedestrian gameplay or uninvolving plot.

Which brings me back to one of my initial points - the idea of someone drifting between two worlds could have been genuinely interesting
column15: but here it's just a bunch of cameos and silly puzzles. For example
column16: Wayward could have used a fictional character and had his struggle in limbo reveal details about his friendships and past
column17: and what drove him to suicide. But no
column18:
it's CAMEOS AHOY!

Well okay
column19: I guess that's what Wayward wanted
column20: but it is somewhat annoying to hear people going on about what a genius game it is when all I can see is one big missed chance."☃"1031343741"☃"apud.zip"☃"1"☃"195.93.33.11"

column1: A True Master of the Dark Arts☃"double berry"☃"youthofnausea@aol.com"☃"I am a veteran RPGer

column3: the latest game in Fishkarrde's masterpiece is definately the best that I've ever had the pleasure of playing. Some RPGers were very disapointed
column4: and consider FFZZT a failure in the world of RPGs
column5:
yet I STRONGLY disagree... I will share my opinions in this review.

Graphics - This is definately the point I judge RPGs the least on
column6: but nonetheless
column7: Final Fantasy ZZT definately delivers in this catagory. The pre-rendered backgrounds are absolutely outstanding
column8: easily the best in any video game I've seen to date (and this is a year after it's been out!) The polygons are EXACTLY what I like in RPG characters... they are based off of Skullie's amazing art
column9: and capture SD anime art VERY well
column10: much better than what I've seen of Chase's in the Final Fantasy ZZT X demo. They move VERY well
column11: with great body language throughout. You really feel like you control the character. I remember thinking in past RPGs such as Chrono Trigger or Final Fantasy 6 (3 in the US) things like "Well why can't Chrono jump on top of this thing?" or "Gosh! Why won't the game let Locke climb across this rock?" or whatever. In FFZZT
column12: I didn't feel that way at all
column13: and felt in complete control of my character. The FMV is absolutely amazing
column14: and
column15: once again
column16: is STILL the best I've seen. It blends flawlessly with the actual gameplay
column17: to create an absolutely amazing storytelling environment. These graphics do not hurt the score at ALL
column18: unlike some gamers
column19: as these are still the best graphics I've seen in not just an RPG
column20: but any GAME to date. (and yes
column21:
I've played alot of games since then)

Music - While not as important as say
column22: gameplay or story
column23: this is an extremely important aspect of any RPG. Guess what? FFZZT delivers. I feel that this soundtrack is Fish's finest work
column24: even outdoing any previous Final Fantasy games (FF4-5-6) and Chrono Trigger
column25: which he helped to work on. Songs such as One Winged Faggot
column26: the Final Ryosuck
column27: Valley of the Sexed-Up Karrde
column28: Trishfood
column29: When Ya Hot Ya Hot
column30: Hey Mr. Wonderful
column31: Kaiser Roll
column32: the ending... I could go on forever! Most all of the songs I listed beat anything on FF6 or CT's soundtrack
column33: which are the two finest video game soundtracks before FFZZT
column34: in my mind. Enough about music
column35:
lets move on to...

Characters - Karrde did a GREAT job creating the amazing characters of FFZZT. I feel that these are some of the best in any RPG to date
column36: if not the best. It seems as though he took the best of Amano's and Toriyama's styles and talents
column37: and combined them for the characters in FFZZT

column41: FF6
column42: FF5
column44: not all of the characters develope

column52: that each have an important role in the story

column54:
Karrde!

Gameplay - one of the most important aspects of an RPG is the gameplay

column57: FFZZT delivers. It takes the best qualities of all of the previous Fish games: the defined characters of FF4
column60: the strategy and fun of Chrono Trigger

column66: while there are some overpowerful Oralsexia (Knights of the Mouth and 4x Cock
column67: mainly) they either take FOREVER to get or require LOADS of AP to level up to be useful. The Anus Break system is one of the best I've ever seen. I mean

it creates a package unmatched in RPG gameplay.

Story - WOW! This is easily the best story in any RPG I've ever played... no contest! It is VERY complex

column93: and one of the best I've ever heard

it has something for everyone!

column3:
okay?

OMFG THE GRAPHICS ARE GREAT OMG OMG OMG!!!

There.

So yes - lovely graphics. But as with almost every Chase Bramlage game
column4: the gorgeous visuals can't make up for the dreadful
column5:
<i>dreadful</i> gameplay.

In the case of NEO
column6: you're tossed from subgame to subgame with only the tiniest fraction of a second before your character is horribly killed by snipers/mines/guards/whatever. There are no helpful explanations of what to expect on each screen
column7: just a brief few seconds before you're tapping the ESC key and glowering at your monitor. Chase's games seem to be less a test of the player's skills and more some kind of twisted Pavlovian experiment
column8: with the player acting out the part of the salivating dog. Except instead of spit
column9:
all you'll have in your mouth at the end of playing is bile.

Assuming you can get through the teeth-gratingly difficult five screens allotted to each character
column10:
you'll get a passcode for the next disc which - apparently - was never released.

The plot is thrown at the player in a 500-word infodump (the lamest of all literary devices) at the start
column11: although it pretty much boils down to "DNDNDNNDNDN SUPER SOLDIERS". There's virtually no actual plot progression because of the missing second disk and frankly
column12: the only real entertainment comes from Bramlage's laughable spelling ("Washingtom
column13:
Philadelpia").

One point for being pretty. None for anything else."☃"1031352086"☃"neo1.zip"☃"1"☃"195.93.33.11"

column1: Apparitions of the SHITTY more like! Ho! Ho! Ho!☃"Funk"☃"wilko_3000@yahoo.com"☃"When I first reviewed this poetry and art collection
column2: I summed it up as "shitty art + crappy poetry = crappy shit". However
column3: I was informed by Kev that this did not constitute "constructive criticism". I shall
column4: then
column5: go through each of the poems one by one
column6:
commenting on the poem and the art that goes with it.

<b>haiku 1</b>: Actually I kind of like this one
column7: although haikus are so rigid they're hard to fuck up. Does fairly well at evoking an image. But what are the headlights reflecting off? Seriously
column8: I'm not taking the piss - you have to clarify the not immediately obvious. And in a haiku that's not possible
column9:
so better to use a less obtuse noun.

<b>poem 1</b>: There are a number of generic amateur poem genres. This one is the "taking an ordinary object and making it a thing of beauty" one. In this case
column10: a fluorescent lamp. Sadly
column11: rather than create any original or interesting images
column12: he just hammers down lots of words like "undulating"
column13: "purity" and "celestial" and hopes they sound good. He even uses the word "decadent"
column14: for fucks' sake. This is so much like a parody of generic teen poetry it's not true. The art's just a bunch of white solids
column15:
fakes and breakables. Why?

<b>haiku 2</b>: Again
column16: it's hard to fuck up a haiku and again this is quite good. In fact
column17:
I'll repeat it in its entirity:

<i>purest wind carries
our empty shells across the
grave mountains downtown</i>

See? The restrictive nature of haiku means that Kev can't give in to his teenpoet sensibilities and slap down as many polysyllabic words as he can - he has to choose his words carefully
column18: and this works well. I would
column19: however
column20: have used "bitter" rather than "purest"
column21: if only because it looks less anachronistic given the images and tone of the other lines. I know some might think that it's changing the point of the haiku
column22:
but I honestly don't think Kev chose "purest" for any reason other than he thinks it looks kind of impressive in a poem.

<b>poem 2</b>: Just when it was going well
column23: it's back to the teenpoetry. Again we're working with a teenpoetry cliche - this time it's the DNDNDNDN GIRL IS PRETTY IN MY DREAMS one. Some of the imagery is more effective here (the image of her floating in a "black wedding dress
column24: eyes blazing" is strong in its simplicity although it is somewhat derivative)
column25: but his insistence on using mathematical symbols
column26: parenthesis and misspelling "thru" makes it look like a Radiohead inlay. Predictable use of reverse-metaphor ("the midnight sky shines brighter than the sun")
column27: and tired subject matter (outside world is grey with rain
column28:
brightened only by Her beauty). Poor art. Disappointing.

<b>haiku 3</b>: Whaddaya know? A crap haiku. Cuts off abruptly
column29:
imagery fails to evoke anything in me. Quite the opposite of haiku 2. Beginning to talk like Rorschach.

<b>poem 3</b>: A big one. Dull subject matter (looking at the lives of people in NYC) not lightened by verbosity. Again
column30: we get words such as "angelic" used more because they look good than because they mean anything. I mean
column31: New York an "angelically restless and spellbound city"? Restless yes
column32: spellbound you could probably sell me on if the subject of the poem was about uncovering that spell (money? the media?)
column33: but ANGELIC? NYC? In fact
column34: calling any city "angelic" is absurd since none of the connotations that the word carries could possibly apply to any city
column35:
let alone the most famously badass town of them all. You can't just throw these words about without qualification.

Parenthesis and maths symbols continue even (though they) are retarded+annoying. Poor puns that are too wordy to work (the line about transcending and descending).

<b>haiku 4</B>: Boring. Another DNDNDN THIS IS WHAT I IMAGINE IT WOULD BE LIKE TO HAVE A GIRLFRIEND poem. Don't tell us that her eyes are "freezing a moment"; that's what the haiku is supposed to BE - a frozen moment of time. Also
column36: don't say "your eyes
column37: intense" - come up with a way of describing the intensity of those eyes. I'm sure you don't want to read a poem about "your shirt
column38: green". Haiku 2 worked because you said the wind carried your "shells"
column39: not your "bodies". See? "Shell" implies both the body and its hollowness
column40: emphasises its fragility and that paradox that it's designed to protect. Choose your words more carefully. The best haikus evoke a feeling
column41:
not describe it.

<b>poem 4:</b> So yeah
column42: there's life in everything
column43: including frickin' parentheses again. Obvious ironic contrast between life and dead things. Dull central concept made duller by the tiresome and formulaic layout of the poem. Rather than offhandedly mention a "skeleton-tree" (a cliche in itself)
column44: why not explore that tree and descibe how it lives still or - if that's your point - how the life has left it forver. Also
column45: rather thn use the usual "life sucks
column47: death angst" crap (you might as well staple a sign to your head saying "I'm a third-rate teenpoet. Ask me how!") why not approach it from another angle? Talk about how life will spring from the tree in
column49:
Spring. Or how those graveyards left untended can become forests (life growing from the remains of death... come on this is - pun not intended - fertile ground). Death for death's sake is just boring.

Conclusion
column50: to Kev and everyone else: THINK about what you're putting down on the paper or on the screen. Look at each word. Does it get across what you're trying to say? Are you just writing what's there
column51:
or are you writing what you want the reader to feel?

Branch out your subjects. Life isn't always grey and miserable
column52: even if you're a teenager. Even Sylvia Plath wrote some wonderfully life-affirming pieces (indeed
column53:
they make up about 33% of the Ariel collection).

Also
column54: Mark Rothko uses pretty colours. You might want to follow his lead."☃"1031357507"☃"appariti.zip"☃"0"☃"172.180.107.119"

column1: Dave2 thinks this game is fun☃"Dave2"☃"dragopublish@hotmail.com"☃"Who would have thought that when you take some pre-fabricated objects and monsters you could make such a fun game?  Anybody could have made this game first
column2:
but Eurakarte does it with real style.

The object of the game is simple: Kill all the snakes. Wether you need to use energizers to plow through the snakes
column3:
or knock them to pieces with a boulder (my favorite method) you must kill all the snakes in order to save Mr. Shapiro's imprisoned friends.

The difficulty of this game was moderate. I hardly ever died
column4: and when I did I looked forward to playing the level again
column5:
instead of cursing at my monitor like I would usually do.

Music was fairly nonexistant
column6: and I think the doctor mario music would have been appropriate.  But really
column7:
this hinders the gameplay in no way.

One big problem with this game: It was far too short. 4 levels? Even had it been a mini-game
column8:
I think MSCNFS should have had at least a few more.

All in all
column9: it was a blast.  And if you didn't get enough the first time around
column10: (and who did?) play this fun

column1: Woah...☃"Dave2"☃"dragopublish@hotmail.com"☃"Burglar.  It's not a game
column2: It's a saga.  You play Luke Steel
column3: a character who you slowly grow to love.  Luke is into the burglary scene
column4:
and decides to join a VERY organized crime. What other crime underworld holds pick-pocketing competitions?

As Luke
column5: you rob houses and apartments
column6:
and you're certainly not restricted to a single line of action. You choose your three pieces of equipment. You can steal EXTRA objects in order to purchase more "batteries" (which are really torches...).

And after all that
column7:
you go on a free style pick-pocket competition. Where you pick pockets from people. And it's so cool. Y'know?

And for a game reminiscent of that Old AKware burglary game
column8: the story lines can't even compare.  Burglar! has many characters you actually need to remember
column9:
one who's name is "Pique Poquet". You actually want to smash in his face after perhaps having lost the competition.

The difficulty is quite moderate. You need to be wise in which items you choose... Would you pick a gun to invade a totally empty house? Use your head
column10: kid.  But in the last few levels
column11:
you'll be constantly reloading your save files... The last level is TOUGH!

All in all
column12: Burglar was a great game.  It is a game you could play with the pope.  It should be a household item.  But it was really hard so I give it a four!"☃"1031374728"☃"burglar!.zip"☃"4"☃"142.161.0.92"

column4: I'm Hollywood's famous Chase 'look at me
column5:
I'm Hollywood's famous Chase "(etc)" Bramlage!' Bramlage!" Bramlage!' Bramlage!" Bramlage.

Chase Bramlage
column6: creator of N.E.O. and Operation: OBRIEN 1&2
column7: is more famously known to ZZTers of a certain vintage for the whining
column8: childish letters he sent to those that gave negative reviews to his games back on zzt.org. This built up something of a resentment amongst several folks
column9:
a resentment that eventually inspired the creation of this game.

You see
column10: Bramlage planned (or plans
column11:
though he hasn't been heard of in a while) to make Final Fantasy ZZT. Fishfood rightly pointed out that making a Final Fantasy ZZT game was pointless as they were all so completely different from one another that you could take pretty much any ZZT RPG and call it "Final Fantasy".

With this in mind
column12: Fish and Wildkarrde created FFZZT
column13: partly to point out the meaninglessness of a FF game made by anyone other than Squaresoft
column14: and partly to piss off Chase
column15:
who would have to change the name of his game before uploading (it wasn't even going to be a Final Fantasy game to begin with anyway; he only changed it to that to drum up publicity).

As a joke
column16: it's pretty damned funny and worthy of 5 stars. But as a game? Well..."☃"1031404429"☃"FFantsy.zip"☃"0"☃"195.93.49.11"

column1: ScouSin's not going to hell!☃"Apud le Medius Res"☃"Scous_In@yahoo.com"☃"   When I saw this game (as recomended by WayWard) I checked it out.  I really wanted to check it out because Octagon was a great hit with IT'S mentality.  But that's a whole new review.  What I want to say about THIS hard to prenounce titled game is that it enforced both sorrow and hatred within me.  It is a genious game among all genious games.  Not because it is "fun"
column2: but because it both proves a point and deserves to be a book.  Enough of my compliments
column3:
now about the game.

I'm going to try to explain this game without spoiling anything. It opens with a cinema of someone jumping off of a cliff (VERY sad) . You then start out in some VERY wierd area in which you have MANY options as to what to attempt first. You go around "doing" stuff for other people. There are several cameos in it too. This game's real story doesn't happen unless it's the very beginning or the very end. You'd think that your character was tripping on acid this whole game or even had downer syndrome
column4:
but that is NOT the case. It is not much to play but to "play".

Where I am getting at is that this game is a work of pure genious in it's storyline. It is WayWard's last game...possably so far or for good. It is sad that someone of this talent in writing has to waste it on ZZT. THIS is what ZZT is all about in the end! But what I really would like to say is to "play through the damn game!"."☃"1032011130"☃"apud.ZIP"☃"5"☃"68.9.33.33"

PPDV raises the pointlessness bar further with pointless music and pointless writing. The pointless characters make the pointless tedium ever the more pointless.

This review is
column3: of course
column4: pointless
column5: because
column6: as far as I can tell
column7: the essence of this trippy game's humor is pointlessness. In theory
column8:
enough pointlessness crammed into the a tiny space is hilarious. The incongruity of the images is supposed to create humor that lacks any sort of punchline.

Trippy? Even a nightmare ostensibly has some sort of internal semi-continuity
column9: the faintest glimmer of a point. I don't know if a drug trip has one
column10: but
column11: if taking LSD is at all like walking through this game

column1: Oh my....☃"Commodore"☃"Jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"    Burgular! was the first game is was impressed with in ZZT. I had just come the the community and Burgular was right there on the front page so I downloaded it. This was also the first ZZT game I had ever seen with STK. So Since the first thing that hit me was the graphics
column2:
let's talk about those.

From 3/4 perspective streets
column3: to surreal interiors
column4: this game has it all. I've always been partial with mixing surrealism in with normal imagery
column5: and the interior of the company building does just that
column6: two ambigous rooms
column7:
and a giant computer. Sitting in what normally would not be a building's shape. Finally the streets where you pick pockets is a wonderful melange of colours that blend in very surreal ways complementing the insanity of the crime you commit. Then we have really well drawn cutscene (granted MadTom is no Chase when it comes to cutscenes) that appear from time to time.

As far as music goes
column8:
the opening music kicked ass. Sometimes I could rip it into MP3 format. Sadly not much more music was featured.

The gameplay was brilliant as well. I personally would've cut down on the instant kills but the last infiltration into the police station was marvelous
column9:
with the rooms slowly revealing themsleves and the ingenuity needed to figure out some puzzles (How many games make you remember Chemistry class?)

Finally
column10: the story. I loved how you had no regrets throughout the whole game. No internal turmoil shit about the moral implecations of stealing or killing
column11:
just fun robbery with a great revenge twist added in.

This game INSPIRED me back into the ZZT world. Of course seeing more than 8 colours helped
column12:
but the brunt of it was in the careful execution of the game.

Thanks MadTom

column1: Oh, bother.☃"JohnWWells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"There's a style of comedy that I call the Comedy of Escalation. In this type of joke
column2: the audience is meant laugh as a situation grows more and more bizarre. An example would be the famous stateroom scene in the Marx Brothers' "A Night at the Opera." At first
column3: a few people occupy a small stateroom. Then cleaning staff come in. Then somebody comes to deliver a meal
column4: and is caught inside with everybody else. Then somebody comes to fix a piece of furniture. And so on. The room
column5: of course
column6: becomes about as tightly packed as a sardine can
column7:
leading to an inevitable punchline.

Nothing Constructive Part One is a hard game to review
column8: because it's missing the punchline. It's cleverly written
column9: with comic tension building as the PC manages to anger one interplanetary power after another
column10: but there's no ending - just a cliffhanger. The story is neatly done
column11: and the action between the cutscenes is well-planned and carefully executed
column12:
but the punchline never comes.

This is to be expected
column13: of course
column14: as it was being saved for the sequel
column15: but there is no sequel. NC Part Two was never released
column16: and probably never will be
column17: as Zanno left the community. What's left is a witty
column18:
fun game without an ending.

Whether or not you can still enjoy the game depends
column19: I guess
column20: on whether you could read
column21: say
column22:
the first two books of the Lord of the Rings and be contented to leave it at that.

I
column23: for one
column24: will take what I can get. As long as it lasts
column25:
NC provides great fun.

Pros: Good graphics

column27: good storytelling

column1:
No, but seriously: are you guys smoking a crack?☃"Funk"☃"Wilko_3000@yahoo.com"☃"Or even some pots?

Nothing Constructive is not well written. It is not funny. The plot is not clever. Jesus
column2:
how low your standards must be to think that this is anyhting CLOSE to being a classic.

Okay
column3: let's take this from the top. Nothing Constructive could potentially have been a great game. However
column4: Zanno has fudged up everything horribly. We being with a classic framing device - our heroes are being held at gunpoint
column5: and the lead character (Zanno. I hate it when people put themselves in their games) flashes back to the start of the chain of events that lead to his current situation. This can be particularly effective
column6: as it provides dual narrative tension - how did he get into this position
column7:
and will he be able to get out again?

But Zanno over-eggs the mixture by having the voice-over constantly harp on about how X was the start of the last week of his life
column8: or Y was the reason he was going to get killed blah blah blah. The framing device should be a tease; something to whet our appetites and fire out imaginations
column9:
not bore us to death with monologues of doom.

But this is made worse by having the narrator tell us not only what happens in the long-term
column10: but in the short-term too. We're told that Zanno is going to be sentenced to death three screens before it occurs
column11: leaving the player staring at a cinema which tells him nothing he doesn't already know. Even the other characters do it - Steve apparently has a limited perception of the future
column12: and repeatedly tells the player that there are baddies in the next room. No surprises. No tension. No reason to keep playing
column13:
except the blody-minded drive to complete the game. Someone needs to tie up Zanno and make him watch "Fight Club" until he <i>understands</i>.

The voiceovers
column14: as I mentioned before
column15: take up a large part of this game. In a movie this can add to the atmoshpere
column16: with the narrator providing an ironic accompaniment to the action
column17: and allowing the viewer to see exactly what his opinions on the current situation are. However
column18:
in Nothing Constructive it's used ALL THE FREAKING TIME. This wouldn't be so bad but it's usually just to hammer in another "I'm going to die soon" anvil.

Now this crappy construction might not be so bad if the plot clever and original
column19: but there's nothing new about a guy who has a package that everyone wants. Of course
column20: all we've got here is the first part
column21: but there's nothing here to warrant any praise. You get parcel. You get into loosely-connected episodic troubles
column22:
people chase you. There are hints that things may not be what they seem but frankly everyone's so boring it's hard to care.

Which brings me onto another problem: characterisation. Zanno begins the game by murdering a guy he doesn't particularly like. Playing a sociopath might be fun
column23: but midway through the game he's taking down robbers and getting pissy when they kill a bunch of hostages. Huh? Jesus
column24:
either the guy's a nut or he's not. Make up your mind.

Aside from that
column25: Zanno's character is paper-thin. He's not particularly funny
column26: and seems to veer between being very dumb and very clever. But he's a fully rounded character compared to Steve
column27: whose "character" is to stand around being smug. There's an attempt (or at least what I assume is an attempt) at rounding him out by having him bicker with a Communist man who joins your party
column28:
but their dialogue isn't sparky or funny enough to seem like anything more than a waste of your time. The rest of the characters are perfunctory and serve to rattle along the creaking plot.

Speaking of the Communist
column29: what IS Zanno's problem here? We're constantly told that Communism is BAD BAD BAD
column30: and from the start Mr. Doom the Communist is shown as an EVIL NASTY GUY who wants to shoot you in the face. Now I'm assuming that this is building up to an incredible revelation where it turns out that the Communists are the true goodies and help you out. If not
column31:
then Zanno's got some kind of redneck-style Communist hatred issues to work out.

Okay
column32: I'm getting tired now so I'll list the rest of the stuff - the game uses dialogue at the bottom of the screen rather than in a text box
column33: which is tooth-gnashingly slow. The bad guys are mostly boring to fight against. It features the world's worst RPG battle (and no
column34: making a joke about how RPG battles suck does NOT excuse it). Ammo's usually in depserately short supply
column35:
and there's often not enough money to buy more. The game world makes no sense. The tertiary characters are stupid. The "humour" is tiresome and formulaic (and in places seemingly ripped off of other sources). The graphics are passable. The programming largely solid.

Overrated."☃"1033604112"☃"nothing.zip"☃"1"☃"195.93.33.11"

column1:
Stratego☃"Nanobot"☃"nanobot@chipx86.com"☃"DESCRIPTION

Stratego is a collection of five challenging puzzles. In each puzzle
column2:
your goal is to reach a white statue that then delivers you a key. You must collect all five keys to procede to the Castle of Stratego.

If you are in the mood for a few good slider puzzles and other such mind challenges
column3: this may be just what you want. This game holds some of the most intricate puzzle that I've seen
column4:
and it should give your brain a nice workout.

SUMMARY

Fun Factor: This game is really fun if you're the puzzle type. As far as solid puzzle games go
column5: this is definitely one of the top. The puzzles are difficult enough ensure that you don't beat it too easily
column6:
yet not so hard that you quickly become frustrated and stop playing.

Gameplay: The puzzles are generally very solid. As in most games with intricate moving parts such as this
column7: there is sometimes and occasional glitch that prevents you from continuing on as normal
column8:
but in most cases you must work hard to create such a glitch on purpose.

Graphics: It's hard to apply a graphics rating in a puzzle game. A wide variety of colors are used on each board
column9: causing your mind to "wake up" and become attentive for the puzzles. There isn't any necessarily attractive graphics
column10:
though that isn't a necessity for a puzzle game like this.

Plot: The plot is minimal
column11:
as would be expected in an average puzzle game. An attempt at a plot is at least shown.

Sound: There is no sound or music in this game
column12:
besides the default sound effects.

SCORES

Nanobot's Genre-Based Weight System

Genre: Puzzle

Fun Factor (75% weight): 80/100
Gameplay (10% weight): 85/100
Graphics (5% weight): 30/100
Plot (5% weight): 40/100
Sound (5% weight): 0/100

Final Percent: 72%
Rating: 4"☃"1033776993"☃"stratego.zip"☃"4"☃"66.122.181.67"

column1: Fun, but needs more polish for a "Silver Edit☃"Ryan Ferneau"☃"rferneau@iastate.edu"☃"It's a nice attempt at transfering the greatness of the show to a game.  The author probably messed up a couple of story concepts
column2:
but that's not what detracts from the game.

The general flow of the story is well-conceived. The first file has an intro level
column3: then challenges the player to find ten golden keys to finish the game and continue to the second file.  (Though for some reason I ended up with an extra key...?)  The coolest part of the deal is that the player gets to choose where to go next.  Some levels can be beaten at any time (sidequests)
column4: while others go in a certain order (main quest).  The scoring system is neat
column5: and the help board explains it pretty well.  The second file is a couple of really hard puzzles and a couple of really hard boss battles that finish off the story.  Overall
column6:
the game did a good job of mixing various gaming genres into a coherent story.

The downside is that the game is really easy to glitch up sometimes
column7: especially on Rytop and Zeta-B7.  The author ought to do some more heavy testing to foolproof the puzzles so they make a bit more sense.  (And if you're trying to block off the player from the passage he/she just entered
column8: DON'T SURROUND IT WITH FAKES AND TRY TO CHANGE THEM TO NORMALS LATER!  If anything
column9: surround the passage with one-way teleporters
column10: then delete them when it's time to leave.)  The other bad thing about the game is that most of its boards look rather ugly.  Mostly it's just the old newbie "gotta fill up the board" syndrome that Tim Sweeney's first three games tended to have
column11: plus the tacky force fields made out of water that change to forest."☃"1036480158"☃"drwho1.zip"☃"4"☃"64.113.91.12"

Guaranteed 100% intro-free☃"JohnWWells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"Plot:

There is a disease of ZZT designers that I like to call... Terminal Introsis. The most common symptom is the placement of a huge knot of exposition in the introduction of a game. When this happens
column2:
it is extremely likely that the writing in the remainder of the game will be minimal. The general effect of this is that it becomes clear that the author wanted to get the plotline out of the way early.

Rogue Three not only dodges this problem
column3: but completely reverses it. Rather than give the player central information at the beginning of the game
column4:
Bitman does something unprecedented.

He creates suspense
column5: and gives out the answers at the END of the game! At last
column6:
a ZZT writer has figured out why mystery and suspense novels sell so well.

The discovery of the nature of the gameworld is left up to the player. Clues are dropped left and right
column7: but complete explanation is saved for the game's ending
column8:
which ties up the plot threads and neatly explains the setting of the game for those who missed the clues.

The ending itself is a mixed bag. To those who don't see it coming
column9: it should seem an extremely clever plot twist. To those who DO see it coming
column10: it will probably seem anticlimactic. It's still neatly done
column11:
though.

Graphics:

A mixed bag. But I don't really care.

Gameplay:

Although Bitman flirts with nonlinearity and multiple scenarios
column12: and has some very clever timer effects
column13:
there are several areas of weakness in the gameplay.

The most noteworthy puzzle of the game is a clever slider puzzle that requires considerable forethought. It is surprisingly good
column14: and brings a bit of life to the tired formula
column15: but it's still a slider puzzle. Some might object
column16:
I suppose.

The other sticking point in the gameplay is an "underground cavern" sequence of darkened rooms
column17: monsters
column18: and
column19: if you are unlucky enough to be thrown onto one particular plot thread
column20: insufficient ammo. The sequence isn't long
column21:
but it's completely unnecessary.

The third
column22: and greatest
column23: weakness of the gameplay is the large ratio of walking to actual playing. There are some very nice landscapes
column24:
but they are often essentially empty of noteworthy objects.

On the bright side
column25: the cutscenes and dialogues are in text box form
column26: and can thus be read quickly
column27:
without the ridiculous "one line every ten seconds" format that results when an author decides to use the bottom-of-the-screen marquee text approach.

Overall:

A very nice game
column28: with a creative plotline. It has its weak spots but
column29: at its best
column30: it reminds me vaguely of Isaac Asimov's "Nightfall.""☃"1036546110"☃"rogue.zip"☃"4"☃"131.215.90.232"

column1: Oddly amusing.☃"JohnWWells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"The cameos of A Community X-Mas are inaccurate. In fact
column2: the game's writers specifically state this at the game's opening. And so
column3:
an obvious question arises:

Why make a cameo game with inaccurate cameos? Doesn't that miss the point?

This becomes even more of a problem due to the nature of ACX-M's gameplay. Much of gameo consists of walking around and talking to the cameo objects. There's a mystery plotline tying everything together
column4: and a refreshingly different endgame
column5: but the majority of the game still consists of wandering around talking to people whose names you recognize. When the names don't match the personalities
column6:
the game naturally feels flat.

This is a puzzle to me. Why take an excellent premise ("ZZTers are trapped in a palatial chalet in the snow
column7:
and begin disappearing one by one. Whodunit?") and then rob it of its charm by leaving out the one thing that would make it really compelling: the personalities? Why throw away the chance to make people actually interested in finding out whether or not their persona is the villain? There's an astounding amount of wasted opportunity here.

On the other hand
column8: ACX-M would be a decent ZZT game even if all the recognizable names were discarded. There are some amusing bits
column9: the whole game is very nicely illustrated
column10:
and the Rube Goldberg sequence in the endgame is particularly clever.

Summary: Forget trying to associate the characters with their online personas
column11: and just act as if ACX-M didn't contain anybody you knew. In those circumstances
column12: it's actually pretty entertaining."☃"1038134645"☃"comxmas.zip"☃"4"☃"131.215.90.102"

column1: And now I would like to present "Hamlet ZZT&q☃"JohnWWells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"Well
column2: I'm not exactly certain what to say about this game. It's brilliantly hilarious
column3: but that's because it pulls all of its dialogue from the brilliantly hilarious novel upon which it is based. On the other hand
column4: it isn't exactly an act of plagiarism
column5:
as Nanobot credits Douglas Adams with the dialogue...

Gameplay:

I suppose the most fitting genre for this demo would be "semi-interactive tribute." It's mostly composed of cutscenes
column6:
with the exception of one well-executed interactive sequence that nicely captures the atmosphere of the novel's opening.

Graphics:

Varied. The cutscene graphics are nice
column7: and I really liked the title screen
column8:
but the scene in Arthur Dent's house was a bit bland.

Writing:
Brilliant
column9: as I mentioned. Also in violation of copyright laws
column10: but what can you do? Nanobot trimmed and edited some of the funnier passages from the book and used them for the game's dialogue
column11: and the effect is generally a positive one. However
column12: some of his transitions are careless
column13:
and his mixing of quotations sometimes results in abrupt shifts in tense.

Oh
column14:
and it won't be QUITE as funny if you've read all the jokes before.

Final Verdict:

This could be a good game if the cutscenes were minimized and replaced with more gameplay. Actually stomping around the house as Arthur Dent [1] has its charms
column15: and exploring the Heart of Gold in the full version could be extremely fun. However
column16: the editing of Adams' work needs to be more careful
column17:
and the quoting less extensive.

[1] The comic timing of this segment is thrown off somewhat by the interactive nature of the sequence
column18: but it's still not bad. Infocom did a better job of it
column19: though

column1: Evan Darrow games...☃"krzhang"☃"krzhang@cox.net"☃"From what I remember
column2: Evan Darrow was a designer back in the days of 1992-1995ish times
column3: when ZZT was really active on AOL (sadly
column4: the service for ZZTers has all but disappeared). Evan Darrow wanted to charge for many of his games
column5: but the games were very amatuerish
column6: usually resulting in no plot
column7: and gigantic meshes of battles with premade monsters and slightly-programmed objects. I really don't suggest that any of Darrow's games are worth looking at
column8: even though they were done at such an early age. An example of a game of much better quality but was done at the same time is Link's Adventure Trilogy
column9: and although that game will not be ranked highly now (post-STK era)
column10:
the game was definitely a classic of the time. Darrow's games will be not.

-Yan"☃"1038755657"☃"roleplay.zip"☃"0"☃"64.121.6.19"

column1: Lost Gem?☃"krzhang"☃"krzhang@cox.net"☃"Hey
column2: its my first review. I've been playing ZZT since like 1993
column3: but haven't made anything since then so probably nobody knows me. (I code in C). But since I have played a lot of games
column4: I guess I'll offer a few reviews
column5:
this being the first.

I always thought Fury Spell was a very impressive title
column6: which is disappointing
column7: given that I never really saw it given a great review
column8:
and found it lying on some random website. However...

Get the bad things out of the way. The plot has nothing too special here. "Evil Wizard killed your master and you must avenge him" or something
column9: though I must say that the ending is very interesting. In the music department
column10:
I don't think there was anything spectacular. Some tunes were fine though.

The graphics were really good for its age
column11:
I think. The RPG graphics were well-designed and the shading showed adequate experience in ZZT graphics. The subtle animations were dutifully worked on.

Gameplay... I think this game really shines here. I like the concept of collecting spells from different sources and using them in RPG-battles everywhere. RPG Battles have now become commonplace
column12: ever since probably 1999
column13:
but the Fury Spell works it out fine. My only complaint was that the last battle was ANNOYINGLY annoying to win.

I really thought this was a good game. Recommended.

-Yan"☃"1038756236"☃"fury.zip"☃"4"☃"64.121.6.19"

and the idea of conserving limited resources is greatly appreciated.

Thanks! A nice title indeed.

column1: i hate this game and i hate you too☃"Nadir"☃"nadir427@hotmail.com"☃"If Tseng games were ice cream
column2: Gem Hunter SE would be Rocky Road
column3: Mega Job would be Mint Choc Chip
column4: and November Eve would be Brandy and Butterscotch; a good idea in theory
column5:
but in practice overrated and just a little crap.

The plot leads on from Gem Hunter 2; following Kim's kidnapping by Aric on planet Seegeeb and Gem Hunter's saving of her from rabid dobermans
column6: the two head to the Da Hood capital (whose name I forget)
column7: and make a visitation to an opera. Towards the end of the torturous performance
column8: however
column9: one of the actors begins acting (duh) strangely; before action can be taken
column10: the entire audience spontaneously combusts
column11: eith the exception of Kim. Gem Hunter survives being burnt horribly
column12: and is taken to hospital while Kim goes after the killer; only to find he is possessed by an evil spirit or something called Steve who is making the xamboxumbadria of the Da Hood citizens (similar to earth's mitochondria) overcharge and explode. Being from Earth
column13: Kim is not in possession of this organelle perculiar to Da Hood
column14: and is therefore the only person able to approach Steve. With the help of Tyrone and the Boys in Blue
column15: she tries to stop Steve before he blows up the entire city. The plot's a rip of Parasite Eve
column16:
and I like it.

So I like the plot. So why 2/5? Instead of writing a whole lot of crap I'll condense my scathing into a few bullet points;

* annoying RPG battle engine which is too slow to manouvere
column17:
mildly confusing and requires no real stategy beyond "dodge the bullets"
* horribly tedious "flashing line at bottom of screen" cinemas with borderline retarded dialogue
* inverted shading ruins the otherwise neat graphics
* too damn many of the aforementioned horribly tedious cinemas
* irritating
column18: repetitive title screen and cinema music (courtesy of Kev Carter
column19: who usually wrote much better (except the stuff in Freedom
column20:
of course))

Having said that
column21: there's a few nice touches. Having all the cameos in the game explode horribly was neat
column22: as was the effect of having Flatcoat Lab explode and 'turn into' a dark grey charred corpse was neat. The idea of having a third
column23: locked file with a proper ending also adds to the gameplay
column24: and the third file is admittedly engaging
column25:
having mini-games and a battle with craNKGod. But the game is less than the sum of these parts.

Don't get me wrong

column27: it's better than Welcome to Hell
column28:
which in terms of ice cream is that horrible Rum and Raisin flavour. =(

My advice here is to skip the game and just play the third file!

column1: Well, I like it. In that funny-feeling-in-my-loins☃"Commodore"☃"Jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"    Rebirth is all in all a good ZZT game. Compared to recent releases

column4: sometimes. The music seems to have no direction and takes wierd turns. But it is used properly and is never tedious. The music is used not just to add depth to a scene

and that's the most you can ask.

The graphics are spot on. Good shading and drawing on buildings andsuch. The forests are a little lack lustre
column7:
but I really enjoyed the caves. They even had stagmites. Sadly there were very few art boards.

So the graphics were good and the music was good. What went wrong?

Well
column8: it was partly the gameplay. It might've been easier for those young'uns out there who can remember every Tekken move on the face of the planet (i think there are 2 million?) but it just either didn't translate well into ZZT or i'm just dyslexic. I was able to kill
column9: but mainly avoid
column10: my enemies
column11: but it just didn't lend itself to aiding the rest of the game. The concept is great
column12: don't get me wrong

column14: or in my case avoid (another flaw
column15: you could get through a lot of the game with little challange.) a lot of monsters in a lot of areas. This lent to frustration as a dying player could not properly execute his moves whilst surrounded my ten monsters. Well
column16: for this sort of battle system

column18: that way you can have a nice 1 on 2
column19:
1 on 3 battle with creatures that knew their way around the ring making battle a little more interesting.

column3: with the obligatory battle between Science and Magic

the writing is a mixed bag.

really.

column1: Mom would be proud.☃"Commodore"☃"Jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"Ezanya is a really good game. The problems are minor yet very detracting to the gameplay. There are some programming errors

column6: the writing is top notch with detailed descriptions and some really nice imagery. The game is very diffucult to beat though and I did have to cheat in some parts where health was really running thin. A position that presented itself a few too many times was having 10-20 health and having to back track through walls of spinning guns. A really good game definetly worth downloading to see some of the better gems in 1991 bag of games. Someone needs to make an SE. :D  "☃"1040601890"☃"Ezanya.zip"☃"4"☃"68.112.246.23"

column1: One of the best from 1991.☃"Commodore"☃"Jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"Smiley Guy is one of the best. With very non-linear gameplay (for the time at least)
column2: nice graphics
column3: and good gameplay. This game was so good that when Zenith made a SE
column4: he only had to change the graphics. The only pre-programmed monsters in the entire game was a set of centipedes at the begining. From begining to end this game drips of originality. The story is bizzare and funny. Treking through a monster/robot is engaging and it's neat to see all the different parts of the body. The puzzles incoperate flags accross many different boards; while a standard now
column5: it certainly was not in 1991. Then when you think the game will sucumb to the archetypes of 1991 standards and you just know that the last boss will be shooting in four directions and throwing an ungodly amount of stars
column6: he doesn't. And instead you playfully chase him around the room until you catch him. The graphics were great and sometimes very humourous. There is little that makes this game weak
column7: except for perhaps the deep throat boards and the mazes. But even the maze was interesting. And the deep throat boards were the earliest of this type i've seen. My advice
column8: PLAY THIS GAME. You won't regret it."☃"1040757852"☃"Smiley.zip"☃"4"☃"68.112.246.23"

column1: Yo ho ho and a bottle of fun☃"Commodore"☃"JDDGames@Yahoo.com"☃"Deceiving Guidance is a very impressive and fun game. It really go out on a limb to create something both original and fun for the player
column2: and it succeeds. Because this is a very complex game
column3: I will attempt to devide everything into sections
column4:
yet somethings will bleed over.

Story: From the begining I thought the story was good. I was pleasently suprised when by the end of the game it got even better. The tribulations between the mysterious Dark elves (The drow) and the light elves of the overworld
column5: made for a wonderful contrast in moods as the game progressed from the nice village to the wild forest
column6: to the cave
column7: to the drow lair. There was plenty of history provided along with details of cultural differances. There was a nice twist and a good ending that did leave me feeling that there should be a sequal. My onlt qualm with the story
column8: which is more of the writer's choice
column9: was the fact that it didn't seem epic. Even though it only happened in an area maybe 2 miles wide it still could've captured more of a scope. Look at Diablo
column10:
it only takes place underneath one town!

Graphics: In standard IF style the graphics were well polished and added very much to the overall feel of the game. The first file was the most impressive with lovely cottages and well drawn forest scene. I've seen better caves
column11:
but in general the proper atmosphere was set and the gradual transformation from cave to lair was a very mood setting effect. The cutscenes at the end of the game were what really set the second file apart from the first and the last board was a great capstone to the entire game.

Gameplay: Nothing spectacular here. The standard run up and touch a creature to death. Something I'm not to good at and I had to play the game a few times to survive till the end. It was good challange but in the end my tactic was to avoid as much as possible
column12: making for a game without gameplay. Had battle been a little less of a hassle
column13: then there would be more fun. (YAY another thing to kill!) There was little exploration in the forest
column14: yet the caves made up for it which in this case was a bad thing. I expected that the caves would be built around the same semi-linear fashion as the forest. Yes this is somewhat a bad call on me
column15: but once again I had to play  through a few times. This time the reason was not dying
column16: although I did my fair share of that
column17: it was lack of torches. I had to play through a few times finding out where everything was before loading it back up and running through doing what I had to do before the life-sustaining light ran out. In the caves another gameplay change is the addition of a "gun" actually its magic but you get the ability to now shoot at yuor enemies. I'm torn on this one. It seemed the proper thing to do
column18: but also it seemed like the programmer(s) were making it easier for you. In the caves
column19:
you could no longer avoid your enemies as well as you could before. This makes me wonder if even the programmers technique in the forest was avoiding enemies. Not a good sign.

Music: Better than what I can do
column20:
I'm jealous. Used perfectly.

The Puzzle: Well
column21: this thing haunted me for nights after playing it. Usually in slider puzzles you know what order they are supposed to go in
column22: in this puzzle you need to figure it out. I think I must've missed something early in the game that would have helped me with what it was supposed to read because this thing took me as long to beat as the rest of the game. Clever and a good piece of programming
column23:
but it could be a game unto itslef and SEVERLY ruins the pace and mood the entire first file was attempting to create.

Overall: One of the best games ZZT has ever seen. It could be better(Gameplay!)
column24: but I can't argue with the high calibre story and sensational graphics. Two thumbs up

column1: Good game☃"WildWeasel"☃"wildweasel_lemon@hotmail.com"☃"Being a fan of Squaresoft RPG's in general (Parasite Eve in particular)
column2: I naturally had to grab this game. Essentially a parody of the Parasite Eve game
column3: it's handled quite well
column4:
from the RPG battles to the cinema sequences that are almost the same as the originals (I dont count the dialog in the similarity).

The game starts with Gem Hunter and Kim playing a game of 5-card stud poker. They had taken a bet: if Kim wins
column5: she gets to drag Gem Hunter wherever she would like to for the night. Kim wins
column6:
and she takes Gemmy ("I TOLD you to quite callimg me Gemmy!!") to an opera at Migraine Hall.

It all stays the same; just incredibly boring
column7: until the people start setting fire. One of the actors is possessed by Steve
column8: who has control of the Xamboxumbadria in all beings. And so
column9:
Kim must stop Steve.

The battles are handled quite well
column10: with te ability to attack your enemy
column11: use special attacks
column12: or heal yourself. It's a lot more involved than most other ZZT RPGs
column13: all because of the variety in ways you can attack (instead of "ATTACK" and "DEFEND"). While waiting for your AT gauge to charge
column14: you must dodge the attacks of the enemy. Its usually more fun if you set the ZZT game speed up by 3 notches. Add to that
column15: you have 3 equippable weapons
column16:
and the ability to find new items and November Energy abilities to use on enemies (or yourself).

The cinema sequences
column17: which are used to advance the story A LOT
column18: are handled like most other ZZT games. It takes a while to see where all the characters are
column19: and what they're doing. The dialog is entirely done using message row text (and since this isnt MZX
column20: its flashing
column21: but I can deal with it). The only thing preventing me from ?ZAP-ing my way to the next board was the funny dialog
column22:
courtesy of Tseng.

It's amazing that such a game can be done so well in ZZT
column23:
so I give Tseng's effort 4.5/5.

IN REVIEW:
HIGHS - Good graphics in most parts
column24: funny dialog
column25:
RPG battles handled well for the most part
LOWS - Cinemas can get boring.
BOTTOM LINE - A good ZZT RPG

Traipse through an ultra-derivative plotline and meet flat
column2: uninteresting characters while performing flat

uninteresting tasks.

Elemental crystals of immense power? Check.

Player character is a knight in service of a possibly megalomaniacal king? Check.

Old childhood friend who happens to be a skilled thief? Check.

A "stop the bandits who are robbing our village" subquest? Check.


Graphics:

Here
column4: FFZZT shines. This is great work - detailed
column5: varied
column6:
and textured. Some very nice animations round out what is probably one of the most well-illustrated games I've seen in a while. The effort that went into these scenes is obvious and commendable.


Writing:

The writing in FFZZT ranges from the trite and mediocre to the utterly horrible. Spelling and grammatical errors abound
column7: and the story takes quite a while to creak into action. It's all rather threadbare
column8:
and actually made the Final Fantasy movie look good. This writing left me begging for claptrap about Gaian Spirits and Bold Sacrifices By Dull Heroes.

The worst part is
column9:
it's _still_ better than the majority of ZZT games.

Gameplay:

Not much new here
column10: really. The turn-based battles near the beginning of the game soured me on combat
column11:
and the gameplay didn't really improve particularly much from there.

Overall:

A good effort
