column1: Christing Puce!☃"Funk"☃"Wilko_3000@Yahoo.com"☃"Bramlage is
column2: yes
column3: probably the finest artist the ZZT commune has ever encountered. However
column4: like most artists his skills do not extend too far beyond his chosen art. Remember Picasso's novels
column5:
or Van Gogh's symphonies? No? Exactly.

The title screen is spectacularly unappealing
column6: but the intro sequence is nothing less than gorgeous (the picture of the planet is probably the nearest ZZT will ever get to photo-realism). The art
column7: however
column8: serves to highlight how dreadful Chase is at writing - not just in composing sentences ("When the clash of swords echo [sic]
column9: the journey chasing the past ends
column10: and the journey to know today begins..")
column11: but also in knowing exactly how to pace his drama. For a guy who wants to become CAPTAIN HOLLYWOOD
column12: Chase sure doesn't seem to understand how stories should work. Take the second intro screen
column13: for example; the player is treated to a fantastic animated picture of our hero - one so detailed that his mouth and eyes move
column14: and his hair sways in the breeze. Now a GOOD storyteller would - well
column15: <i>tell the story</i> and leave all the pretty animations as pleasant background details. Not Chase though! He has us sit there and be told that "A calm wind brushes against your face. You close your eyes and breathe deeply" (cue animation) "BLAH BLAH you look down at the courtyard" (cue animation) "BLAH BLAH you watch people walking by" (cue animation) until we really <i>understand</i> how much detail has gone into the graphics. Of course
column16: this is horrible to sit through; aggressive self-aggrandizement is never a pretty sight
column17: especially when one is trying to enjoy a story. It's like JK Rowling stopping in the middle of a sentence and saying "See? Isn't Severus Snape a clever name? Doesn't it just sound all EVIL?" - it's ugly
column18:
intrusive and makes the author look like a twat.

Sadly
column19: Chase is unable to maintain the high level of graphics throughout the game; though the mountainside looks fantastic and some of the smaller villages are alright
column20: pretty much all of the first city is horrible. Take the inside of the king's castle for example - Chase relies too much on diffused shading
column21: so that everything lacks definition; walls blend into the floor blends into the carpets that almost hide tiny blue soldiers. In something like VGA it would have been okay
column22: but when you have as few "pixels" as ZZT provides
column23: the screen just looks like a jumble of random blobs. Yes you can pick out shops and fountains if you look closely
column24: but the player shouldn't have to strain to make out where they're going. If the graphics are the best thing about this game and they aren't even all that good
column25:
you should have a rough idea of how fun this is to play.

Okay
column26: let's move along then shall we? The plot itself concerns a young man who is sent on a mission to get taxes from asuidsuifoh -- sorry
column27: I lost consciousness and hit the keyboard with my head. Where was I? Oh right; this lad needs to get taxes for his king
column28: who aims to get the four crystals of s;zghkljda -- crap
column29: I did it again. Uhm
column30: so this lad goes to the village but finds that they're suffering attacks by bandits rxzgkjhoih --oh look
column31: I can't do it; the plot's just too dull. It may well have been ripped off from Suikoden - I haven't played that game - but at least there you apparently had an expansive game world and decent gameplay. Here you get-- well
column32:
let's take a look shall we?

After the intro (which lasts about fifteen years)
column33: the first bit of 'gameplay' involves asking a guard for a password so you can leave the castle. Why on EARTH would you need a password to LEAVE the king's castle? Not only is this bit really stupid
column34: it serves no purpose but to further delay the game proper. Whilst little stupid things like this may make the game last longer
column35:
it's something of a false economy. What's the point of making the game last another five minutes if those five minutes are boring? If Chase had put in some proper puzzles (perhaps you needed to knock a guard dog out with some poisoned meat) then at least the player would spend their time doing something entertaining.

So you leave the castle and enter the (very ugly and pixilated) village. Again
column36: you have to do a series of small but annoying and pointless little actions before the game can progress - go to the weapon shop
column37: then return home to watch a cinema then FINALLY get the chance to leave the town and get on with the game. Frankly
column38: this could have been solved by just being given a big sword and sent on your way ala Ned the Knight (which is surely the template for such games)
column39: but no! Instead you have to be introduced to your father
column40: sister
column41: friend and servant who all talk EXACTLY THE SAME. Seriously; there are no distinguishing features between any of these characters
column42:
except for their names and sexes. No doubt some of them will be bumped off as the series progresses but Chase is going to have to buck up his writing if he expects us to care about them.

Right
column43: we're outside and introduced to the crappiest world map ever. Firstly
column44: there are the RPG battles - blue boxes "randomly" open up with the option to either fight or flee the baddies. In practice
column45: this involves both sides attacking each other and doing <i>the same amount of damage each time</i>. Seriously
column46: would it have been so hard to knock up a randomizer
column47: or at least give more options than just "attack" and "run"? All bad guys of the same type do the same amount of damage and take the same amount of attacks to kill. No variations
column48: no spectacular hidden moves - why not just subtract 15 health and then die? Hell
column49: sometimes you can't even run so your options are "fight" or - er - "fight". And you still have to select the option
column50:
which just makes it even more irritating.

Worse
column51: there are little objects running about the maps that engage you in arcade-style fights
column52: so that you have to barge into them a few times before they die. There's nothing to stop them attacking you during RPG fights
column53:
so that in-between the blue boxes you can be losing health from a pack of bats or something.

And I haven't even started on the random deaths in the mountains! Stand too close to the edge and you'll die without warning! Push the wrong boulder and you'll die without warning! Step on a pressure plate and spears?ll skewer you! Question: Since when has arbitrary death ever been fun? Answer: NEVER!

And what about the 'proper' RPG battles? Lifeless. You do damage on bad guys but there's no real indication (No flashing "YOU DID DAMAGE TO THEIF 2!" or injury animations)
column54: and the moves are distinctly unimaginative. In fact
column55: the RPG fight against the cave thieves stuck after a bit
column56:
so I had to zap my way out.

Which reminds me! The game has tonnes of bugs. Accidentally fail to select a name in the intro screen and you'll be stuck looking at your character's hair waving in the breeze forever. Accidentally fail to say yes or no to the chap in the castle and again you'll be stuck until you restart. Enter your house again after the "father/sister" cinema and you'll be flung to the start (though that might be a ZZT problem due to filesize). Only one of the exits from the cave leads to the correct cinema - the rest go straight to the fight. Gimlio's "Dragon" attack (I wonder where Chase 'borrowed' that from?) does nothing at all. These and many more mistakes appear throughout the game
column57: frequently resulting in reloads. Apparently three people beta tested this game. Presumably they just skipped through a lot of it
column58: because there's simply no plausible way that they could complete it without finding at least one crippling bug. And let's not forget the spelling mistakes! Chase is hardly the most literate gent in the universe
column59: and though Herc did his best to find all of them
column60:
there are still little mistakes here and there (including a classic your/you're mix-up).

This is a horrible
column61: horrible game. It splutters and misfires repeatedly
column62: is no fun to play whatsoever
column63: has a thoroughly boring plot and even its best features - the graphics - are not without their problems. Final Fantasy gets a 0.5 for graphics and nothing for anything else. Do us a favour and learn from your mistakes
column64: Chase. You've made far too many games that are pretty but thoroughly lack fun."☃"1042201645"☃"ffdisc1.zip"☃"0.5"☃"150.237.47.2"

column1: Put simply 'a great game'☃"TTTPPP"☃☃"The game is in a simple style
column2: with most boards having clear definition between walls and floor.  It uses the colours well
column3:
and for the first few boards has full background detail (scenery which you can get to). However this fairly well stops by about the fourth or fifth board.
The aim of the game is to carry out tasks
column4: though it's not always clear what to do next.  This
column5: I think
column6: brings out much of the fun in the game.  There were a couple of moments where I thought that I was fairly lucky to touch an object
column7: but the majority of the time there are obvious objects
column8: which tell you what needs to be done to them
column9: or with them.  There is a bit of running back and forth and testing to see if things work or not
column10:
but it doesn't subtract from the game.
The game was a good length and had a sensible number of boards.
The only negative thing I have to say is that I wasn't too impressed with the ending
column11: it seemed a little unexplained (especially the dark grey creature on one of the last few boards).  Having said that I did like the end text

column1: A refreshing social commentary.☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"    This game is drenched in political messages. Just from the opening title can you see the message is already clear
column2: featuring a gun superimposed over an American flag. The design of the school itself is marvelously accurate in an abstract way. It's not that it's a "school". It's a symbol of our school experience. There is little direction given to us as we procede. instead seemingly insignificant choices lead to our successes and failures
column3: and (as the game poigantly illustrates) failure occours more often than success. Then we get to the shooting. the only actual shooting in the game is hardly a challange. You go into a classroom
column4: and kill students
column5: who are all alligned in a row waiting and come at you pretty much one at a time. no skill is required to get to the room
column6: or even kill the students. in fact
column7:
if it's only the first time you've played the game then you usually think that you've come to the room accidently. And you're probably just as surprised as the students in the room.

this game is a strong statement in a universal package. The graphics are abstract
column8: and could concievealbly be any school. A remarkable piece of work indeed. "☃"1042849072"☃"schoolzzt.zip"☃"5"☃"134.241.2.49"

column1:
Pure genious in a glass☃"TTTPPP"☃"tttppp123@hotmail.com"☃"Winter is an extremely well made game. The boards line up seemlessly and the graphics give a wonderful sense of 'uniformity' to the game.
Plot:
There is a fairly limited plot in the game
column2: but it's a puzzle game and doesn't really need one.  You are in a classroom and start to daydream... (see Flammable Monkey's review).  But basically the plot is of the sort - you are somewhere
column3:
but you want to be somewhere else.
Graphics:
The graphics are great
column4: nice use of blues and whites to give the game a cold feel to it.  There are some very detailed boards and some which are just one big object.  Posibly the worst graphics was the top of the tree
column5:
which wasn't really bad at all.
Puzzles:
All of the puzzles were entertaining. Without exception. There was a fairly large range of puzzles as well
column6: some revolving around key and door problems
column7: some around memory
column8: some mazes and some where the biggest puzzle is working out what the puzzle is.  There are a few which you can muck up badly enough that you can't go on
column9:
so it's worth saving before attempting each puzzle.
Sound:
This game uses little bleeps and twiddles to speak to you. There is no text (words making a sentence type text) except in the info screen. Instead you rely on things making happy arpedgios for good things
column10: rising blips for something being turned on
column11: etc.  This makes the game much more fluent than a game with large blue text boxes whenever you enter a room
column12: or press a button
column13:
or whatever.
Overall:
This is probably the best puzzle game I have played from the archives
column14: and posibly the best ZZT game of any sort I have played."☃"1043582795"☃"winter.zip"☃"5"☃"131.111.8.101"

column1: ZZT Nirvana☃"Flaming"☃"OkComputer135@aol.com"☃"For Death Gate
column2: it is not a matter if it is a five star game or not. Rather
column3: it is a matter if you can have too much of a good thing in ZZT. You have five of the greatest minds in possibly the entire history of ZZT
column4: Wil
column5: Zenith Nadir
column6: Hercules
column7: aetch
column8: and Hydra78
column9: coming together to make a single ZZT game. The thought of it is enough to put any ZZTer in heaven. But is it as good as we expected? The answer is undoubtfully yes. Death Gate brings out the best in each of the authors. Each contrasts the other to make it a superb gaming experience like no other
column10: like a fine gourmet meal. From the  musical stylings of Wil and aetch
column11: to the beautifully drawn boards of Hydra78 and Hercules
column12: a graphical nirvana
column13: and the wit and pure enjoyability of Zenith Nadir. And to top it all off
column14: one of the most original and excellent science fiction plots
column15: not only in ZZT
column16: but quite possibly in all of science fiction. So
column17: as far as Death Gate is concerned
column18: you cannot have too much of a good thing."☃"1043706331"☃"dgate.zip"☃"5"☃"205.188.208.170"

column1:
Planets☃"Quantum"☃"christophermounce@gmail.com"☃"I'm surprised that this game hasn't received much attention.

First
column2: the disclaimer. As a game
column3: Planets is only so-so. Controlling your ships is cumbersome. This can be forgiven to a certain extent - it <i>is</i> a ZZT game
column4: and you've only got a few keys on the keyboard to work with. However
column5: there are still a couple of glaring problems. For one
column6: the programming is not idiot-proof. You have to be very careful when you move your ships
column7: because it is possible to break the game. Attacking other ships (and the other player's planet) can be confusing. There isn't much strategy involved - both sides have the same number of ships
column8: and all ships are equal
column9: as far as I can tell. There are a few sound effects
column10:
but no music. The ending is lackluster.

Now that that's out of the way
column11: I'll tell you what I like about Planets. The engine is innovative and very ambitious. It is a <i>turn-based strategy game in ZZT</i>
column12: and as far as I know
column13: it's the only one. The execution might not be stellar
column14: but it isn't a horrible game either - it's fun to engage enemy ships and watch the health meters with suspense. The graphics are pretty good
column15: too. What really strikes me
column16: though
column17: is that it was written in 1996
column18: a year before ZZT was released as freeware. Now
column19: I'm pretty sure this wasn't the first engine game ever
column20: but it's early
column21: it's advanced
column22:
and I'm surprised I haven't heard of it before (or seen a similar type of game in ZZT).

It's not a brilliant game
column23: but it does offer some entertainment value
column24: and it's a clever little engine. Definitely worth a look."☃"1174100224"☃"planets.zip"☃"3"☃"140.142.173.84"

column2:
I was unaware of this dave2 fellow until this plucky young chappie approached me on the streets of London town with a propostion I shall never forget.

"Shine ya shoes please guv'nor?"

It was at this point I realised ZZT would never be the same again. I promptly took him into my household and presented him with a computation device that would be able to sustain his enormous creative impulses indefinetly. Once hooked up to this "Computational God/Machine" he began to produce things the likes of which had never been seen before!

It is good to see that this has been released to the decent public with the purpose of increasing the splendour and glory of the British empire
column3:
may she reign over the uneducated fool indefinetly.

The way this game dealt with the allocation of personality struck me as a profound way of interpreting how we define both ourselves and others in society
column4: indeed many of my psychologist friends have suggester a nobel prize should be in order for a thing which in essence capture the spirit of human identity. The three progressive levels evidently point to stages of evolution in society

column7: I had no idea what to expect. Should I act smart? Should I act stupid? How should I type? What should I say? I had to learn these things the hard way. I was ridiculed for months by the likes of "Power Hungry Admins" and "Zamros" (Avoid zamros by all means

is KRACKEN. I bet you didn't know that!

So

☃"double berry"☃"yotsua@aol.com"☃"One of the most unique and thought-provoking games ever made
column2: Coolart is a fascinating tale of religion
column3: history
column4: and superstition that ranks among the least-known underdogs of all time. The game is set in the 10th and 11th centuries AD
column5: during the Heian period in Japan when Kyoto was known as Heiankyo. The game includes episodes drawn from a large body of tales
column6: legends and illustrated literature produced during or after the Heian period. These vignettes are edited into interactive
column7: experiental forms
column8:
to allow the user to realistically sense the worldview and lifestyle of an ancient time. The game was inspired by The Tales of Genji and similar Japanese folktales.
Your character in the game is a no-name male traveler
column9: an ordinary human being who is faced with opportunities
column10: driven by desires
column11: and is bound to die. Your actions determine your path through this world
column12: and many reincarnations to come. You may meet troublemakers
column13: and demons
column14: enter Paradise or Hell
column15: be reborn
column16: and re-enact the story of a scholar who played the devil in a high-stakes game of backgammon. In addition to very well-drawn authentic backgrounds
column17:
the game includes an excellent database of over 400 screens of text and pictures that gives background information for the time and place where you are in the game.

Calling Coolart a "game" is a bit misleading-- you don't get to solve any elaborate puzzles in traditional point-and-click adventure sense. Any item you carry with you will be used automatically when the time comes
column18: so you can't really get "stuck" in the game. Coolart is better described as an interactive story that lets you interact with the game world at your leisure
column19: similar to choose-your-own-adventure books. And what a world it is. The designers spare no pretense
column20: no illusion that this is a "politically correct" or "family" game. Heiankyo comes alive before your very eyes
column21: with all the gory details and harrowing images that its inhabitants truly faced or believed. You will come across a dog eating a corpse's entrails
column22: long-winded old farts
column23: a monk leading a prayer meeting
column24: kids playing ball in the streets
column25: a maiden with an obscenely phallic tongue
column26: and many more true-to-life characters. And when you get to the underworld (yes
column27: you *must* die in this game. Several times
column28: in fact)
column29: you will find hellish scenes populated with sharp-toothed demons and tormented souls that are so effective as to churn your stomach. These characters are drawn with vivid facial characteristics
column30: a cross between the cartoons of medieval Japanese art and the exaggerations of modern Japanimation. The speaking voices are filled with personality
column31: often taunting
column32: teasing
column33: or sexy. They all speak Japanese (in the ancient tongue
column34: no less)
column35:
but all speech is subtitled in English.

What makes Coolart truly remarkable is that as you enter the town and interact with its inhabitants
column36: you have only two choices. You can
column37: in your arrogance
column38: remain as you are
column39: a contemporary Japanese or American
column40: for example. And you won't get very far. The structure of relations that are the real art of the work won't let you. It does not allow this nonchalance with meaning. A more interesting choice is to try and understand the world as it would have appeared to a person of the time. Then you start to make your decisions
column41: when you meet the guard
column42: or the priest
column44: according to someone else's meaning making map of Kyoto
column45: and indeed of the world. You work within the constraints the artists have placed in the matrix of relations that are the art of this work. The look and feel of it are just window dressing. They are not art
column46: they are design. The art is the in the relations. Follow along the line of those relations
column47:
and you learn what it means to be in the world as the world appears from the point of view of Pure Land Buddhism.

As Roger Ebert concludes in his review
column50: that one could wander this world indefinitely. This is a wonderful game." This truly wonderful
column51: delightfully twisted path to enlightenment is well worth the honor of being one of the few full CD-ROM games on the site (yes
column52: that big zip file contains the whole CD). A must-have
column53: especially for anyone looking for a mature
column54: meditative game that is a far cry from today's superficial releases."☃"1048952496"☃"COOLART.zip"☃"5"☃"172.180.252.225"

column1: Again?☃"John W. Wells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"The Kane Project 4 is
column2: well
column3:
a lot like most of the other games Master Raze has made.

Graphics:

The cutscenes are passable
column4: and sometimes good. However
column5: the gameplay boards are generally rather flat and lifeless. The streets of the city look rather like a typical dungeon
column6: except with walls of big
column7: blue blocks that are meant to represent rooftops
column8:
and the final battle looks particularly lackluster.

Writing:

Well
column9: my expectations were pretty low here
column10: and Master Raze met them. TKP4 is filled with flat situations and sophomoric humor so overstated as to make MY jokes look subtle - which is no mean feat. Its plotline manages to be stale yet maintain a charming incomprehensibility at times. Also
column11:
a proofreader would be welcome here.

But there is one good line about the habits of serial killers in movies...

Gameplay:

Many games have predictable plots
column12: but Master Raze has managed to do the seemingly impossible. He has managed to combine a variety of different types of action
column13:
and yet still keep the entire game on a predictable track.

The reason for this is as follows: anybody who has played Master Raze's other games - and I know there are a few others of you out there - has seen all there is to see here
column14: pretty much. There are one or two ideas he hasn't used before
column15:
but most of the game is very familiar.

I mean
column16:
what other author could possibly make you say:

"Okay
column17: a break-in sequence is coming up
column18: so that means I'll have to access some computers to open doors
column19: sneak behind guards to break their necks
column20: maybe hide from some cameras
column21: and possibly get a password. Afterwards
column22: I'll end up in a forest or jungle or something
column23: pursued by animals that I really shouldn't kill
column24: because I don't want to run out of ammo. There might be some fistfighting action
column25:
which basically amound to touching objects instead of shooting them. The objects might run away when I chase them while simultaneously decreasing my health."

It's not BAD gameplay
column26: for the most part
column27:
but it's getting old fast.

Overall:

Effort definitely went into this on some level; all of those cutscenes and battles didn't come out of thin air. But it all feels suspiciously like a Mr. Potato Head approach to design; begin with a dull
column28: plastic thing and add on the premade parts. This is very popular in Hollywood; I mean
column29: TKP4 is AT LEAST as original as [insert latest buddy action movie here]
column30: but Raze could do a lot better."☃"1049151542"☃"tkp4.zip"☃"3"☃"131.215.90.164"

column1: Not bad☃"YipplyYAya"☃"squirtlerulez@yahoo.com"☃"This game was rather entertaining...though i don't like it. Its graphics were not bad though. for another opinion
column2:
refer to below...
I hate Role Playing Games. For so many reasons over so many years
column3: I have never gotten the same enjoyment from them that others have. I never liked the cute cartoony characters or turn based combat
column4: nor today's FMV smothered fodder crammed with heroes named ''Squall Valiannartessions.'' The only reason I ever gave Nipple Saga a chance was its name; I love the Nipple games so I got it. I never expected to like it
column5: and really never expected to love it. Truth be told
column6: it is one of the greatest games ever released and really deserves all the hype that other RPGs now get. The Game This is one damn fine playing game. The story revolves around a young man named Nippleanus
column7: member of a crew performing freelance missions for der Doktor. The ship is overtaken and Nippleanus's own Doctor (and surrogate father
column8: essentially) is slain before him by der Doktor von Bagstein himself. Before you get knocked unconscious
column9: you witness Bagstein's men steal an artifact resembling a coffin from some ruins... then comes the pistol whippin'. You black out
column10: and arise at the bottom of a cave
column11: feeling hopeless. Your anus comes to your rescue
column12: and so the adventure begins... The game has three basic playing modes: Flying around on your anus
column13: exploring on foot
column14: and combat on the anus. All are well implemented; the majority is on the anus
column15: and controlling it is as natural as could be. The game will send you flying across large bodies of water
column16: through ravines
column17: over tundra; the flying is very similar to the preceding Nipple games
column18: only not as deft (these are exploration sequences). Pressing the A button brings up the targeting icon; anything accessible can be highlighted and interacted with via this system. It comes together perfectly for an RPG
column19: especially considering how much of it is rooted in shooter. The on-foot moments are actually similar to the flying; you roam around
column20: but all interaction takes place with the targeting icon. While sounding awkward simply for running
column21: it is really quite fitting; often there are several items you can look over
column22: and you can choose among them without moving around. The game's combat system is phenomenal. Forget all the boring turn-waiting and cutesy stuff; Nipple Saga came to play. It isn't as fast as the shooter iterations
column23: as this is an RPG
column24: but the pacing of the battles is amazing. You're given a set of meters that fill over time. You can perform certain tasks according to your amount of meters filled; thus the give-or-take strategy planning begins. Do you hit with a bunch of one meter attacks
column25: or wait for some more powerful 2 meter attacks? Time can be of the essence
column26: and some of the more epic battles will have your hands sweating as you try to decide the best course of action. As you play on
column27: the Doctor evolves and changes into new Robo-Doctor types. This means he's more powerful and more resilient towards attacks
column28: just as Nippleanus is when gaining experience. When your Doctor learns Berserk commands
column29: you're given a whole new class of ''spells.'' The intervals at which you're given access to the new features is perfect; you get them right when you're ready for something new. There is also NO need for ''leveling up.'' The game makes sure that if you play the game through
column30: you will be powerful enough without ever having to spend useless time fighting ridiculous amounts of repetitive enemies just to feel adequate. Thematically
column31: Nipple Saga (as well as all of the Nipple games) has no equal. The enemies you fight
column32: the doctor
column33: the quirky people you meet- this is a far away universe that really should be closer. The range of monsters really makes it seem as if the world you're venturing through has different species and classes; not just random ugly creatures
column34: but actual populations living amongst the humanoids. The areas and levels are very appropriate residences for the characters
column35: accurate and fitting without exception. The story goes on to become so much more than it starts with; the importance of the being in the coffin
column36: etc. It all comes together almost without hitch. The sole problem in its execution is that it can be hard to discern a few alliances towards the end of the game; this doesn't kill the story at all
column37: but is rather just a bur in the saddle. Play the game through over a short period of time and the story will reward you like few others in gaming. Side note: While it says on the back of the case that NS offers the ''Uncompromising Conclusion'' to the Nipple lineage
column38: that is FAR from the truth. The ending is not bad
column39: but it is NOT what is advertised... The Delivery Nipple Saga has it's graphical highs and lows. The shimmering water is the best seen on the PC (or the XBox)
column40: and the Doctor is a beautiful model considering the hardware. He bends and maneuvers beautifully; in fact all the animations of the game are excellent. Berserk effects are also dynamite
column41: with plenty of pretty colors and lighting erupting from the attacks. The game even fakes some great reflections in a few areas
column42: a feat never handled with much grace by the ZZT. The lows however
column43: are some pretty gritty looking structures in the walking segments
column44: and some rough character models for the human(oid)s. This is 32 bit 3D stuff here
column45: so it isn't bad at all considering the hardware
column46: it just isn't the best of its league. The overall visual presentation is still superb; the theme is rendered exquisitely and the intentions of the developer are well executed. The music is almost eerily fitting. It's as if the levels themselves designed the music; from the bongo-style rhythms of Dir en Grey to the digital woodwinds of Initial D music
column47: the stuff is the aural representation of the visuals. The track that accompanies regular outdoor battles is a perfect example; no other track could ever capture the moment like that
column48: as it blends the constant motion and primitive-yet-advanced theme the game so brilliantly delivers. The Truth I once thought I would never review this game simply because I don't think I could do it justice. Although I overcame that hurdle
column49: this review is far from doing right by Nipple Saga. It is worth its ridiculous prices on ebay. I hate RPGs and this is still one of the best games I've ever played. Ignore the commercials on TV for so many other games you'll be able to rent to find out they aren't worthy. Nipple Saga is amazing
column50: stellar; how could the ZZT not succeed with JUST this game on it? Find this game and pay the money and yell at other people to do the same. "☃"1049169991"☃"Nipsaga.zip"☃"5"☃"202.156.2.90"

for example) greatly enhance replayability.

APPEASEMENT☃"Terryn"☃"achristi@bradley.edu"☃"I was going to write up something anyway
column2:
but I guess I'll dedicate this review in the name of Funk! =.

NOW GIMME BACK MY "NO SOLICITORS" SIGN. <b>AND THAT BOX FULL OF KITTENS</b>

ESP is a large story-based ZZT game with several snippits of gameplay interspersed; sometimes it's an inventory game
column3: sometimes it's an action game
column4:
and once or twice it's even both.

The game's strongest point is the writing. The descriptions are verbose enough to please while the The humor (in my horrible opinion; rating humor is a purely subjective task) ranged from slightly droll to pretty amusing; nothing was horrible save for what was intended to be horrible (well
column5: except maybe the horse joke).  The plot
column6: while truthfully less relevant than it was when Wells originally started work on ESP
column7: was implemented very well. It involves a tricky man named Cleatle who sneaks into the Protest Party headquarters and suggests confuddling up the ballot system to gain more votes.  Despite his means of entering
column8: he's inducted into the Protest Party and is sent out to get the ballot scanned.  The rest clumps together in an odd mess from there on
column9:
and I'd rather not give out plot points on a strongly written game when the game itself does ton(ne)s better.

Oh
column10: let me point out that I noticed two typos thoughout playing the game.  TWO.  Considering there's enough text to fill at least a novelette and _especially_ considering that this is a homebrewed game
column11: that's about as likely as ...ah hell
column12:
I can't come up with a simile that won't make me sound elitist. :< But you get the picture!

As for the gameplay
column13: the inventory game was well-programmed.  Several (and I mean SEVERAL) specific but pointless inventory reactions were put in. Also
column14:
some of the puzzles were pretty devious. (I ended up using the help file twice; once to get that pocketwatch and the other because I was blind and couldn't see a docked boat.)

The action scenes are widly varying; they range from simple bullet evasion to a run'n'gun type game. About the only flaw is the large head start you can get in the first minigame
column15:
but that's nothing game-destroying.

(For those of you just in for the story
column16:
pretty much all of the action scenes can be skipped over.)

The artwork thoughout is quite sharp. Funk contributed to the first file; Zenith to the second and fourth; Rob_P to the third. The art styles
column17: while abviously varying from artist to artist
column18:
didn't conflict heavily enough to cause problems.

It's nice
column19: really!  I was expecting good things from this game
column20: and I'm glad that I wasn't disappointed.  It's the first ZZT game I bothered to download in quite a while."☃"1049413484"☃"Esp.zip"☃"5"☃"136.176.200.202"

column1:
Totally Whack Yo☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃" ESP is a game that has been anticipated for a long time. Does it hold up to the hype?

Yes. Altough I was disapointed slightly. Because this is a massive game
column2:
(4 files) I'm going to have to resort to dividing up the review into sections.

Story: The premise is very clever
column3: and it's one thing to have a clever premise
column4: it's another to be able to follow through with it to the end. Wells
column5: who is known for his attention to writing
column6: can support his bark with his bite. The game is layered and while some of the things within the game become absurd and seem to have little to do with the main point
column7: it all flows and aids in creating a world where it might be possible that a group of Sorcerers might take over and hypnotise people to win an election. Sometimes however things get to detracted and by the time you get back to the main story
column8: you're confused as to what had been going on. The sections in between are as wordy as the main plot and while it maintains the writing standard that is somewhat expected
column9: though not entirely necessary
column10:
it puts much between the main theme of the game and the side parts.

Gameplay: For a game thick with story ESP still squeezes out a good amount of gameplay. You can skip a lot of it and you can also cheat to great degree as allowed by the programmer. The engines were well done for the most part. The RPG battle was a little stale albiet humourous. (On a separate note the boat ride was similar to one my airplane engines hehe:)) The shooting game play plays a bit weak and some scenes incorperate stars which in my opinion should be avoided at _almost_ all costs. In general though the gameplay
column11: while varied
column12: was not totally entertaining
column13:
skipping it seemed wrong though and I felt left out of the action of the game. The fact that you switched between characters was a good feature though that added depth to both the gameplay and the story.

Music: I think I might be the only one to notice that the title screen music was a poor rendition of "VGA Trek". The music was very good in some parts and annoying in other parts. But there was music throughout which while a feature for most games to-day
column14:
is hardly the standard for ZZT games.

Graphics: Ranged from awesome to radical. There was depth
column15:
perspective. Some of the best graphics I've seen in ZZT and even better than some MZX games. The combination of artisits is noticible but does not detract from te game at all.

Overall: The graphics and the story make up the brunt of the "game". Given the option of being able to skip a lot of the playing parts
column16: it plays more like an interactive movie. This is the problem with ZZT
column17: get too involved in story and it's hard to make the game a game. ESP is one of the best things to come around in a while
column18: but there are still better games out there. I'd give it a five for the sake of effort on the parts of all the programming writing and drawing
column19: but if that's what earns a movie five stars
column20: The Core will sweep the Oscars next time around.    "☃"1049419226"☃"Esp.zip"☃"4.5"☃"68.112.244.46"

Anthropomorphic animal characters.

Cartoonish
column2:
lively graphics.

Occasional ALL CAPS interjections.

Yep
column3: Frost 1 is about as Zenith Nadir-y as you can get. Is this a bad thing? Well
column4: that's a matter of taste
column5: I suppose
column6: but there's no way Nadir's technical skill can be faulted here
column7:
nor his sense of timing. This is a fun game.

Plot:

The plotline is fairly standard RPG stuff; we get an ominous hint in the opening that Something Bigger is happening
column8: and then the game jumps to the main character
column9: a teenager who makes a rather important discovery about herself
column10: like all teenage RPG heroes. No
column11: she isn't heir to the throne or anything like that
column12: nor do her parents suddenly get killed off
column13:
but the device that's used here is still pretty ageworn.

The game continues along a fairly predicatable track
column14: with some pretty common stock scenes and a "find a pet's owner" quest. Nothing immensely original
column15:
but it could be worse; it could be incomprehensible (see most trippy games).

Writing:

But even the most tired plot can be made to shine with solid writing
column16: and
column17: thankfully
column18: Zenith pulls through here. The characters are satisfactory
column19: and the pacing is excellent. Clunky exposition is kept to a minimum - although
column20: as the first game is meant to set up the world
column21:
there is definitely some there - and the dialogue isn't overlong.

I
column22: personally
column23: find the authorial interjections annoying. At times
column24: Zenith clearly puts his own catchphrases and bits of random silliness in the mouths of the characters. Even worse
column25: it occasionally... OCCASIONALLY got a laugh from me
column26: so I couldn't quite ignore it
column27: either. That's a nasty thing to do
column28:
throw inanities around and then surprise me with humor. For shame.

Of course
column29:
I consider the amount of cursing excessive. What else is new?

Gameplay:

The gameplay sections of Frost 1 are solid. There's a swordplay Simon Says sequence and a bunch of forest and swamp screens with monsters to fight. This isn't anything new
column30: but it's done very smoothly and competently. The monsters require a bit of work to beat sometimes - and there's one really great moment of blind panic. It's telegraphed
column31:
but that somehow makes it better.

The game does take a bit of time to get going
column32: but once it does
column33: it does. I prefer to think of the pacing as "excellently done and unhurried
column34: " as opposed to "long setup
column35:
no payoff yet."

Music:

It's MadTom. It's good
column36:
what there is of it.

Graphics:

So
column37: you can have Suikoden Fantasy
column38: where the graphics are the best thing in the game
column39: but are basically just look pretty
column40: or you can have Frost 1
column41: where the graphics are the best thing in the game
column42:
and seem to define its personality and give it a great sense of fun.

Programming:

I didn't run into any bugs
column44:
and the masses of enemies worked well.

Conclusion:

A fun

column2:
but when you finally get to the gameplay you're left with a stale game that just seems to frustrate you.

The side scrolling action is poorly designed with jumping not able to be preformed at the same time as moving without some difficulty. The majority of the levels involve weaving your way through guns that shoot far too frequently and there are many times where it's near impossible not to be shot when bullets are comming at you from above and the side at the same time. The boss battles leave much to be desired. One of the X bots is killed by a defensive gun's bullets and the second one can be shot safely from underneath through the water that's used as a platform. Magman only needs to be shot through the feet with a stream of bullets then taken out from behind. For some odd reason his head throws stars which can't hurt another object. Later you ride a raft down a lava flow which means you dodge rocks(bullets again) for a period of time. After that you fight a volcano which you can saftly attack from the side defeating all of its shooting elements and leaving you to clear the rest of the breakable boss looking for it's "weak spot". Fire man

column1: ZZTAE is AWESOME and EXCELLENT☃"dave2"☃"dragopublish@hotmail.com"☃"The ZZT Advanced Editor
column2: the best thing to make your new and hip ZZT games in.  It's like ZZT
column3: but everything is shinier.  You can make instant background fades
column4: without having to spend hours getting it to look just right.  There are object libraries to keep you from having to re-create those Burger Joint-esque doors all the time.  you never need STK again with ZZTAE
column5: the entire palette is at your disposal by the press of a button.  It even makes newly created boards completely blank; that's right
column6:
no yellow borders.

Having surpassed the buggy Kevedit as the leading ZZT editor
column7: ZZTAE isn't without it's own share of bugs.  You still have a chance of corrupting your ZZT
column8: forcing the nervous
column9:
pessimistic ZZTers to constantly have to make back-ups.

This problem aside
column10: ZZTAE is far better to use than ZZT.  You still need ZZT to test your game though; ZZTAE is a true blue editor
column11: no exceptions.  If you don't think ZZTAE is for you
column12: get it anyway.  It's vast array of features might change your mind."☃"1050640926"☃"zztae.zip"☃"4.5"☃"142.161.0.92"

Great!☃"MadTom"☃"madtom@comic.com"☃"I hadn't ever used KevEdit before 0.5.0 was released; I'd been using ZZTAE
column2:
and when CyQ told me he was discontinuing the project he suggested I try KevEdit instead.

KevEdit is a fantastic ZZT editor that not only saves the average ZZTer considerable time in their projects (like the cut-and-paste feature ... no more transferring pictures one character at a time!)
column3: but also allows one to tweak ZZT in ways that the classic editor and even ZZTAE simply do not allow
column4:
such as adding and removing object stats.

The fade tool is excellent and can be manipulated very freely
column5: combining the selection and buffer functions. The interface is very practical and elegant
column6:
and the help files very thorough.

I've noted a couple of minor bugs in this version
column7: but otherwise KevEdit is a fantastic ZZT editor
column8:
and anyone who hasn't should definitely give it a try!

It's good that there's a Windows version available

Finally, a Euler circuit based puzzle game!☃"Quantum P."☃"cipher110@yahoo.com"☃"I thought this was a pretty neat puzzle game. The player walks through a randomly generated maze
column2:
trying to collect as many gems as possible while avoiding the deadly ammo things. The engine is designed so that the player leaves behind a trail of solid wall; this keeps you from following the same path twice.

Backtrax is just fine as an engine
column3: but it would be much better
column4: like Commodore said
column5: if there was something else added to the challenge. I would have really liked a time limit system; maybe torches could give you more time
column6: and ammo would take away time
column7: instead of health. Another way would be to have an object running through the maze
column8: instead of the player; you could program it so that it would be constantly moving
column9:
giving you little time to make a decision.

Still
column10: Backtrax was pretty good
column11: despite its small size. For the unique idea and great programming

You probably already know this...☃"Ryan Ferneau"☃"rferneau@iastate.edu"☃"I thought this game was really cool when it first came out.  That was when I only played TOWN.ZZT
column2: DEMO.ZZT
column3: and TOUR.ZZT
column4: and I couldn't even edit Town or Tour.  I totally wanted to get Caves
column5: Dungeons
column6: and City
column7: but I could never convince my parents to pay for them
column8: y'know?  I also thought it would be cool if I could send in a game board for Best of ZZT
column9:
but that never happened.

Anyway
column10: I found that the coolest part of ZZT was that the level editor could create games just like the ones that came with ZZT.  I was used to games like Think Quick that put limitations on how much you could make your games like the pre-packaged ones
column11: so as I explored ZZT
column12:
it turned out to be a real treat to duplicate all of the tricks in Town and more. Probably the pinnacle of ZZT's flexibility is its "object-oriented" language for programming your own game characters. There are dozens upon dozens of ways for these objects to interact with the player and spice up the game.

When the Internet got to be a really big thing
column13: making ZZT games also grew in popularity.  Now you can share your work with friends all over the world and try to get some recognition.  There are plenty of places to look for free games to download.  Although Tim Sweeney may have missed a few ways to improve ZZT
column14: its sheer replayability earns it a 5."☃"1054881091"☃"zzt.zip"☃"5"☃"167.142.21.190"

column1: I am confuzeled.☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"I didn't get much of the story
column2:
the opening cutscenes were very vauge with short dialouge that seemed to have nothing to do with anything. There was no description to tell you where you were and the graphics were too poor to show you. I'm still not sure where or what time period the game is set in. (Modern time probably but what else? We need info!)

The fighting was poor with monsters that many times take more bullets to kill than the ammo they give you. They move and shoot randomly. The bosses /seek you at cycle 3 allowing you to defeat them easily simply by firing a steady stream of bullets straight at them. The music was pretty good in many places and helped smooth out the (many) rougher areas of this game.

Some fun is to be had
column3: but not too much. I never bothered to open the third file

column1:
I should have reviewed this a long time ago.☃"JohnWWells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"CraNKGod is either the reincarnated spirit of Henry Dudeney or some kind of puzzle savant. How else can you explain Little Square Things?

This puzzle game is at least as cleverly designed as most of the commercially released ones I've played
column2: and better than most of them. The levels are varied and continually surprising
column3:
ranging from frantic action sequences to subtle planning exercises.

But Crank isn't satisfied with offering just a few levels of quality gameplay. Using a branching-path system that allows the player to give the game who-knows-how-many different playthroughs
column4: Crank makes absolutely certain that there's always something new to see here. And
column5: of course
column6:
there are the bonus boss levels...

And it's bug-free
column7:
as far as I can tell. No bugs. Did I mention that I didn't run into any bugs?

NO BUGS.

If you've ever tried to program a game of this scope
column8:
you know how _miraculous_ that is. Solid proof of the time Crank put into making this the best game it could possibly be.

So
column9: are there any flaws here? Well
column10: a few levels have rather unrealistic expectations of the player's reflexes
column11: but
column12: thanks to the branching level system
column13: those can be avoided. And the boss races are insanely
column14: horribly difficult
column15: but then
column16: you'd expect them to be
column17: wouldn't you? The plotline
column18: well
column19: is sketchy
column20: but there's more than enough there for a puzzle game
column21: definitely. Nope. No real problems here. Maybe one or two poorly conceived levels

column1:
What?☃"JohnWWells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"Summary:

What can I say? I know that hyping a game isn't really a good idea
column2: but this game could have used it. Massive and filled with nifty theme boards and fun puzzles
column3:
Pipeline 99 is one of the neater puzzle games I've played for ZZT.

The premise is simple
column4: and actually sort of overused; you have to arrange objects on a screen so that a ball hits a target. The devil is in the details here; a simple set of tools has to be used
column5: so that the gameplay can be picked up
column6:
but the thing can't get too repetitive.

Story:

Well
column7: there is a storyline here. It's a silly one
column8: and is appropriately simple
column9: but it adds a bit to the game. Furthermore
column10: there was one really good joke
column11: which is one more than I expected. This isn't Grim Fandango; this is The Incredible Machine
column12:
and any story is a bonus.

Music:

What? No brilliant musical score in a WiL game? I don't think anybody cares
column13:
actually.

Gameplay:

The player puts down special pieces on the board that redirect a little ball. Simple enough in theory
column14: but it gets tricky when gravity gets reversed
column15:
or the ball sticks to the walls... or the thing just keeps falling into pits.

It's fun
column16: really
column17: and that's all I can say. It gets a bit repetitive when the game drags out to the sixtieth level or so
column18:
but an effort is made to keep things fresh and ramp up the difficulty.

Graphics:

Workmanlike; anything complicated would get in the way of the engine
column19:
actually.

Overall:

This one's worth a download. It was ignored in its time
column20: so a lot of you have some catching up to do. I don't expect many people will play all of the levels (a branching system
column21: like that of Little Square Things
column22: would have worked better)
column23: but it's good to know they're there."☃"1064047296"☃"pipe-99.zip"☃"4.5"☃"131.215.158.186"

column2: I'd intended to review this <i>before</i> I saw his LJ post begging for it. Warning
column3:
spoilers galore.)

Zenith's first full ZZT game in three years is a full-blown triumph
column4: a graphical masterpiece with original characters
column5: an intriguing storyline
column6: a cohesive
column7: well-developed and depicted setting ... and the gameplay isn't half bad
column8:
either.

<i>Frost 1: Power</i> is a cinema game based on characters that Zenith has apparently been brooding on for a long time
column9: perhaps years. Some of you might recognise
column10: for example
column11: the character Henna in prototype form from his art compilation <i>UltraWack</i>
column12: which was released way
column13: way back when your grandfather was learning about STK
column14: and
column15: much more recently
column16:
from the infamous KrackeNadir art journal.

The graphics are the game's main strength
column17: which is not really surprising for a self-confessed cinema game
column18: and
column19: at the risk of sounding like I'm exaggerating (I'm not)
column20: I've never actually seen anything quite like it
column21: particularly the art boards. Light and shadow are used very effectively
column22: and the attention to detail is pretty astonishing. Zenith's trademark skylines
column23: such as the purple-grey sky of the first 'teaser' board of the game involving a character named Set
column24: are used to full effect
column25: including consistency with descriptions of weather ... he said it was overcast
column26:
and he meant it!

The gameplay
column27: when you finally reach it after the marathon introduction
column28: is simple; Penny Shaïwell
column29: upon being exiled from her homeland of Gian
column30: is on her way to Alsace
column31: walking through forest and swampland
column32: and using the sword given to her by her mother to KILL things in the process. She faces such feared opponents as polliwogs and bloodflies
column33: and
column34: of course
column35: the everpresent zombie muttering such intimidating threats as "rrrr brains"
column36: and the task of finding the mysterious swamp witch Henna
column37: whose unfortunately wounded pet is blocking the bridge to Alsace. All very simple
column38: but rather nice. In fact
column39: the only thing that <i>really</i> turned me off about the gameplay was the duplicator reproducing the enemies
column40:
though that's admittedly long been a pet peeve of mine.

In spite of the potentially morose atmosphere of latter parts of the game
column41: Zenith keeps a reasonably light perspective with occasional interjections such as "stumpy is speshul :("
column42: swearwords
column43: and "say goodbye to gian 4eva". Which is just as well
column44: otherwise the game might have collapsed under its own (considerable) weight. The dialogue generally flows freely and realistically; there's no pretentious
column47: comprised of a mere two pieces
column49: so I'd best ignore that ... and yes
column51: I saw my goddamned <:) smiley on the squid board. I CONSIDERED PINGING YOU A POINT JUST FOR THAT I'LL HAVE YOU KNOW
column55: unparalleled ZZT artwork set to a well-thought-out storyline
column56: with a level of gameplay acceptable to a cinema game
column58: and pretty damn good writing. Even if it was made by a guy who
column60:
looks like John Denver.

Download it and play it now

Hogan's (a) Hero!☃"dapper gent"☃"yotsua@aol.com"☃"Micr0wave has made a triumphant return with his first ZZT game in seven years: Hoganeater. The all-star cast (featuring Boothe Howard
column2: Smiley Burnette
column3: Mr. T
column4: and last but most definitley not least
column5:
Bob Crane as Robert "Hulk" Hogan) pull off an amazing performance that will send you reeling.

You take on the role of Hogan. The digital comic opens in a ring of lies: The UN. A heated arguement has started between Hogan and Mr. T
column6: over T's unorthodox practice of using UN planes to fly in autographed baseballs. Just when Hogan was beginning to win
column7: T lobs a baseball
column8: signed by baseball legend Rolly Fingers
column9:
into the ribcage of Hogan.

Robert was infuriated; what's a nigger doing in the UN
column10: anyway? Hogan drives to Hot Pepper Hill
column11: to confront his boss (Smiley Burnette). It was all a setup: Hogan is tied down and shaved
column12: execution style. Left for dead in a laundry bag on the side of the highway
column13: Hogan is found by Boothe Howard
column14: who gives him hair implants
column15: and the ability to vomit bubbles at his foes. Hogan bursts out of the doctor's office
column16: and makes his way back to Hot Pepper Hill
column17: to face his old Boss
column18: with a mouthful of bubbles. Will Hogan succeed? With your ingenuity
column19:
maybe!

The graphics are astounding. There's a beautifully detailed picture of Bob Crane wearing a towel on the title screen. The locations look great
column20: too
column21:
as they were all filmed and photographed ON LOCATION! Micr0wave cut no corners here.

The sound is a mixed bag. The dialogue is absolutely fantastic: audible
column22: clear
column23: and very well acted. The musical score
column24: performed by grammy-winning orchestra "The Pee Wee Johnnies"
column25: leaves a bit to be desired from. Don't get me wrong
column26: it's good
column27: but not as good as what we've come to expect of them. The title screen theme song
column28: however
column29:
really shines.

Gameplay is your standard digital comic faire
column30: but it's not without its excitement! Between all that 'look'ing and 'think'ing
column31: there's many a shoot (Barf?) out with the bad guys! Some are quite challenging
column32:
but nothing your typical shoot-`em-up player can't handle!

Great graphics? An all-star cast? Exciting action sequences? A cameo/tap-dancing scene by Jeremy "Be Anal" Beanal? Hoganeater has it all.

Good job
column33: Micr0wave. Keep churning out the hits

It's pulled from the Death Gate game

The game is broken up into segments

and probably quite a few friendships. I don't know; I've never tried that.

Wow. Why didn't I get around to playing this earlier?

Answer: It lacks either compelling gameplay or a well-told story. The writing is weak. The thing just doesn't stick together as a whole.

I wasn't missing much.

The first bad sign was the text at the bottom of the screen. It wouldn't have been a mortal sin
column20: I think
column21: if it had been well-written. Sadly
column22: it was an ungrammatical mush of the game's fantasy jargon and Big Pronouncements. There were some attempts to give unique characters to the people in the game
column23:
but only the author cameos actually had real voices. I don't know; I guess that's what happens when you write yourself.

Oh
column24: yes
column25: the second bad sign was the author cameos. See
column26: in order to put the pieces of the world back together
column27: the player has to go to different realms and bring back the game authors. So
column28: first the game sets up an elaborate fantasy premise
column29: which it repeats at great length whenever possible
column30: and then it tears down any suspension of disbelief. I don't know; is this meant to be cute
column31: or clever
column32:
or just wink-wink-nudge-nudge in-joking?

In order to review Death Gate
column33: I'm going to have to look at each of its sections separately
column34: though
column35: as each has its own personality. Even if Death Gate's dialogue often strikes the same few notes of exposition over and over
column36:
it doesn't repeat itself here. The segments are quite clearly distinct.

Hercules' segment:

This one begins with Lord Xar
column37: your character's exposition dispenser
column38: doing what he does best: dispensing exposition. He drones for a bit
column39: and Hercules
column40: who just a few seconds before was asking himself questions about the possibility of life in the other realms
column41: listens politely to the spiel. Of course
column42: this seemed repetitive to me
column43:
but I don't know.

This is probably the most interesting thing in this segment. The rest of it consists of the player walking around HercLand
column44: talking to a few token NPCs
column46:
and answering a pop quiz. On ZZT.

Now
column47: I don't know why people include ZZT quizzes in ZZT games. First of all
column48: it breaks the fourth wall so thoroughly that you just can't repair it again. Secondly
column49: it's not fun. If you know the answers
column51: and it's a piece of cake. If you don't
column52: there's no real way to deduce them. You just keep trying again and again until you're through with the damned thing. And
column54:
they become harder with time.

On the bright side
column55:
this one doesn't kill you if you make a mistake. You just have to start over. This alone suggests the existence of a merciful God. I don't know; it seems a lot better than the Prime Mover argument.

Summary of HercLand: Not fun. Not interesting. No compelling characters. No real reason to keep going. Dull. I don't know; there might be something I'm missing.

Jacob Hammond's segment:

This one's short and bizarre. The player does a nonsensical fetch-and-carry
column60: that's it. It feels sort of... dashed off. On the bright side
column61:
this one doesn't take itself too seriously.

Summary of Jacob Hammond's bit: Silly. Quickly over with.

Zenith Nadir's segment:

What's this? Actual gameplay? A throwaway joke opening? Two diverging paths through an action segment? Okay
column68: and ends with a standard action battle. Nothing original
column70: but what they hey. There's an effort here
column71: and it doesn't exactly take itself seriously. Indiana Jones makes a brief cameo. I don't know; does that count as a joke
column73:
am I the only one who thinks that those two paths through the temple are actually kind of similar? No? Darn.

Summary of Zenith's segment: We've got (pedestrian
column74:
but well-executed) gameplay!

WiL's segment:

This was the most ambitious segment; it relies on the use of a timer and a sort of real-time adventure gameplay. In this case
column75:
"adventure" means "running around frantically trying to talk to the right people at random before time runs out."

It could have worked
column77: way too easy to put into an unwinnable state. Now
column79: WiL clearly means to do this
column81:
but that doesn't make it good design. More open-endedness would have been a good thing. I don't know... maybe it would have just made things messier.

There's another multiple-choice segment here. If you make a wrong choice at any point
column83:
then you are left in Can't-Win Limbo. You'll also end up in Limbo if you aren't in the right place at the right time. You won't even know it immediately. You'll just flounder like a hopeless king who forgot to pick up the dead fish.

Now
column84: all of this would be sort of forgivable if the gameplay made any sense
column85: but you're in a dreamworld of sorts
column86:
and that's WiL's favorite excuse for discontinuity. You just have to hope you're on the right boards when the timed events happen; logic won't get you far. I don't know; maybe I'm missing something.

This is all a shame. This segment tries to raise Serious Ideas
column87: and almost succeeds at some point; one of the key questions is whether or not we should cling to the comfort of old dreams. But the writing can't escape its pretension
column88:
and the attempt at connecting emotionally with the player was too much like a multiple-choice exam to really work. Sorry.

Summary of WiL's segment: It tries.

Overall:

I don't know. Am I missing anything? Oh

column1: ☃"Tazz"☃"mrhahn15@hotmail.com"☃"You might be wondering
column2: "What the hell is this?" Well this is Mind Vomit
column3: not to be confused by Edible Vomit made by Draco. This game was made by Zandor. When you first load the game into a computer
column4: you will see the title screen which says........TITLE SCREEN! Of course this makes you think "HEY! THIS GAME IS AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAWWWWWWWWWWWWWWEEEEEEEEEEEEEEESOME!" and in the big bold white letters that says title screen
column5: there are hidden sublimital messages saying
column6: "Press P if you want to have a good time." Which you will. The game is split into 3 part. One is a cinematic showing how a text box took control of a bunch of colored letters. Two is a trippy game where you run around touching door looking objects hoping for something to happen. While your there
column7: you can stop by at the houses and talk to some people and worship a cactus. The 3rd part is the best part. The art section. Zandor has done a hell of a good job drawing the art work for this segment of the game. Yes this sounds like a good game with only one major flaw. While watching the cinematic about the text box
column8: it gets glitchy at the end
column9: which sortof hurt the game a little. But who cares! Its trippy! A game like this deserves a 5 out of 5. Nice job Zandor! "☃"1065892448"☃"MindVomit.zip"☃"5"☃"64.80.246.157"

column1:
Why the telescope?☃"TTTPPP"☃"tttppp123@hotmail.com"☃"This game aims for horror and does surprisingly well.
When I first read the html 'readme' file (what happened to the txt file?) I thought a ZZT horror game wouldn't work
column2: but by a brilliant combination of prosaic text and dark rooms (dark in colour
column3: not the sort where you need torches) the author pulls off a scary feel to it.  Admittedly it's not the sort of thing you can manage with a film
column4:
but I was impressed.

Other than that the game was quite simple - run around and touch a load of objects. There were places where I had to consult the walkthrough as I was required to do something I'd already done again. (Even something like reading a book - maybe it didn't sink in the first time). I couldn't manage to pick up the objects I expected to be able to
column5:
but other than that the game seemed quite bug free.

The game was really short
column6: and could have done with more puzzles
column7:
like places where you had to get an object to get into somewhere to get another object to...
The story though was well presented
column8: and based on a great idea.  Without giving anything away
column9: there was one line at the end which was along the lines of "It worked then" which raised a couple of completely unanswered questions for me
column10:
and there's a girl who doesn't seem to play any part in the game.

Overall though it was well worth the download
column11: and made entertaining playing."☃"1066081136"☃"blind.zip"☃"4"☃"131.111.8.96"

column1: Sonic The Hedgehog 4: ZZT☃"(Com)Buster"☃"marcel_willem@hotmail.com"☃"You play as the famous Sonic the Hedgehog. In the beginning of the game he is walking around until he got hit by a robot. Seeing the creature
column2:
he knows that dr. Eggman (For me better known by his second name Robotnik) wants again to transform all creatures into robots.

After playing the first level Sonic finds Dr Eggman which like any other evil person tells him about his plan
column3:
before escaping. He also tells that he has captured his friends Tails and Knuckles as part of his plan.

In the next two levels
column4:
Sonic frees his two friends and decides it is time to go after Dr. Eggman

At the end of the fourth level Sonic witnesses Dr. Eggman taking a chaos emerald
column5:
which gives him extra power.

In the fifth and sixth level Sonic chases the scientist until he gets to his space station
column6: where they will fight again. Sonic ruins the plans of dr Eggman
column7:
but the scentist will escape only to make up new plans.

In the course of the game Sonic can find the chaos emeralds in the bonus levels. If sonic has collected all seven
column8:
he will transform into super sonic and the game continues so that sonic can finish off Dr. Eggman.

The game is easy to play
column9:
but it is not too difficult to do. The game is separated by scenes which unravel the plot
The graphics are of good quality.
The plot is logical and almost flawless
column10:
and could be very well the basis of Sonic the Hedgehog 4
The programming is unfortunately not perfect. There are some bugs
column11: (most of them in the last few levels)
column12:
and there is one passage in the wrong color so that the player will get stuck when going through.
After playing this game
column13:
I started up the genesis and played Sonic 3 (Sonic & Knuckles) for the comparison. Difference no.1 I MISS MUSIC. The only play commands I've found is at the menu
(when you change selection). Though this is not much of a problem if you have problems with your pc speaker ;)

Statistics

gameplay: good: 1pt
graphics: good: 1pt
plot: YAY: 1pt
programming: bugs: .5 pt
sounds 'n music: ZZT sounds only: 0pt

column14: locks everybody inside

too?).

column21: a bird in a tree

Mystery Science ZZTheater 3000☃"Dr. Forrester"☃"dr_forrester2001@yahoo.com"☃"Interactive MiSTings? What a great concept! This game proves that ZZT is an ideal concept for creating a MiSTing. As this is an treated as an episode of the show
column2:
I will write my review in Amazing Collasal Episode Guide format.

The Game:
"Godzilla vs. Planet X5" is a boss battle game that throws you against a half dozen of the Godzilla movies most famous villians. Obviously
column3: you play as none other than
column4: who else
column5:
Gamera


No
column6: just kidding
column7:
it's Godzilla :)

the plot seems to involve our main characters
column8: "PVT" and "SGT" throwing Godzilla from boss to boss via the "Godzilla Transport Devive" in some effort to stop an invasion by aliens. Or something.  The author
column9: Jpasc123
column10: doesn't seem to do a very good job fleshing out the story.  After the battles are through
column11: we are treated to several ZZT versions of the author's favorite scenes from the Godzilla series.  Only about a quarter of the games screens are interactive
column12: the rest being simple cutscenes that have to relation to the game you just played (other than featuring Godzilla).  It's a bit like playing one map from Gettysburg
column13: then getting to watch one hour from Gone With The Wind.  Horrible spelling
column14: typos
column15: and grammer abound
column16: making the text seem almost Dr. Thinker like in quality.  The boards are decently designed
column17:
and better writing and more interactivity would have definately helped this game.

Segment One:
Thanks to a black hole
column18:
Mike & the 'bots find themselves transformed into ZZT characters. Crow notes that he is now an accented lowercase E. Pearl takes advantage of the situation by sending Mike "Godzilla vs. Planet X5" on the ships main navagational computer.

[henceforth
column19:
all segments take place in the theater]

Segment Two:
Gypsy informs everyone that the ship is on a collision course. Since the game is running on the main computer
column20: gypsy can't turn the ship or stop.  Mike suggests using the "#walk idle" command
column21:
which the 'bots scoff at.

Segment Three:
Mike's idea works better than expected.
"When in Rome..." notes Gypsy.

Segment Four:
Outside the theater
column22: Mike can't stop smiling (probably because he is a smiley face).  This angers Pearl
column23:
who promises to send something worse next time.

The unknown author of this MiSTing did a very good job converted the original game to the MST3K format
column24: and several riffs will have you laughging out loud.  The addition of "touch" jokes
column25: for when the player tries to interact with Mike & the 'bots works especially well.  Overall
column26: I have to say that this game does an excellent job
column27: but doesn't seem to nail it quite as well as either Aceland or Despair (which I'll try to review as well.)  So
column28: only four star since those two eventually surpased this hilarious game
column29: but starting the ZZT MiSTing idea earns it another half star."☃"1067270761"☃"mst3000.zip"☃"4.5"☃"198.85.71.19"

column1: An original puzzler!☃"Amoden"☃"blitzchops@turkishprison.com"☃"It isn't every day that you find an original puzzle game. Oh

column4: or a Columns sequel here. When I read the name "Little Square Things"
column5:
I though this would be one of the above. What a shock I was in for!

No
column6: Little Square Things is a crazy game where you control little square things. Like in boulder-xod
column7: (if I recall) you guide boulder-like objects onto fakes. Unlike boulder-xod
column8: there are many types of boulders
column9:
some which aggravate me to no end. Which is the real killer of puzzle games: difficulty.

But
column10: the author side-stepped difficulty and cussed at it. How so? The game operates on a pyramid. After completing a stage
column11: you can take two paths (which boosts replay tremendously)
column12:
leading to a rather lengthy game.

5 stars."☃"1067211381"☃"lst.zip"☃"5"☃"66.42.39.219"

column1: Aceland: The MiSTing☃"Dr Forrester"☃"drforrester2001@yahoo.com"☃"The second (as far as I know) ZZT MiSTing released takes us back to the Joel Robinson era of the show
column2: a good move in my opinion. Anyway
column3:
on to the Amazing Collasal Episode Guide format...

The Game:
Prakash's "Aceland" is a fairly mediocre attempt at a ZZT game. It has a very basic "save the kingdom from the evil tyrant" plot
column4: strung together with many boards suffering from "i-gotta-fill-in-the-board" syndrome. Basically
column5: you must collect 5 keys
column6: (note: actually objects
column7: not really keys) four white and a yellow
column8: to get to the tower of the evil mugerlock. The game actually holds together rather well
column9: until the point in the game where your character gets the microwave weapon
column10: essentially allowing you to kill every NPC in the game with only a touch or two. A gem generator in the bank makes money/health essentially unlimited
column11: even if getting to it is supposed to be a secret. Also
column12: the original version had a bug that prevented you from finishing the game
column13: fixed for the purposes of this misting. And further still
column14: the game has an annoying habit of holding your hand at times
column15: removing almost all difficulty. Overall
column16: Aceland is a dull
column17: unoriginal ZZT game that the author must of thought was terribly witty. Unfortunately
column18:
it's mearly terrible.

Segment One:
Joel & the 'bots discuss ZZT
column19: and possibly making their own game. Crow suggests one set on the Satellite Of Love
column20:
and Joel tells him it's been done.

Invention Exchange:
Joel - Device for clearing a room full of monsters
Mads - Device which turns classic literature into bad ZZT games

Dr. F decides to try his invention on Shakespeare's Macbeth
column21:
and tells Joel it should be ready by the time the experiment is over.

Segement Two & Three:
none

Segment Four:
Joel does the classic "tell me one good thing about Aceland
column22: and i'll give you a RAM chip" bit. Dr. F sends Joel the Macbeth game
column23: and Joel deletes Tom's knowledge of Shakespeare for the time being. You then get to play through a rather silly dark board where you must murder the king. TV's Frank then recites a little from "A Midsummer Night's Dream"
column24:
which the 'bots gleefully riff.

Stinger:
howa bouta soma ammonitino

Although the second ZZT MiSTing leaves out Joel & the 'bots in the corner of the screen like in "Godzilla"
column25: it is still my second favorite in the series. John W. Wells is our writer this time around
column26: and he captures the characters prefectly. The riffers poke fun at the game's poor level design
column27:
ridiculous economic system (what with the infinte gems in the bank) and all points in between. The addition of the MST3K theme song overlayed on Aceland's original title screen is very nice.
Very
column28: very funny. allthough "Despair" is still the better MiSTing if you ask me
column29: it's only by a small margin. I'd give this game 4.75 stars if i could
column30: but since a can't

column1: YAY SIRS!☃"ZZDevelish"☃"zzdevelin@yahoo.com"☃"After a small preview on his LJ. Zenith Nadir releases my favorite game ever! Frost 1 Power is a graphical Masterpiece and Zenith's best game ever. The graphics are incredible the swamp graphics start eerily spooky and then with the nice blending totally give a wet swamp feeling. Zenith's trademark skylines peek in. And in the two boards (attack/reload & Death cab for rosie)The skyline is extremely "G00B". Frost has good details everywhere for example the fakes in the linking board to the swamp right before the swamp board the rocks and plants everywhere. Of course ever since Blue moons moon scenes and Dragon Woods Zenith's graphics were known. The music is well done by Master Composer MadTom. The sword engine was good and the enemies slight AI was good enough. The story while not being completely original was good enough and as MadTom said the slight interjections (HOORAY!
column2:
SHIFT YO ASS) prevented the story from being to serious but didnt make it Chickenwired.

Programming 5/10 Uh.. yeah

Graphics 11/10 Beyond anything i've seen in ZZT so far.

M00SICK 10/10 Hi MadTom!

Plot 8/10 Good

Overall: 10/10 The programming could have more tricks like some in Chickenwire v1.8 (The smiley's diagonal blinkwall trick)and the plot could have more twists but overall a must play

I EAGERLY AWAIT FROST 2 (& 3?)!

-ZZDevelin"☃"1067704321"☃"frost1.zip"☃"5"☃"216.84.80.197"

column1: Har har har.☃"Terryn"☃"terryn@jingoro.net"☃"So
column2: out of curiosity
column3:
I loaded up this game to see how Nadir changed it (you can find it on the NES Quattro Adventure cart) and I was quite pleased!

Firstly
column4: the difficulty was FAR reduced.  Most of it I'm assuming was because of the limitations of ZZT itself; there's simply no way to keep the original three item shuffle inventory system in ZZT
column5:
and there's no way to restrict ZZT from allowing a savegame.

The pain of trying to pogo or crowbar underwater
column6: as you'd have had to arranged your items offshore to where the snorkel was last or DEAD
column7:
is gone! MAJOR POINTS

Secondly
column8: the game is actually prettier in this form.  zn knows how to make good ZZT graphics
column9:
pure and simple.

Thirdly
column10:
the text is ...far less minimalistic. VERY FEW things ever gave out any text (which made the obvious totem-pole puzzle far more difficult).

Lastly
column11:
CAMEOS

The mechanics of the game remained pretty much the same. There was one or two almost negligible omissions (like having to have a plunger as well as dynamite to set off the blast). The switch to overhead is just as good
column12: if not better
column13:
than the original.

The game itself? Inventory
column14:
and fairly short but good. Some scavenging thrown in as well.

What I missed: I'd have liked to have allowed Dizzy to kick at least one bug-eyed giant fly
