I have to think of another clever review title?☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"This game starts with a rather pretty title screen and a few well drawn introduction boards. However once you actually start playing the game
column2:
the graphics disappear.

Blood Oath carries a decent storyline where you play the apprentice of a necromancer who disappeared long ago in search of immortality. You can apparently attain immortality by drinking the blood of the BIG BAD wyrm. Before he left you both made a "blood oath" that if he never came back
column3: you would go and try an kill the wyrm yourself. So off you go
column4:
into the cave.

The cave is a fairly large place. It's drawn simply
column5: grey walls with a grey top to give it a little more of a 3-D feel. All in all though it is sparse on detail. Sure there are a lot of dead bodies
column6:
but most of them at just #Bind'ed to another object and give you a message like: "A skeleton with a crushed head."

There is little in the way of puzzles
column7: but there are a few simple adventure style puzzles. The real meat of the game comes with the RPG battles. The battles are decent but nothing spectacular. They are randomised enough to give it less of a programmed feel
column8: but in general
column9: if you lose a battle
column10: it's usually because you missed the health potion back a few screens. In this programmers opinion
column11: without a level system or some sort of way to improve your characters
column12:
RPG battles are fairly pointless. Not being able to get past something because you are too weak is a key part of RPGs.

The author attempts some dark dramatic writting that sometimes works
column13:
and sometimes feels like a bad movie script. The only redeemable quality of the writing is the actuall story itself.

The graphics are on the weak side
column14: excluding the nicely done opening cutscenes
column15: and the gameplay is on the minimal side. Despite all of that it's still an enjoyable game with a decent story that won't take you too long to play. And even if you don't finish it
column16: you won't quit the game pissed."☃"1070959227"☃"BLDOATH.zip"☃"3.5"☃"24.151.143.76"

column1:
this brings me back...☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"Probably the first ZZT game I downloaded off of the web directly from cly5m's own site.

Turmoil is a fun game that takes place in space on a large spaceship. An intelligent computer gives you various missions to accomplish on different worlds.

The worlds are varied and fun to play. Each has a different feel to them and not all your tasks end up the same. cly5m has some good characters that accompany you on missions or give you advice. The characters add a good sense of cohesion to the game for it lacks a clear-cut story most of the way through.

A entertaining space oriented game that should not be over looked. You can clearly see the style developing that would soon come to make Kudzu the great game that it is. Simply a classic in its own right. "☃"1071290736"☃"turmoil.zip"☃"4.5"☃"24.151.143.76"

column1: The Rose☃"Homz"☃"sherlock_homz@hotmail.com"☃"The Rose is a strangely moving piece of art
column2:
put together with the style and flair that is typical of such a ZZT master as WiL.

This cinema concerns WiL and his ex-friend Patrick
column3: and the growing animosity between them when Patrick decides that he would rather spend time making out with his girlfriend than playing Super Smash Bros. with WiL and two other friends. After a prelude that outlines this tragic turn of events
column4: you
column5: Ian
column6: are introduced. You are actually the famed superhero Kid Action. After a fun night of doing your job
column7: you go to school the next morning
column8: when WiL asks to speak with you for a moment before the bell rings
column9:
thereby enmeshing you in this bitter feud.

The graphics are superb
column10: evoking just the right feelings to suit the occasion
column11: be it the dim alley
column12: Joey's sparse house
column13: or the sky lit with fire. The music sets the mood perfectly with its beauty
column14: and brooding sense of sorrow
column15: and there is just enough music to fully round out and complement the game. The programming is always good
column16: and at two places impressive
column17: those being the battle engine
column18: and leaving the house. The gameplay is what you would expect from interactive cinema
column19: for the most part
column20: except
column21: perhaps
column22: a little less interactiveness than some might desire
column23: but
column24: for the story
column25: it suits perfectly. The story
column26: of course
column27: is what moves the game along
column28: and is fittingly marvellous. It is just serious enough
column29: yet still has those little touches of WiL absurdity
column30: humour
column31: and strangeness
column32: yet these seem perfectly suited
column33: somehow
column34: fitting right in with every thing else
column35: and a beautiful
column36:
if slightly inconclusive ending that is very moving.

Overall
column37: this is an almost flawless cinema
column38: which every ZZTer should experience and treasure. Yes
column39: it has its strange parts
column40: but they seem to fit in with the usual seriousness of the story. As far as I understand
column41: the story was based on a dream that WiL had
column42: so this is fairly standard dreamish material
column43: though perfectly suited to ZZT. It is indeed a necessary download
column44: and one of the best of its genre."☃"1071785575"☃"therose.zip"☃"4.5"☃"66.38.200.194"

column1: Duky Inc makes me moist.☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"There is so much going for this game. Battle Tech is authored by Alex Drelick
column2:
but the style is so remarkably like his brother's that one has to wonder who was the genius. Perhaps they both were.

Battle Tech is a Duky Inc game from 1997. It's 4 files long
column3:
and take quite a while to play. One of the few games on the archive I hasten to call "epic". Much like its predecessor: Overflow.

The storytelling is nothing spectacular
column4: but it has its moments. The real hook this game has is it's graphics and gameplay. The author has a distinct architectural mindset
column5: and uses combines a strict use of symmetry with random spatterings of simple shapes and patterns to please the eye. Everything is in vivid colour and each board gives the eye something new to look at. There is a vast world to explore with lush forests
column6: artic wastelands
column7: mechanical nightmares
column8: and everything in between. Hordes of monsters stand in your path and bosses fight you fiercely
column9: many with their overwhelming visage looming overhead. The first two files are simple distractions from the plot
column10:
simply to test your mettle. The last two files alone could easily have been two seperate games.

What's that you say? Don't fancy fighting prefab enemies? If you are not like me and don't really care for the classic ZZT enemies
column11: you'll still be pulled onward to discover what lies beyond that next passage. What spectacle will you behold next? The destruction of a moon prehaps? The alien mastermind? The adventure never stops
column12:
and the action never lets up.

Only a few flaws seperate this game from being perfect. But in the end it still stands as a feast for your itchy trigger finger
column13: and candy for your eyes. A fantastic game that has not yeilded in power to the newer
column14:
more complex games.

Play it now."☃"1071828759"☃"battle.zip"☃"4.5"☃"24.151.143.76"

column2:
no reviews. I thought WiL was more popular than that. .

Voyage Of Four is said to be an interactive movie (It is) but it is a lot more. There is a lot more interaction than what is made out to be. Many RPG battles and puzzles make this more of an adventure genre.

PLOT: The setting is a mid-evil type land where populations live in small vilages. The culture therefore is primative in nature. Location is purely fiction.

Well the plot was pretty simple at the beginning
column3:
but I was thoroughly confused towards the end. It begins with the story of a man who's village is destroyed and all the residents killed (Including his family). From his wife's last breath he learns that the army which wiped out his village is led by a mysterious "Man in Red." The man then devotes his life for revenge.

Further in the story this man runs into three other "heros
column4:
" which is where "The Voyage of Four" comes from.

The end of the story became very confusing. It rambled on about a dark realm opposite of the regular world abd bringing balance between light and dark. It gave me horrifying memories of the Chronos Wars story line. Despite this written confusion
column5: the ending DID make sense (At least the one I took. There are four
column6:
I believe).

Overall the plot was quite good
column7:
despite a few weak spots in writing and a bit of confusion.

GRAPHICS: You guys all know WiL
column8:
and you know what kind of job he does. The graphics for this game were marvelous and fit the story perfectly.

MUSIC: Recently
column9: ZZTers haven't been focusing much on the topic of music. They don't realize
column10: however
column11: how much it can add to the game. A good theme on a title screen can start the game off well
column12: or perhaps a nice song during beginning narrations. WiL uses music to his advantage
column13: giving the game a great feel. Not only is the music excellent
column14:
but it is exactly the right amount. He does not over-do it at all.

PROGRAMMING: Voyage of four has two main types of programming; engines and cinematics.

This game IS an interactive cinema
column15:
so much of the programming is dialogue or movements. I did not notice any flaws in the cinematic programming. The other major part of the game includes various engines.

WiL uses an original (I think) RPG engine which worked very well. The only thing I didn't think did much was the dodge option. Mabye I'm wrong.

Another engine I really enjoyed tracked the player's party across a map. For each step the player took
column16: random boulders would generate and turn into either breakables or fakes. Breakables acted as an obstacle
column17: possibly forcing you to take a different direction. To make this engine feel like a Final Fantasy type RPG
column18: enemies would randomly pop up on certain sqaures. When these were defeated
column19:
the player could resume his travel.

Overall
column20:
the programming was very good. It even had a few "tricks" like diaganol movement.

COMPLETE BATTERY: This game is definitely one of the better games in the archive
column21: and should be played by aspiring ZZTers. I really enjoyed it
column22: and didn't get the feeling of "When does this end?" I would give it a five
column23: but there were a few aspects that made me think otherwise. The story became boring in some parts
column24: and for a cinematic game
column25: that is not good. Everything else
column26: however
column27: was excellent

column1: C'mon guys...☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"After a careful replaying of the game
column2:
I decided that the above reviews do not adequetly highlight the obvious strengths of Nothing Constructive.

Indeed the narrative element is overused
column3: and it's more than once stated that "this was the worse decision of my life" or something along those lines. Dispite that the story of NC is rather enganging. The character of Zanno is an interesting hero
column4: a post office employee who blows the crap out of a co-worker/shoots random thugs in the streets
column5:
and gets drunk quite frequently. His only real goal is to survive.

The writing is a bit on the sloppy side
column6: with some poor and easily predicted jokes
column7:
but there are some golden moments in this game. The courtroom scene is the most dragged out scene in the game and could very well have been eliminated or shortened significantly. I will not comment on the Communist.

A lot of the gameplay is difficult and poorly concieved. The random shootouts with pirates/burglars/cops are frusterating. The game is sparce on health and ammo
column8: you are only allowed to shoot one bullet at a time
column9: and a lot of the action sequences are interupted by unneccesary spurts of plot or pointless narration. The gameplay is hit and miss. The shootouts can be fun
column10: or tragically annoying. Being in a corridore with 8 guys shooting at you from behind a water barrier is not my idea of a fun shootout
column11: and the programming that went into showing the other two characters dispatch their foes goes largely unnoticed by a player more interested in deducing how he's going to dodge the wall of incoming bullets. On the other hand the battle with one of the thugs is very difficult
column12: but still is one of the more ingenious AIs I've seen in ZZT shooters
column13:
and the battle with the space pirate captain is equally well programmed.

The random RPG battle was
column14: well
column15: random. Usually I don't like it when a game thrusts an RPG battle onto me unexpectedly (unless it's a game that has used many different engines all throughout)
column16: and I was a bit skeptical of the quality when reading the TXT file warning me of the impending event. I am not a fan of real time battles (Time gauge like in later Final Fantasies) but this one was a good one
column17: the enemies used life bars
column18: but not the breakable sort
column19: and the main characters' HP were actuall numbers
column20:
the action was fierce and quick paced.

There are some clever programming tricks used here
column21: and the graphics (although composed of a lot of linewalls) are well done and abstract
column22:
much like the plot. The differences between the earth and neptune are great and add a very nice sense of atmosphere :)

Overall
column23: Nothing Constuctive is not a game to be avoided. It's a diamond in the rough :P Okay
column24: that might be a little over the top... but none the less
column25: NC is a good game that was obviously a labour of love and one worthy of your time
column26:
unless you've got less than an hour...

SCATHING REVIEW☃"Zenith Nadir"☃"napalmlachatte@gmail.com"☃"Okay okay
column2: I'm going to try very
column3: very hard not to make this review an ad hominem attack. It hurts you
column4:
and it hurts me too. But... it will be difficult.

I hate ZZT Crime
column5: and I hate most of Wong Chung Bang's games too. You know that bit near the end of the newest ChickenWire where I go off on one about how his "retro-style" ZZT games are actually just derivative rip-offs of someone else's creativity? Well
column6: ZZT Crime isn't quite as retro
column7: but the point remains that he's basically let someone else do the hard work
column8: taken the best bits and used them for his own output. In fact
column9: it's worse here than in those games
column10:
where he at least tried to put an original spin on Tim Sweeney's zillion-year-old puzzles.

ZZT Crime touts itself as an unofficial "sequel" to Barjesse's seminal ZZT Syndrome. This would be fine
column11: if he were then to tackle problems not covered in the original file... but then the first seven boards repeat
column12: almost word-for-word
column13: EXACTLY what ZZT Syndrome advised; don't use yellow borders
column14: don't use lots of monsters
column15: don't use stars
column16: etc
column17: etc. Aside from being an obvious ripoff
column18: it's also superfluous; yes
column19: I realise that the game is geared towards amateur game designers
column20: but even so it's not hard to tell them to just go download the original file
column21: which is credited as "inspiration" on the title screen! Or maybe it's just a way to disguise your own dearth of ideas for the file? Surely not! I count that 18 of the game's 38 playable boards are dedicated to regurgitating Barjesse's advice. If it was just a little here and a little there I wouldn't mind
column22:
but good god man that's almost half the board total.

This continues throughout; the game tells you to give the player enough health and ammo
column23: not to lock your games (albeit with a semi-nifty "runtime error" animation and a better explanation of why not to use Super Locks)
column24: not to use ping-pong paths
column25: not to beg for money
column26: blah blah blah. All been done before
column27:
far more eloquently.

Anyway
column28: enough bitching about unoriginal content. The game does have some original advice
column29: such as the evils of item fields
column30: how to #lock and #unlock objects properly
column31: and an intensely irritating board where you are told by the author himself how stupid and terrible swearing is
column32: that makes me want to fuckin' smack him. These points are sound
column33: I guess (apart from the latter
column34: of course). Of course
column35: these original points are interspersed with Barjesse's stuff
column36: which as a veteran ZZTer I just find distracting
column37: although if you're a newbie who doesn't know any better you won't mind. Saying that's okay
column38: however
column39: is like saying it's okay for children to watch terrible low-quality cartoons; while it won't actually harm them
column40:
they won't thank you later.

Ironically
column41: the game suffers from a crime itself which is not mentioned throughout; linking the wrong board through a passage! It also veers dangerously close to another crime not mentioned; PLAGIARISM. Yes
column42: I'm really hung up on this. "You vs. Stupidity 2" is a far better guide on this matter
column43: and that's not even a tutorial
column44:
it's a game where you kill Blue's Clues.

On the plus side
column45: it's cool to be able to type "zzt crime" in the DOS prompt to load the game up
column46: and the graphics are okay (he actually uses STK this time around
column48: don't bother with this; get ZZT Syndrome and ZZT Pro (by Kjorteo
column49:
it's good even though I vehemently disagree with his stance on dark rooms) instead. You deserve better ZZT tutorials than this derivative rehash of someone else's ideas.

column1: Smiley Guy and Toxic Terminator☃"Al Payne"☃"al.payne@juno.com"☃"A word from the author . . .way to go Underdogs!  Nice to see the old games have survived.  Here's a bit of ZZT trivia about how these games came about.  Smiley Guy was one of the winners of a game contest that Epic Megagames sponsored to generate interest in ZZT.  I deliberately left off the password protection.  So
column2: it's great to see what Zenith did to improve the graphics.  In fact
column3: I had a graphically improved version of Smiley that I submitted
column4: but it was too late to make Epic's publication.  By the way
column5:
I no longer live at the address that you find early in the game.
Smiley received fan mail. Yeah
column6: fan mail!  Tim Sweeney at Epic told me that Smiley might have been the most popular of the contest entries.  So
column7: I sent him a sequel
column8: Toxic Terminator.  At first
column9: Tim rejected it
column10: because he was moving to 256-color graphics with Jill of the Jungle
column11: which I got to test while in prototype.  Later
column12: he called me and said his office got hooked on Toxic.  So
column13:
Toxic became Epic's last ZZT game tied to the roll out of Jill of the Jungle.
ZZT is fun and addictive. Enjoy!"☃"1080160219"☃"zzttoxic.zip"☃"5"☃"12.2.142.7"

Graphically the game is simple and pleasing. Certainly Newt has a good grasp of the concept of video game aesthetics as can be plainly seen on the title board.

column3: and the art itself is vivid
column4:
and iridescent with pioneering concepts. All the animals drawn are complete with hideous or beautiful appearances. Some of them have wicked looking faces complete teeth and grimaces. The use of STK is the best I have ever seen in this ZZT file; the colours are blended and arranged in comical images for the best possible ZZT art.

Unfortunately they let Peter Saltfleet (Nadir) do the narrative and preamble. His barely conscious and unfunny rhetoric is utterly painful to read. But since this is an art collection
column5: the bad writing skills are irrelevant; so I am awarding five stars."☃"1082785444"☃"OWNAGE.zip"☃"5"☃"195.92.67.79"

column1: Go back and DO IT AGAIN☃"medieval"☃"medieval@fairytooth.co.uk"☃"The title ?Flower of Light? will be considered ?cheesy? by many
column2: but insofar as the motive behind it can be discerned
column3:
I don?t really have a problem with this name. The game itself is quit boring. You must go to ?Fairyland? and find a flower that will cure the blindness of your king. Yawn.

Although the plot preamble is charming
column4: it is unfortunately debased with the impurities of nonsense. It seems that the author had a fairly good idea for the plot
column5:
but rushed its conception. And ultimately the viewer is left confused as to whether it deserves full acclaim.

When I finished the game
column6: I was left somewhat disappointed because it seems that the author put a lot of effort into the atmosphere of the game
column7: but rushed the narrative and plot elements. I enjoy games that can offer a unique atmosphere; like the wistful feelings of decay in DPLobster?s ?Daymare?
column8: the cold and breezy evocation of Herc?s ?A Community X-mas?
column9:
and the seriously retro-eighties feel of Well?s ?ESP?. But these outstanding atmospheres require a firm plot-base to uphold them; and it is vital that the author of a game has good literary skills. Unfortunately this requirement wasn?t met in ?Flower of Light?.

The graphics in ?Flower of Light? don?t remain at the original level of superiority. By the time you get halfway through the game
column10:
the boards appear rushed at best. The puzzles in the game are far too easy to solve. Does anyone remember those puzzles in ?Town of ZZT?? Now that?s what I want to see in these modern ZZT games.

Gameplay wasn?t very appreciable. You would expect uniqueness in monsters in a modern ZZT game
column11: not prefab enemies. And you get given too much health and ammo. The rpg battles are just copied from the original pioneering battles of other games. The author of this game hasn?t done anything to make them original
column12:
or even challenging. Boring.

The ending in this game is awful
column13: and it was so quick too. A quick ?You bring teh magik flower to da king and cure his eyes and stuff and the princess is saved and stuff. The End?. Sigh. I wanted something that would bring a tear to my eye. And you would expect that from a game with a title like ?Flower of Light?
column14: wouldn?t you? Yes

you would.

(My new method of awarding stars is to divide the maximum possible 5 stars between the five major aspects of a game. Action

column2: the game centers around a war between two rival street gangs
column3: the Green Dragons and the Red Dragons.  Of course
column4:
I can't really say for sure -- that was all inferred from the dialogue.

While there are some very good games that don't reveal much of the storyline at the beginning (i.e. Code Red) this one doesn't really give the player enough time to figure everything out -- I think I beat this in under three minutes. A little piece of advice for Nixon: only split your game if it's too big for ZZT to handle."☃"1083170550"☃"dragons1.zip"☃"1"☃"150.134.92.12"

column4: and combination of preprogramed and object enemies makes this a worthy addition to the ZZT saga. WCB's first game of this type

column7: which did not capture the feel of the original games. Pyramid on the otherhand

column15:
the simplisic graphics are less taxing on the eyes as the disjointed colour fest that was The City of ZZT. WCB's decision to abandon the excessive line wall aspect of the originals is much appreciated.

The writing
column16: what little there is

Is this thing really worth a 5?☃"Mr.bob"☃☃"     Ownage Triangle. This is not a zzt game but a collection of art boards done by two people who left ZZT years ago. Nadir gatherd the art and added a few little knickknacks here and there. Besides alot of art boards this 'game' has a few long speeches by Nadir
column2: and a demo of sorts of a game called
column3:
"THE PIT".
Now
column4: Ownage Triangle has really no gameplay in it besides looking at art
column5: but thankfully that is where the game excels the most in. It will show you PURTY art
column6: possibly the best that art can get in ZZT. Besides having almost no gameplay there is no music. (That I can remember). So
column7:
this is basically a short art museum tour. Not that its a bad art museum tour but lets say that the trip is TO short.

Gamplay-(I'll base this on "THE PIT")
Lets face it. Art Boards get boring. They get boring FAST. So it really is a nice addition to Ownage Triangle to have a nice little dungeon hack. The graphics of the dungeon hack simply dont give you much of a feel for the total atmosphere of the game so that sort of brings gameplay down a bit. There are many challenges and a few tid bits along the way but overall it is a bit repetitive and annoying. 3 out of 5.

Music- Like I said I did not hear any or mabey my music thing was off. So no score here. N/A

Graphics- Some of the best in ZZT. "THE PIT" however has poor graphics. I like seeing ZZT go this far
column8:
and hope we all can make ZZT art like this one day.
4.5 out of 5.

Funfactor- Not much fun in a short art tour
column9:
and "THE PIT" does add some much needed gameplay but just does not keep up the beat that long. 3 out of 5.

Story- Oh
column10:
yeah. This game has a great story. N/A

Overall- Nice
column11: worth the download

column2: (or game disaster)
column3: Appliance. Appliance's games over the years have almost always varied by Genre. This is his first Platformer to hit this site. Pandemonium Alpha is a solid platformer with some puzzels
column4: somewhat annoying enemies that can jump from the floor to the ceiling
column5: varying bosses
column6:
and a dissappointing story. The gameplay however is very well done but sometimes can be plain annoying.

Gameplay- The gameplay is solid
column7: and the enemies give you a hard time to get by. Sure the blind ninjas that can jump from the floor to the ceiling are kinda easy
column8: the metal turrents are put in the most annoying places EVER
column9: (Even in the first level). There a 5 parts of a level you have to go through
column10: the fith part is always a boss. The bosses are very well done in programming
column11: but in art style they somewhat look bland. Alot of the bosses
column12: however
column13: dont really need that much detail in art. How you beat them is the same
column14: look for the weak point and fire away. (One boss
column15: The Metal Spider
column16: you cant kill with bullets
column17: you have to find a different approach.) Few last things
column18: you have unlimited ammo
column19: there is a grappling hook
column20: (COOLNESS)
column21: and like in the Megaman games there are spikes that kill you by just touching them. =( HULK SMASH. All in all
column22:
the gameplay is pure and has just enough variety to get you through the game. 4.5 out of 5

Sound- The music is perfect. One can't say no to Level 5's music. In the game the cut scenes have music that propel the mood of the game onward. Appliance also put in music while you play the levels in the game. At first this sounds cool
column23:
but it gets VERY annoying after one or two minutes. The music is varried and can be very engaging and mood altering. (such as the fourth level where there is some light stealth action involved.) Together these pices of music are very well done but get annoying once you've heard them for awhile. 4.5 out of 5.

Graphics- The graphics in the gameplay certainly lack flair
column24:
but you would think the cut scenes would make up for it. They dont. But the graphics do add to the 'look' of the game so you really cant complain that much.
3 out of 5.

Story- It gives you some insight into the dark history of this small galaxy. There defiantly should be some more background into the diffrent 'worlds' that reside in this game. But sadly the only two plantes you know is the 'good' planet
column25: and the 'bad' planet. (Lucindea and Drakor
column26: however you spell them.)The story tells a tale of a young girl who saved her planet from impending doom and was cryogenicly frozen to keep her for the next time she was needed. Fenx
column27: (her new partner)
column28: is somewhat of a perv and loves Rina. Rina
column29: on the other hand
column30: would kill Fenx faster than you can say
column31: "Cheesy-pun-pinker-nickle"
column32:
if she did not need him to pilot her to her different mission areas. The game has great character development but the lack on other things really leave more to be disired. 3 out of 5.

Funfactor- Some fun is to be had. Be it the perverted jokes of Fenx
column33:
or the feeling you get once you've taken down an entire space fleet and sniped out one of the generals of the opposing army. 3.5 out of 5.

Overall- A nice game for when you have some free time. Im looking forward to Pandemonium Invasion. =)
3.5 out of 5

Leaps and bounds...☃"Dapper Gent"☃"dadsquad@aol.com"☃"...and Lyle the Panda is stuck in the pound!!

Panda-Monium: Alphabits is the latest sound novel from Goodwich Appliances
column2:
a former kitchenware manufacturer that just started making games this past spring. Does it fare as well as their grilled cheese sandwich maker? Well...

STORYLINE:

The storyline (which is what counts most in a sound novel) is very juvenile: you take the role of Lyle the Panda
column3: who lives with his owner
column4: a little boy named Jeffy Bone on Neat Street. Everything is fine and dandy
column5: until one evening
column6: you hear the incessant ringing of a telephone from the front yard. You venture out of your pandahouse. The next thing you know
column7:
you're in the back of a van and you're heading for the pound!! Why? That's what YOU have to figure out!

Although the story is aimed at younger audiences
column8: there are a few jokes and examples of social satire that us adults will chuckle knowingly to ourselves at. My favourite of these is a scene involving club politics in the secret barroom in the back of the pound
column9: which I won't spoil for you
column10: but let me tell you
column11: it's a real hoot. Anybody who can read will enjoy this game. Unfortunately
column12: the majority of the public do not have this skill
column13:
so this gets points off.

GRAPHICS:

I'm very pleased with what characte designers Alcazar Geddy did with this: No anthromorphic "furs"
column14: that you'd see in most of today's games
column15: movies or political rallies; Geddy stuck with making each animal look like a real animal. The rabbits? They're no bigger than the size of your hand
column16: and they look at you blankly
column17: or in slight confusion
column18: like a real rabbit would. The birds? You don't see the birds up-close-and-personal
column19: because
column20: like real birds
column21: they fly away in a panic when you approach! Bravo
column22:
Geddy! Bravo!

The backgrounds can be a bit bland at times
column23: but some scenes shine like no other. My favourite backgrounds are Neat Street
column24: the secret barroom
column25: the weight-lifting yard
column26:
and the spooky and atmospheric basement of the pound.

SOUND:

Goodwich Appliances must have pulled some major strings somewhere
column27: because they got K(yrgyzstan)-Pop idol Naryn Baryn-chan to sing the opening theme
column28: "Vinny Viddy Volvo". The song shines through the mud like headlights on a struck-down five-year-old girl. It even prompted me to buy a Naryn Baryn-chan album ("Sixty Fathers With No Way Home"
column29: if you're wondering
column30:
and it's superb).

The rest of the music
column31: however
column32: is standard Casio demo music. Not bad
column33:
but nothing mind blowing.

AESTHETICS:

Most sound novels have the same aesthetics; look
column34: investigate
column35: talk
column36: move
column37: use item
column38: etc. And for this
column39: Panda-Monium does its job well. There's a minigame near the end: a cowboy style quickdraw shootout with---oh
column40: I can't spoil it! The controls in this minigame are responsive
column41: and accurate. The guns miss every time
column42:
and occasionally jam and explode in your hand (paw?). I'm LOVING it.

OVERALL:

Unsurprisingly
column43: Panda-Monium hasn't brought anything new to the table. Surprisingly
column44: it's a fun little game from a kitchenware manufacturer! The heartwarming tale and slightly lewd humour kept me hooked to the end
column45:
and I'm sure it'll do the same to you.

So
column48: I raise my glass. A toast! A toast of..."☃"1084896104"☃"Pand1.zip"☃"3.5"☃"172.189.65.108"

column1:
A relic of ZZT's era gone by...☃"Rothul"☃☃"Remember that time is ZZT's history when it was all about AOL? Where Coolness and Yoshi's Island were the be-all end-all as ZZT games were concerned? Where Zed-Omega Productions ruled the gaming world with an iron fist?.
.
.
.
.
Me neither. I wasn't around then
column2:
but that's what makes ZZT Times so interesting.

It is of course
column3: a magazine first
column4: and it has the standard previews
column5: reviews
column6: mini-games
column7: programming tricks
column8: and the like
column9: all of which are handled quite nicely (though a bit overdone on the plugs for Sock Munching Ocelots and Nintendo Dinosaurs) but more than that
column10: for anyone interested in ZZT's early history
column11: it provides a snapshot of the ol' scene
column12:
circa 1995.

From an interview with Gregory Jansen (though not a good one
column13: unfortunately)
column14: to a preview of "Warlord's Temple" to a gaming survey that shows the top games of the day (and including several titles unrecognizable... note to self
column15: download AOL compilation)
column16:
to cameos from all the programmers of the day (JDewbre even!) It's as if you've comissioned a time machine for the incredibly stupid task of charting the history of an ANSI game programs.

In any case
column17: it's worth seeing for a laugh or two (especially Tucan's thinking that Yenrab was a guy
column19: and a definite reccomendation to anyone looking for some old-skool zzt. (Is that redundant or what?)"☃"1088814576"☃"times.zip"☃"4.5"☃"64.12.117.5"

column3: but it is satisfying(and humourous) to see a 100 or so "super-soldiers" whitle their numbers down to 5 within seconds. Also one thing that should be know by anyone programming an enemy is that you can't shoot it when it's touching you
column4: which makes the stair case scene a little annoying. There are artboards and cutscenes here
column5: which help drive the plot. And there's a little more freedom. It's not difficult at all
column6: you start with about 4000 health and 32000 bullets
column7:
making the shops and vending machines you encounter pointless.

FOr SKC Soft I'd suggest learning to program enemies better
column8: using perpendicular movement

column10: and learning when to use "?" instead of "/". There are times when the enemies get hung up in their flailing deaths. Learning what makes a good enemy in zzt can really only only come from playing others games

and doing a lot of experimentation.

Absolutely Terrible☃"Oris"☃"oris472@hotmail.com"☃"Dr. Dos said it all
column2: really.  What we have here is a bunch of engines stolen from the ZZT encyclopedia
column3:
it's put all together in an attempt to trick the player into believing that he has just downloaded a new cutting-edge ZZT OPERATING SYSTEM!!


...riiight.

To spare you the trouble of having to download this and see for yourself how bad it is
column4: which you will definitely regret
column5: I'll go into some detail
column6: deconstructing the so-called "features" of this... this... "thing."  There are three different "modes" you are given to choose from when you load WISH.  Regular
column7: Safe Mode
column8: and Deluxe.  As far as I can tell
column9: there is no reason at all  to select Regular or Safe modes
column10: all they do is make the graphics considerably worse AND take away some of the features.  Why do this?  Why take a bad thing and make it worse?  It's as if the author thinks that Wish DX might make ZZT "unstable" on certain machines
column11: because it is sooooo advanced
column12:
there must be 3 different modes so all kinds of computers can run this.

Uh-huh.

Next on our tour
column13: we are taken to a jukebox
column14: creatively titled "My Player" (ISN'T THAT CLEVER)  In the jukebox
column15: you are treated to "6" different musical selections... it turns out that in reality
column16: you only get 5.  The author didn't know the notes to one of the songs
column17: so it links to a request to send him the notes if you know them.  Cute.  Also included are some visualizations
column18: supposedly 3
column19: however there didn't seem to be a way to select anything.  It's nothing spectacular
column20: just your standard invisible fades in a small 8 by 10 box in the corner of the screen.  Boring.  If you have nothing better to do with your time
column21: you can even go into the editor and put your own music into one of the 4 "user slots" which are empty objects... then you can go into WISH and listen to it whenever you like!!!  Gone are the primitive times when you would be forced to rely on a rudimentary ZZT board that you must create yourself using a couple of buttons... you would actually have to use this method to store your music!!  Thank Zeus
column22: wish is released and now we can go through an unneccessary loading process and store our music creations in up to 4 "user slots."  If this doesn't feel cheap enough to you
column23:
the ZZT music creator thing from the encyclopedia has been stolen and placed in here as a "music editor" for your convenience... rejoice...

Next we come to "Project Pro" which is a complete waste of time. Honestly. There is a .txt document reader which is a waste of time if you have access to a program such as Notepad
column24: there's the graphics creator straight out of the Encyclopedia
column25:
and a "Spreadsheet Creator" which allows you to put a bunch of colored solids on a grid. Nothing to see here...

We come to "Games" next and here is where I was hoping to be impressed. (HAHAHA YEAH RIGHT) We have Wish Invaders up first
column26: which is truly awful and has very little in common with Space Invaders
column27: a far superior game.  Wish Demonz is directly stolen from some other game where you walk around a "3d" labyrinth and fight pre-programmed monsters at random... however
column28: it doesn't matter because you come in through a blocked passage
column29: so selecting this will force you to restart the program.  Then we have the breakout game which I have definitely seen somewhere else
column30: it's stolen and seems to be buggy.  The creator also thoughtfully included a section for "other games" where you
column31: the user
column32: can send him some games you want to see in future WISH releases.. *chokes on vomit*  No
column33: seriously
column34: he wants you to send him some games to put in the next version!  To quote:  "If I approve of it (fun or not)
column35: then I will put it in Wish."  Fun or not!!  This attitude shown by the programmer clearly shows us why this so-called operating system fails to deliver.  So-called "fun" is not one of his priorities.  Having reached this shocking conclusion
column36:
I cannot in good conscience continue to review this abomination.

Dr. Dos WAS being very kind with his 2/5. The two newbies who reviewed this and were sooo impressed by it that they felt the need to argue with reviews by more experienced members

column38:
per game." This isn't intended to be a discussion forum... that's what the Forums are for.

I'll borrow a phrase from Appliance
column39:
to sum up this entire review...

Give me the nice bright colours, I'd love to take☃"MadTom"☃"madtom@gmail.com"☃"<I>Aura</I> is the second major release of Dr. Dos'
column2: and depending on your perspective on community games like <I>Mooseka Richtlinen mit einer Eisenfaust</I>
column3: may be remembered as his best. It is an action/strategy game hybrid with influences from eastern philosophy
column4: Ikaruga
column5: and of course
column6:
ADOM.

In an alternate plane where every being
column7: except of course karmics such as yourself
column8: has an aura of either blue
column9: green
column10: or red
column11: imbalance has occurred and the aurae are struggling against one another. You're out to change all that
column12: even if it means destroying everything in the universe. Dr. Dos refers to these as the 'extinction' endings
column13: comprising three of seven possible conclusions to the game (not counting death)
column14:
one of the games' most recommending features.

Or perhaps you'd just like to have one aura dominate
column15: and then face the boss of that particular aura and lay down some good ol' fashioned karmic whoop-ass
column16:
using your unique ability to change aurae to meet that of your opponents. And you're going to be doing that a lot.

So you run around changing your aura as you meet your opponents. It sounds simple enough
column17: but the levels ascend in difficulty reasonably evenly
column18: and there are one or two that took me four or five save/die/restore attempts to complete. Others are a cakewalk
column19: however. The enemies vary in strength and intelligence
column20: while each aura maintains its own distinct characteristics (red creatures won't even move toward you much if at all
column21:
but they hurt a lot if you do contact them - but the blue ones are the true nasties).

One problem with the game is that at points it can get tedious. I would have been interested had Dos included some slightly less action-oriented puzzles - buttons that change the aura of opponents
column22: or open gates
column23: or using objects
column24: or similar linear puzzles
column25: in the vein of the development that craNKGod introduced into <I>Little Square Things</I>. That would have been neat. Some music or sound for the game would also have been nice (said MadTom
column26:
who was asked to do just that).

Graphics are one of Dos' self-confessed weaknesses
column27: but what the game lacks in an aesthetic sense is made up for in reasonably in-depth level design and a somewhat addictive
column28: though appropriately simple
column29: premise. I can't
column30: for reasons obvious
column31:
comment on the title screen and menu.

<I>Aura</I> is not an easy game. You are not going to beat it
column32: regardless of your choice of ending
column33: without saving/dying/restoring at least a few times. There are several tricks and traps
column34: some obvious and predictable
column35:
others quite nasty. You are likely to learn a few strategies ... which aura is best for the very first steps of each level?

The Ultimate Karmic God ending in particular is reasonably (but not incredibly) difficult to get. The only advice I will offer you is to have a good stockpile of health. Actually
column36:
that applies to just about every level of the game ... good thing health bonuses are reasonably abundant.

All in all
column37: the game is one of the best uploads to the site this year
column38: appropriately also being the very last one uploaded. Dr. Dos' skill as a ZZTer puts him easily within the range of Quantum P.
column39: Commodore
column40: and other present-day whizkids of the ZZTing scene
column41:
and I'm very much looking forward to his next release.

Good job

A leap forward in ZZT gaming!☃"dave2"☃"dragopublish@hotmail.com"☃"With it's astonishing 14 lines of code
column2: 3D talk engine breaks the fourth wall in ZZT
column3: nay
column4: worldwide gaming history.  Put aside for a minute the fact that the board you play on only takes up 2.7KB out of the 49KB within the zip file (28KB of that is a .doc file with a total of six lines
column5:
one of which is "Finally! After all these years! I?ve reaserched how to make characters that talk in 3d!" Another 14.5KB of that is toolkits which were not made by Mew).

Nobody ever said that a game needed to exceed 3KB to be a success (although it is a requirement of Z2). Nobody said that a game needed to let you move the player more than one time
column6: either.  That's right
column7: you move the player in this game a total of one time
column8:
but what an exhilarating one time it is.

Didn't I mention the graphics this game possesses? There's a fine looking chap with a red shirt and blue pants on
column9: and for some reason his arm is made up of objects.  Why?  To up the filesize
column10: no doubt.  To the right of the already excellent main feature is a road drawn with the word "amusment" beside it.  I am most certainly amused!  It doesn't matter that it makes no sense for a vertical road to be going up into the sky in the middle of a black void.  It's obviously amusing enough to stand alone.  It also doesn't matter that Mew misspelled "amusement" because this game rocks
column11: and that's all that matters.  I'm not going to be a grammer Nazi here
column12:
folks.

"Finally! After all these years! I?ve reaserched how to make characters that talk in 3d!" - Mew

On to the main feature of the game. The 3D talking. Don't know what it means to talk in 3D? Play this game to find out. Granted
column13: it's not a perfect example of 3D talking
column14: but for a ZZT emulation of it
column15:
it's about as close as one could ever wish to get!

"it was truly the zzt-oop triumph of the decade" - Nitr0 (Aka Stiltzkin)

After moving one time you are allowed
column16: you can then touch an object which makes a white object (the character's mouth) turn into #char 255 twice.  The game also makes two beeps
column17:
as the word "Hello" spouts from the mouth of the square headed character on the left side of the screen.

This is nothing but pure brilliance. It will forever change the way cinemas are made. I don't know a single ZZTer who hasn't made use of the 3D Talk Engine. As Mew tells us at the end of his 28KB .doc file
column18: "Don?t laugh at it
column19: there will be better versions soon."  I don't think ANYBODY is laughing
column20: Mew.  All I can hear is applause!  5/5."☃"1089928096"☃"3dtalk.zip"☃"5"☃"207.161.35.81"

column1: Mercenary, The☃"Adamsk"☃"orochip_fish@yahoo.com"☃"First off
column2: let me state that the relic system is awesome. But
column3:
it wouldn't be all that great if the experience system wasn't there as well. Both of these things make Mercenary a great game to play.
And though I think that the experience system was executed flawlessly do have a little problem with the relic system.
It became very apparent on my first run through the game exactly what path I would have taken if I had chosen the other relics. The game feels quite cramped when this happens and while I agree to some extent whith the other reviewer who thought that more than three relics would have been good
column4:

everything is _very_ straitforward. There's a lot you don't ever have to do.

Basically it starts in an insane asylum where everyone breaks out and you have to track them down. Tracking them down involves going east and fighting tigers before finally getting to a cave where you face all the escapees one at a time in boss format after they have gained super powers from some sort of machine.

Graphically the game is acceptable
column4:
with plenty of stk and a some decent fades. Gameplay wise it is rather weak. The only real challange is the boss fights (11 of them) at the end which make up the bulk of the playing time. There is no music save the open bars of the power rangers theme.

Overall it can waste an hour of your time

Who the hell deltes a .zzt file. It's not 200mb or☃"Dr. Dos"☃"DoctorDos@gmail.com"☃"I found Anilihator several years ago. And really Commodore's review was pretty accurate on this game.

one leading to victory the other leading to your demise (school zzt).

This game presents a very powerful message about how society alienates those who are different causing them to become angry at us leading to such events as they occur in anilihator.

column4:
and several minigames which represented stuff you might do along the way. I'd made several boards for it as well.
The reason I gave up is because it's a mundane theme for a game.

column1: Indeed, but...☃"Ender"☃☃"What is there to be said that hasn't already been said by our good friend Flimsy?  A lot
column2: in fact.  He really missed the point of the game
column3:
at least as I saw it.

The game begins with the cryptic message RISE AND ASSIMILATE THE DAY
RESISTANCE IS FUTILE. It quickly becomes clear that this game will be played on many levels
column4:
most not on a plane you see in zzt games often.

You play the role of Ebert
column5:
a suicidally depressed WWII vet centegenarian fighting a losing battle with not one but two diseases: Alzheimers and cancer of the body.

The frantic red door is representative of Ebert's mix of dementias: He's trying to kill himself while fighting to stay alive against a tumor knawing away at his body. The tesla coil in his bedroom represents the folly of youth. The sad TV is a bitingly ironic symbol of the horror in the news and media today. There is much more
column6:
but we won't get in to that.

The story is touching: you'll want to laugh
column7: cry
column8: sneeze
column9: fuck
column10:
and do miscellaneous other things whilst playing. It's an emotional rollercoaster.

There are many ways to go; you could go to the rumpus room
column11: or the living room
column12:
or visit the Oval Office! (from the outside!)

And there are gags too
column13: such as be sure to check out the skeletons in Ebert's closet
column14:
or ZAP the door to the room in the upper right corner of the first screen and watch as hilarity ensues.

the last act left me in tears: A runtime error in the living room
column15: representative of good ol' Ebert's passing to the other side.  An abrutpt end to an altogether unforgettable game.  Bravo
column16:
Anonmonymous. I salute you.

Ps there is one complaint I have
column17: however: the game is all too short.  Please make another installment
column18: Mr. 'Mous.  THINK OF THE CHILDREN."☃"1107467893"☃"ebert.zip"☃"4.5"☃"63.228.43.94"

column1:
this game has too many positive reviews and i will☃"Zenith Nadir"☃"napalmlachatte@gmail.com"☃"Chase Bramlage; the Rob Liefeld of ZZT.

I'm sure he'd know what I'm talking about
column2: if he saw this review; his games have always betrayed strong influence from 90's Image Comics to the point of near-plagiarism (his first game
column3: for example
column4: was called Boof
column5: and was about a gerbil with telekinetic powers; I'm sure it's no relation at all to the now mostly-forgotten Todd McFarlane creation "Boof and the Bruise Crew" (the title character of which was also a mouse-like thing))
column6: although I suppose that doesn't matter since it's only ZZT and
column7: well
column8:
who cares who rips off what in these games?

Back to the point; why do I call Bramlage the Liefeld of ZZT? Rob Liefeld
column9: for those who don't know
column10: was
column11: if not the key proponent of it
column12: certainly a major element of the style-over-substance
column13: kewl
column14: X-tryme
column15: "which superhero will die in this issue"
column16: exaggerated anatomy
column17: 100 bad rip-offs of Wolverine/Lobo
column18: gun-toting 'bad girl' garbage that most people think of when they consider the comic collector/speculator boom and bust of the 90's. Although this parallel is most evident in his game 'N-E-O' (in which every character seems to be a testosterone-sweating
column19: hulking great caricature of the Liefeld creation Cable)
column20:
Final Fantasy Disc 1 still has a lot to say for itself. Let's see.

Graphics; While it's true that Chase can draw pretty well
column21: he then goes and wastes this talent by using a technique that could generously be described as 'diffuse'; objects may be well drawn
column22: it's just that you can't work out what the hell they are. The houses in the first village look like month-old horse turds with windows installed
column23: and the floor texture in the castle looks like everything's been chewed up by a puppy yet to be housebroken. There's a lot to be said for simplicity
column24:
especially in something as graphically primitive as ANSI.

In other words
column25: top marks for style
column26:
minimum marks for technique. Just like Liefeld (but replace 'diffuse' with 'tiny ankles and swiss-cheese necks')!!!!!!!!!

Story; As has been discussed in depth by people who have actually played the damn game
column27: this is a huge rip-off from Suikoden. As if stealing the name from a famous gaming franchise wasn't enough! I don't know much about Suikoden so I won't say anything else about that
column28: though it goes without saying that Liefeld stole a lot of character designs from Marvel and DC during his tenure in Image (most notably Supreme
column29: which Alan Moore later changed from a moronic
column30: violent comic into something pretty awesome
column31:
but that's irrelevant).

Programming; Oh hell
column32: I can't really make any comparisons between Chase and Liefeld in this catagory
column33: can I? Well
column34: I'll just say the programming is shoddy and leave it at that
column35: shall I? I suppose that's excusable since the game is blatantly unfinished
column36: but there's no excuse for the dialogue. I'm no writer myself
column37:
but I could crap out better dialogue than this "casual" scene's;

--
It is Devin Liukan
column38:
your childhood
friend
column39:
you haven't seen in years.
He rushes up to greet you. You both
embrace.

Devin: "Surprise
column40:
dear friend!"

You: "What brings you to Stonegate?"

Devin: "I was in town on business
column41:
and
I heard of your acquisition by the king.
-I have come to congratulate you.."

You: "My friend
column42:
.. how long has it been?"

Devin: "Three years I believe.."

You: "You still studying to be a thief?"

Devin: "Still studying?! Hell I'm the teacher now!"

You both laugh.
--

That is the funniest joke in the game. See what he did there?! As can be inferred from the dialogue
column43: all the characters talk the same and there's really no characterisation; Devin is The Friend who accompanies you on your quest
column44: Cleo is Your Sister (who annoyingly says "Father" or "Brother" at the end of seemingly every sentence she speaks)
column48:
which would be fine if there was at least an attempt at some sort of development; but it never comes.

As an aside
column49: an odd quirk of Chase's that I've noticed on editing his work is how his commands all seem to have something to do with excrement; ':poop'
column53: I'm just mentioning it as yet another possible parallel to Liefeld's propensity have his characters say 'shit' frequently. However
column54: there are not enough references to blood in the code for this to be a major point (Bloodlines has 'blood' in the title though
column55:
I suppose that counts).

-

And it's awesome that Chase has only ever finished one project (ie. Bloodlines; I suppose I've no room to talk
column56: I've not touched any aspect of Frost
column59: again just like Rob Liefeld!! Holy shit
column60: it's like they're the same person! I'm surprised Chase never tried to release his ZZT games with multiple title screens (one of which would
column62:
be somehow covered in some kind of holofoil crap)!

Of course
column63: taking the parallel to its conclusion
column64: Final Fantasy Disc 1 has become the butt of a lot of jokes
column65:
just like Youngblood did. Ha ha.

In conclusion

which is an element absent from 90% of Chase's output.

0/5. I'd give it 0.5/5 but I feel a deep and abiding need to lower the score some more from those positive reviews.

column1: An A for effort but...☃"Smiley19"☃☃"Well
column2: here's some context boys - Freedom
column3: for a ZZT game
column4: had some massive hype behind it. It featured music by Kevin Carter
column5: aka Kev-san
column6: who was a 13 year-old musical prodigy. It was also announced during a brief high in "Classy
column7: deep
column8: meaningful" ZZT games spearheaded by Anthony Testa
column9: aka Shigesato
column10: who would later provide the kick-ass graphics to Freedom. The main selling point was the fact that it was a Rock Opera done on ZZT with music by Kev-san. On paper
column11:
it looked like a hit.

But... let me give some history here
I was good friends with Kev
column12: so I could tell you that Freedom was mulling over in his head for a very long time. However
column13: Kev is
column14: IMHO
column15: a better composer than writer
column16: and it shows. Many ideas were basically lifted straight from the classic novel The Giver along with little drops of the darker 1984 - Small community
column17: protagonist with some sort of undefined specialness
column18: evil government and an overall sense of oppression with a tender love story attached. Okay
column19: sure. Not very creative
column20:
but I'm sure that part of Kev's reasoning to make Freedom a musical was because you can get away with unoriginality in a musical so long as your music is good.

Uhh...almost.

Now
column21: despite some of these other reviews
column22: some of the music is pretty kickass. There used to be a CD Kev had which contained all the music using synthesized instruments and I can tell you from what little I heard
column23:
the music kicked ass before being butchered into this.

In detail -

1) Overture - YES! YES! This is great...the intro with our protagonist falling and this wonderful music going at insanely fast speeds. It's fast-paced and epic
column24: yet dark. This is Kev at his finest
column25:
where the PC speaker sounds like an actual instrument.

War - Uhh..no. Total 180 from the beginning. Seems to be going for a jazzy feel at first
column26:
but then it just devolves into some tuneless mess with some drum work that doesn't sound half as good as it should. The lyrics are also kinda bleh.

Decision - The evilll elders are meeting. Great
column27:
simple yet stylish graphics are present here with a pretty decent sound. The lyrics aren't too bad either and there is a fuckin' awesome 'solo' in the middle which again shows why Kev was so sought after for projects. Fairly good.

(I forget the rest of the titles here so..)

Birth - Yeah
column28: our hero is born to some mediocre writing and composition which
column29: while adequate
column30: didn't translate into ZZT very well. I'm sure Kev meant this to have lots of symbolism with stuff like "wrapped in fleece
column31:
" but it all falls flat. The art is not that great either.

Micah's Angsting - Okay
column32: so our hero was put into a home for the retarded to stop his powers from taking over the Elders. Right... Kev really seems to want to make this be a Pink Floyd The Wall esque moment...but. No. Tune is forgettable and the lyrics are
column33: again
column34:
flat. Shigesato did some nice graphics for this one though.

So he goes outside FOR THE FIRST TIME EVAR.

Love Song - Right
column35: you met this chick. She's all cool and into you. You're both rebels and she's a REVOLUTIONARY VIVA ZAPATA. Sorry
column36: but this story is going nowhere. Okay
column37:
they kiss and run off into the forests. Lyrics here are simply wretched (sorry Kev) and the graphics make Rina look retarded herself. Tune is rather catchy though.

Ending music - beautiful. Expands on the tune of the overture and takes it into an almost apocalyptic direction. It's wonderful and causes one to think of What Could've Been if the story had been expaned upon the lyrics refined to exude the class that Shigesato so desperately wanted ZZT to have.

And then it just drops us
column38:
DO THEY *REALLY* live Happily Ever After or DID THEY JUST SCREW THEMSELVES OVER!?!

Sadly
column39:
it could've been interesting to see Rina's revolutionary personality taken deeper - why is she fighting? What is Jorosh the elder really up to? What's so damn special about Micah?

Sadly
column40: none of this will ever be found out. Kev intentionally made his ending ambiguous out of keeping things "open to interpretation." The only problem is that he should've made a story that was interpretable in the first place. As it stands
column41: we're left some pretty incomprehensible symbolism
column42: athmospheric graphics with no athmosphere
column43: music that's up and down and then some. Yeah. Admittedly Kev had alot of frustration over this one
column44:
but he should've kept at it in some spots. Oh well.

A 4 for nostalgia from talking with Kev at 1am about preteen angst when I was 14. 2.5 for actual quality."☃"1112767527"☃"freedom.zip"☃"2.5"☃"172.195.145.118"

column1: Kind of like a Darkthrone album.☃"MaðTom"☃"madtom@gmail.com"☃"You know
column2: this used to be my favourite ZZT game
column3: even after playing the requisite Zenith Nadir and drac0 classics that comprised my earlier obsessions. Of course

column8: really - in ZZT is not an easy task. I've been there. For half of the projects the wise musician will realise about halfway through that this simply isn't working
column9: that even alternating notes just doesn't make it sound right. I've dumped plenty of tracks that way. kev takes on the (in my opinion) insurmountable task of doing this with ONE track of sound. Bluntly

and given kev's ambitions I think it's been done very well.

column13: a remarkably brief story with vague utopian connotations

column15: topped off with the wails
column16: squeals and buzzes of a minor-key track - no matter how good music and the story behind it is
column17:
you cannot convey it in its full glory through a beeping PC speaker. kev himself acknowledges this in the editor notes.

This is why I now firmly believe that the idea of a ZZT musical just isn't going to work. It really didn't even work with <I>The Rose</I>

the shooting ruffians while running through endless ammo fields.

column1: what? no grapes of wrath?☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"In this game you play the loveable retard

column1: Best ZZT Games Ever: Aliens.zzt☃"WiL"☃"masterwil@gmail.com"☃"I recently played all the ZZT games made from 1991 to at least the end of 2003
column2:
maybe beyond - nearly two thousand games in all. Of those I have selected just 66 to be included in my list of "best ZZT games ever."

One of these is "Aliens"
column3: a distinctly ancient game without much in the way of graphics and programming.  Perhaps most of the mojo of this game is unintentional; i would not be surprised if it was.  You are a soldier fighting (Aliens.)
column4: so we're told by the king.  the game starts with an enigmatic "What am i doing here?" which could have been uttered by your character
column5: one of the king's talking guards
column6: or the narrator's eye now cast upon this unlikely hero
column7: or intended to be uttered by you
column8: the player
column9: upon entering this gameworld.  When you and your fellow soldiers are lined up in front of a bunch of aliens
column10: the weapons of your compatriots are wholly ineffective - you must go in
column11: guns blazing
column12: only 50 ammo and a lot of scum to kill.  The gameplay is much like any newbie game thereafter
column13: with the strange addendum of people shouting catchphrases at you at every turn
column14: things like "what you see is not what you think" when traversing a mountain range or "we are counting on you to kill their leader" when their 'leader' appears to be noting more than a bunch of discombobulated centipede segments.  Perhaps if mr miller has played through his game even once
column15: or had worked on it a bit more or been exposed to other games by which he could benchmark his own
column16: we would not have this splended gem of oddness.  I like it because it pays attention to the things that are important - giving the king a name
column17: giving the soldier's story some attention beyond the introduction
column18:
giving us more during and even after the ass kicking ensues - while paying no attention whatsoever to those things which one would expect to pay attention to when making a game; do my objects do what they're supposed to do? Does the layout of my boards make any visual sense?

I hope beyond anything that games like this are somewhere
column19: somehow
column20: being made deliberately - with a little attention this game could be a classic gem
column21: as is
column22: it still shares the spotlight as one of the best zzt games ever."☃"1115376010"☃"aliens.zip"☃"3"☃"12.202.241.141"

column1:
Ingenious engine!☃"wil"☃"masterwil@gmail.com"☃"Good points: This is a well-implemented and bugless true side-scrolling engine for ZZT! It is better than my sidescroller in that it scrolls in all 4 directions and manipulates a persistent world.

Bad Points: slowest engine ever made for ZZT. Use of invisibles severely narrows the potential scope of the project.

Retrospect: best engine for ZZT ever.
I would love to see a plastic version
column2: which could have a much wider variety of terrain types and would run real-time using #look."☃"1125769213"☃"panning.zip"☃"4"☃"12.222.159.167"

column1: Nicely done.☃"Quantum"☃"cipher110@yahoo.com"☃"<i>ZZT Pro</i> is a very nice set of lessons on problems to avoid when writing ZZT games. A lot of it is common sense to non-newbies and has appeared before in <i>ZZT Syndromes</i> (its predecessor)
column2:
but it contains a few tips that anyone can consider and some material that is updated/new.

A fair amount of the content is opinion. However
column3: I do not think this detracts significantly from <i>ZZT Pro</i>
column4: as it is just as valuable to hear the likes/dislikes of a fellow ZZTer as it is to be preached objective fact. Kjorteo even stated himself that his suggestions are not absolute
column5: just ideas to be taken into consideration. As a result
column6:
I have no complaints on this point.

A couple of lessons did not seem thoroughly discussed. For example
column7: the section on guarding against cheating left out a couple of methods that have already been described in the <i>ZZT-OOP Encyclopedia</i>. I also agree with Commodore to a certain extent that there could have been a tad more content. However
column8: these are not significant concerns
column9:
as long as you don't consider this to be the 100% comprehensive guide to everything ZZT.

Finally
column10: the bulk of the content mostly applies only to newbies; I was hoping for something even more advanced
column11: perhaps more tutorials on psychology
column12: creating balanced gameplay
column13: etc... Still
column14:
this is a valuable resource for a newcomer.

Conclusion: A very good update to <i>ZZT Syndromes</i> that could have been ever-so-slightly better. Good work
