column1: A masterpiece.☃"Anonymous"☃☃"The grand-daddy of all frustrating puzzlers
column2: and arguably rei-chan's finest work (even finer than Code Red). It's also unique as there are even red herring items in the game
column3: possibly hinting it was planned to be much longer. There is so much packed into this baby that three of the boards exceed 19K
column4:
and one exceeds 18K!

People have complained about the ridiculous difficulty of Mission: Enigma (especially the final board)
column5:
and few have beaten it without cheating. Below is a complete walkthrough.

It's without a doubt the best 10-board game (12 after title screen and ending) ever made
column6: although it's a shame that the plot wasn't more fleshed out
column7:
possibly because rei-chan didn't want to risk runtime errors. It still deserves a 5/5.

WALKTHROUGH
Steps starting with the word SAVE require precision timing. If you mess up
column8: you won't get a second chance. Most importantly
column9:
do not waste your ammo!

PART I - MAIN FLOOR
1. SAVE. Hide north of the bush until the sentry goes to sleep. Enter the fortress.
2. Read the DOS 9.12h manual. Enter the southwest room.
3. SAVE. Stand a bit away from the knife trap. Activate it
column10:
then step out of the way and touch it from the north or south as it flies toward you.
4. Shoot an empty bottle (ammo=5). Pick up the shard.
5. Enter the southeast room. Touch the guard to stab him. Grab both items on his body. Unlock the door he was guarding and enter the basement.
6. Light a torch. Ignore the oil barrel and bucket (red herring) and keep walking ahead. Touch the guard to stab him. Grab both items on his body. Pull the bar to the right and walk west. Set AC to maximum. Turn off the water valve. Walk west to see a left bucket. Move that bucket three spaces east so that it's aligned with the straight pipe section jutting out of the wall. Shoot the straight pipe section (ammo=4).
7. SAVE. Turn on the water valve
column11:
then immediately turn it off. Pick up the bucket filled with water. Return to the main floor.
8. Pick up the ammo in the southwest room (ammo=6). Enter the northwest room. Ignore the bottle of red wine (red herring).
9. SAVE. Shoot the east air duct (ammo=5). It might take a couple of tries to get this
column12:
but don't use more than 2 ammo to do it. This walkthrough will assume you destroyed it using one shot. Enter the north room.
10. Push the crate so that it's adjacent to the air duct
column13:
destroying it. Enter the northeast room with the crate.
11. SAVE. Shoot the air duct (ammo=4).
12. SAVE. Move the mirror east
column14:
then north so that it's positioned at the northeast corner. Do not slam it against the wall or else it will break!
13. Exchange the diamond on the pedastal with the ruby ring. Fire the lazer. Touch the flames to douse them with your water bucket.
14. Push the crate so that it's west of the lower part of the spring. Activate the spring
column15:
then push the wall back. Push the crate one space west to destroy the air duct. This will move the crate one space north. Now push the crate all the way to the end of the hallway and destroy that air duct. The crate will then move one space south due to the explosion.
15. Push the crate east to where the air duct in the southeast room once was
column16: then walk around and push the crate north. Now you can push the crate into the west room. There are a couple of things to take care of before you do that
column17:
though.
16. Walk outside and pick up the clay. Enter the blue passage
column18: light a torch
column19:
and pick up the gloves. Walk out and re-enter the fortress.
17. Re-enter the basement via the southeast room. Light a torch if necessary. Cover the punctured water pipe with the clay
column20:
then turn on the water valve. Return to the main floor.
18. Use the crate to destroy the air duct in that room
column21:
then push it into the north room and onto the right panel. Now you can enter the second floor!

PART II - SECOND FLOOR AND COMMTHOUGHT
19. Here is the electric maze solution. When you solve it
column22:
enter the north passage:
A. Center room: Press
B. Left room: Middle
column23: left
column24:
right
C. North room: Left
column25:
right
D. Left room: Middle
E. Right room (3 buttons): Left
column26:
middle
F. Far right room: Press
20. Press the switch
column27:
then enter CommThought.
21. Clear the rubble. Walk over to the green defensive chip
column28:
making sure not to touch anything else! The right section of the defensive chip will have a panel. Open it and grab the silver key. Leave.
22. Re-enter the second floor and unlock the silver door. You'll end up in the basement again after going through a series of passages. Light a torch
column29:
then make a note of the manual override code. Leave and re-enter CommThought.
23. All of the purple buttons have a letter designation. Press them in the exact order of the manual override code. The forcefield should lower. Fix the electric wire break
column30:
then leave.
24. Press the switch and enter the green room to play GEMini.
25. SAVE. Defeat CommThought at GEMini. The general strategy is to move pieces 1 and 2 towards the center. Once you do that
column31:
it will be impossible for CommThought to win.
26. Enter the passage to the right of CommThought to get one ammo (ammo=5). Attempt to enter the left passage
column32: then quickly touch the blockade. Once Karen finishes casting Levitate
column33:
enter the passage.
27. SAVE. RUN!!!

PART III - BOSS FIGHT AND CAVERN OF ILLUSION
28. SAVE. Don't attack Karen or Maleen. Instead
column34: shoot Dr. Kris up to five times by continually touching your console
column35: then finish him off with a melee attack. Once you control Karen
column36: alternate casting spells against the demon and melee attacking the demon on your end. You should deal damage faster than Maleen can heal. When you win
column37:
head north to enter the hardest section of the game.
NOTE: If you're not fast enough and Karen dies
column38:
you won't get the extended ending.
29. SAVE. Be quick
column39: as you'll need every last bit of that time! Grab the three visible rocks (ammo=3). Position yourself so that you're south of the right dragon
column40: then touch it twice. As it opens its mouth
column41:
move away and it should shoot south to reveal another rock. grab it (ammo=4).
30. SAVE. Talk to Karen to get her out of the way. Face west of the right dragon and touch it. Step away and it should destroy the left dragon. Touch its remains to grab the golden key. Touch its remains again so that it moves aside. Walk on the space where it used to be
column42:
then touch the west wall to pick up a hidden rock (ammo=5). Unlock the door.
31. SAVE. Carefully shoot the snakes
column43:
as you can only afford one shot for each of them (ammo=3). Unlock and enter the room to the north.
32. SAVE. Here is the solution to the Music-Lock combonation [sic] room. The numbers represent equivalent positions on a clock. 12 is the north door
column44: and 6 is the south door. There is no 3
column68: you should have at least 140 ticks remaining on the clock. If you don't
column69:
you won't have enough time to escape. Head north.
33. SAVE. There is a suspicious piece of the wall sticking out. Shoot it
column70:
making sure that there is a one space gap for it to register (ammo=2). It should turn into a boulder. Push that boulder two spaces west so that it's out of the way.
34. Unlock and enter the west room (the one with the triangle things). Those triangles are stalactites. Shoot the rightmost one from the south
column71:
again making sure that there is a one-space gap (ammo=1). It should fall one space south and turn into a boulder.
35. Push that boulder east. Open the door to the east room
column72: then push the boulder east so that it dislodges the key from the pedestal and takes the place where the key once was. Grab the key
column73:
then turn the water valve on and off.
36. Go back into the north room and shoot east into the river (ammo=0). This will reveal a secret room. Use the lettered buttons to change the white door into the matching door of your key. Each letter represents a different color.
37. Once that's done
column74: hurry through the colored door and out of the fortress! You win!"☃"1138712916"☃"enigma.zip"☃"5"☃"216.99.61.30"

column1: Island of ZZT☃"Quantum P."☃"christophermounce@gmail.com"☃"At first glance
column2: <i>Island of ZZT</i> isn't too impressive; it just looks like the average ZZTer's first game. However
column3: when I played the game
column4:
I noticed a few things that make me think that Ajc1490 has a bright future in the ZZT world.

The graphics
column5: although primitive
column6: improve throughout the game. Many of the boards show use of textures; for example
column7: the sand has a random appearance
column8: there are waves in the water
column9: <i>etc</i>... The pathways have wavy
column10: flowing shapes
column11: fitting the natural settings of the beach and the woods. Palm trees and thick vines give the player some scenery to look at. The dark cellar was especially well-done. It was very simple
column12: but the dark colors chosen did a good job of theming the area
column13: and the bones and blood were a nice touch! For a beginner
column14: these are graphics to be proud of
column15:
and I encourage Ajc1490 to keep developing his style.

The gameplay of <i>Island of ZZT</i> reminds me of older ZZT games. Most of the monsters in the game are the built-in lions
column16: tigers
column17: bears
column18: and centipedes
column19: which aren't used that much in modern games; there could have been more object enemies. The game is easy and not terribly innovative by today's standards
column20: but it can be seen that some thought went into the game. One of the things that struck me was the dying man in the native village. The typical ZZT cliche for giving the player money is to have a an unexplained stash of gems. Instead
column21: in this game there is some explanation for the money; the dying man
column22: reflecting on the fact that earthly riches mean nothing in the afterlife
column23:
gives you his money.

<i>Island of ZZT</i> is not an epic
column24: groundbreaking game
column25: but it does have a certain charm to it. As Ajc1490 improves as a programmer
column26: I believe that he will go on to create some very good games. I hope to see more of his work in the future!"☃"1140486052"☃"Island.zip"☃"3"☃"140.142.173.15"

column1: Whoa.☃"My Liver Hurtz"☃"myliverhurtz@3web.net"☃"I heard FYNDR's request for a review of this game
column2: so
column3: I decided to take a gander at it. I wasn't expecting very much... but
column4: thankfully
column5: I got more than I was expecting. This game is by no means an awful newbie game
column6: instead
column7: it was an enjoyable one. Granted
column8:
I haven't played much ZZT in the past few years and I'm just getting back into the swing of things now.

The graphics were very
column9: very simplistic
column10: so not many marks there. Where my score of 2.5 comes from is the concept and the humour. The concept could have been executed much more
column11: but
column12:
FYNDR more than displays enough potential to create some very trippy and intriguing game concepts.

The atmosphere of Lucidity from the title screen is in tune with the rest of the game. The odd man out is the opening board which sets a darker
column13: more serious tone that I would've preferred been explored
column14:
that I thought opened up a lot of possibilities for a great game.

So
column15: I was a bit disappointed by the typical ZZT going-ons with this game. The humour
column16: though
column17: for some reason really got me. "Hot dogses" and the hot dog stand spontaniously collapsing made me laugh a lot more than they should have. I suppose it's just because it doesn't take itself too seriously... granted
column18: 99% of ZZT games don't
column19: but
column20: this one took another route in the humour which I can't quite pin. FYNDR's humour is more defined in Agent Blue
column21:
I believe.

Anyways
column22: Lucidity is a nice diversion. I enjoyed playing it
column23: though
column24:
it is familiar ground. Very familiar ground.

What I'd love to see is for FYNDR to hone in on his particular sense of humour and style of storytelling and be less general. I'll discuss this more in my review of Agent Blue."☃"1140729218"☃"lucidity.zip"☃"2"☃"199.243.20.27"

column1: Promising☃"My"☃"myliverhurtz@3web.net"☃"I found this game to be more enjoyable than Lucidity. The story is less promising
column2: but
column3: it gives what it promises. The graphics leave much
column4: much to be desired
column5: and there's very
column6: very
column7:
very little innovation in terms of gameplay.

I said I'd concentrate on his humour for this review
column8: though
column9: so I will. FYNDR incorporates tried-and-true ZZT humour and cliches into this game. It gives it a very
column10: very generic feel. Where I sense a difference
column11: though
column12: is in a few key moments of pure hilarity. The ones I can remember the most
column13: since I haven't finished the game
column14: are of the first level on the Cuban superjet. After breaking out of a jailcell (get used to this) your partner in jailbreaking gets mowed down by a million guys with guns. Then
column15: simaltaniously
column16: they all run out of ammo and retreat before seeing you. Your partner's staggered back with blood dripping on the floor. It's really
column17: really
column18: really funny. Then there's the plumbing system placed right where you need it
column19:
where you can overhear the enemy giving you a secret to be found in there. It's just funny.

The reason I gave this a higher score than I normally would is because of that promise of humour which I don't tend to see in ZZT games. Then again
column20: I don't tend to play too many newbie games
column21: so
column22: it might not be all that original. In any case
column23: I think FYNDR shows incredible promise. If he can drop generic humor and clicheic gameplay and focus in on his own particular brand of funny and model his gameplay after it - with good graphics - I can see myself really
column24: really enjoying one of his creations."☃"1140729646"☃"agentblue.zip"☃"2.5"☃"199.243.20.27"

column1: board linking? who needs that?☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"looking for a "classic" game

A nice idea was the author's attempt to saturate the game with music. Some of the tunes were good

play at your own risk."☃"1141695411"☃"metacus.zip"☃"1"☃"24.183.176.86"

column1: Interesting...☃"Quantum"☃"christophermounce@gmail.com"☃"<i>4</i> is an interesting little game. John W. Wells described it well; it is a puzzle game built around a clever cursor engine. The game kept me amused for a while
column2: is pretty much bug-free
column3:
and it looks decent.

However
column4: that is about all the praise that I can give this game. The only thing that kept me playing was curiosity about how the game would end up. There is a story
column5: but it is very vague
column6: and it seemed hastily typed. The gameplay is standard; you win the game by trying every object with every other object. This can get tiresome and even frustrating. Some things just made me wonder; for example
column7:
why is there only one thing - a fish - in the spring? Shouldn't there be at least two objects in every scene to justify the cursor engine that is used to select them?

<i>4</i> is an neat little demonstration of an innovative engine
column8: but it doesn't have much replay value. It is not a complete piece of junk and is certainly worth a look
column9: but it isn't that good as a game."☃"1144366849"☃"four.zip"☃"2.5"☃"71.112.202.198"

column1: Blob Squash☃"Zephyr"☃"drummermlw@gmail.com"☃"This is simply another average
column2: clichéd
column3:
grammatically incorrect zzt game. Nothing too special here.

PLOT: You play a male named Bret who is a member of the town's BOMB SQUAD. Along with your three crazy counterparts
column4: you rid the *nice* town of evil (but only once). There seemed to be a developing plot about aliens invading and destroying the town
column5:
but the game ended before anything really happened.

GAMEPLAY: Too.. Many.. #Endgames.. Sitting in a chair that doesn't belong to you is NOT a legitimate reason for terminating the game! There were a few bugs that occurred later due to the lag of flag clears. Very disappointing
column6:
because these mistakes sometimes render the game unbeatable unless you find out what the flags are and set them yourself (not that I'm that crazy or anything)...
The author seemed to be very antipathetic in regards to cheating. Often times when you completed a puzzle a message would say something along the lines of "HOORAaaaaaY! You Got OUT of tHe Building! BUT You DIDN'T CHEAT did you?!" And in one instance a passage was blocked by an object never to be removed. Curious
column7: I ZAPped it and entered. I came to a place called "h e double hockey sticks" and was forced to answer seven absurdly difficult questions in order to continue the game. After answering and going through the passage
column8: I found myself in a resetting invisible maze
column9: with the exit an invisible passage. I'm not sure why I was so determined
column10: but I traversed it while looking at the path in kevedit. That passage took me back into the game
column11:
but far into the past.
The game had some decent puzzles
column12:
but some of them weren't coded properly and unsolvable. =( The ones that were solvable were clever and challenging.

GRAPHICS: Mostly big
column13: ugly
column14:
non-stk boards. Definitely the bare minimum.

SOUND: There were a few short music blips but they were just a few repetitive notes.

CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE: Annoying and sterile. The fellow squad members included a tree-hugger
column15: disco maniac
column16:
and a loser. Hearing them talk was frustrating and pointless.

FINAL WORD: Again
column17: this is an average

column2:
maybe beyond - nearly two thousand games in all. Of those I have selected just 66 to be included in my list of "best ZZT games ever."

While I am not a fan of drawn-out adventures that have big square rooms and enemies that quickly get boring (A Dwarvish Mead Dream
column3: case in point) there was something special about the way this game played out.  The attention payed to developing the storyline was nicer than it should have been - the entire game utilizes only one cutscene
column4: and so you are the actor in the development of the story; your actions determine how it comes about.  I salute master raze: I can't remember if this is the only game of his i have in my list
column5: but i give a nod to everything he's done.  peace."☃"1150414821"☃"amtrealiate.zip"☃"4.5"☃"74.132.233.81"

column1: Best ZZT Games ever reviews: ANDYSPEC.ZZT☃"wil"☃"masterwil@gmail.com"☃"I recently played all the ZZT games made from 1991 to at least the end of 2003
column2:
maybe beyond - nearly two thousand games in all. Of those I have selected just 66 to be included in my list of "best ZZT games ever."

There are a whole genre of ZZT adventures where you break things and/or hurt people when you touch them
column3: grab the porn stash in your closet along with your gun
column4: and go through a series of adventures in which you do various infantile things.  The magical Adventures of Andy is the finest example in this genre."☃"1150415465"☃"andyspec.zip"☃"5"☃"74.132.233.81"

column1: Best ZZT Games ever reviews: ASSASSIN.ZZT☃"wil"☃"masterwil@gmail.com"☃"I recently played all the ZZT games made from 1991 to at least the end of 2003
column2: maybe beyond - nearly two thousand games in all. Of those I have selected just 66 to be included in my list of "best ZZT games ever."  The sequel adds nothing to my review here
column3:
and is not included in the list.

To sum up ASSASSIN
column4:
because by itself it is not worth playing except as an object lesson:

On every board
column5: you defeat some enemies.  Having defeated them
column6: you approach the black knight
column7: who first insults you
column8: then disappears.  Not every game should follow a formula
column9:
but certainly more games should.

A formula gives a game a heartbeat. It pushes life through the game
column10: but it is not what makes the game alive.  You can give a heartbeat to an imbecile or a boring man and he still will not entertain you
column11: but a game is always on the verge of disaster without some kind of recognizable repetition to keep the player grounded."☃"1150416069"☃"assassin.zip"☃"1"☃"74.132.233.81"

column1: Best ZZT Games ever reviews: BOBSLUG.ZZT☃"wil"☃"masterwil@gmail.com"☃"I recently played all the ZZT games made from 1991 to at least the end of 2003
column2:
maybe beyond - nearly two thousand games in all. Of those I have selected just 66 to be included in my list of "best ZZT games ever."


I didn't realize it until just now
column3: but two of AOL-era ZZTer Andrew Wagster's games made it to my list!  Niether of them were very good
column4:
but they both illustrated some point particularly well.

BOB THE SLUG not only sounds like:

a) a euphemism for oral sex
b) some kind of hazing ritual
c) some kind of hazing ritual involving oral sex

but it's also a ZZT game! While not a great game
column5: in fact a very bad game
column6: there is something it DOESN'T do that we see in games all too often: In your standard ZZT adventure
column7: you are "The Player".  This is bullshit.  ZZT isn't well suited to self-insertion because there's no way for the players to input their own name.  Make the player be a character
column8: like
column9: for example
column10: a slug named Bob.  Make the character have some reason why he is the man for the job
column11: like
column12: for example
column13: being the only slug stupid enough to enter the salt mines and stop an evil wizard from raising an army of saltmen to conquer slugkind.  Make sure that this is reinforced throughout the game or people will lose their anchoring to the reason they are playing.  The ZZT format does not have the subtlety required to eliminate the Puritan work ethic of standard gaming.  To keep your player playing
column14: tie the character the player plays deeply into the story and the interactions of the game.  This game is beautifully tied into this ethos
column15: and deserves mention for it."☃"1150417261"☃"bobslug.zip"☃"3"☃"74.132.233.81"

column1: An unbiased review od this game.☃"Incognito"☃☃"Ignore the comment above. It was posted by my brother

column3:

column4: and the title screen has good art (albeit being in Japanese). The actual game
column5: however
column6:
is lacking.

Firstly
column7: the author used gems to represent rings
column8: which just looks so totally wrong in a Sonic-style game. In addition
column9: most enemies are just built-in ones from ZZT itself
column10: and the only use of objects is to represent other characters. There is also a coding issue in one part
column11: where you do not lose rings despite paying some to one of the characters
column12: However
column13: the gameplay is very good! Being a demo
column14: the game is short
column15: so it doesn't get annoying
column16: and I have to say that
column17: despite all it's quirks
column18:
it's rather entertaining.

But I need to give it a rating
column19:
so here I go:

5 points to start.
-0.5 for a coding issue.
-2 for use of ZZT's built-in enemies and items
column20:
with little use of coded objects.
+0.5 for how entertaining I find it

and because it is a demo.

Needs More...☃"Shadow"☃"mynewboots1999@yahoo.ca"☃"I know this is just a demo but even then its missing some things...

First of all - The enemies could be a little more enthusiastic. When I walk into an area one person says "Look out!" And then they move lethargecly after me. A few of them even shot other officers. Instead of say many officers like this I'd rather like to see 2 or 3 officers who are fast and shoot lots at you. Maybe they shooting them only makes them angrier? Maybe it takes 2 shots to kill them? (The zap function is great for minor bosses or slightly stronger enemies!) And when they run from you try and have them run towards the exit or something. And not just away from you as they can (and often did) get stuck in corners.

Next
column2:
keep instant deaths to a minimum as nobody likes these. Having trees that kill you when you pick the wrong option is not fun at all. Maybe you could have instead it hurt you or something instead of kill you.

Thirdly
column3:
the text is somewhat unimaginative. I liked the begining a fair bit and the one cinimatic sequence a bit less but it otherwise seemed rather dull. Maybe while your shooting them they're could be talking going on like

Guard 1: Men! Pull your guns out!
Guard 2: Stun I presume?
Guard 1: Not on my life your not! Kill...

or

Guard 1: Holy crap! Its radio active!
Guard 1: Kill it! Kill it!
You: You mean the guards?
Guard 2: No... Except for guard 1 maybe.
Guard 1: No! No! Kill guard 2!
You: Your confusing me. Which one do I kill?
Guard 3: Aww what the hell. Kill them both.
You: Maybe you'd like to join them?
And the fight presumes...

Something like that. And one more thing. Please use proper spelling and punctuation. I know its probably your first published game and stuff but if you learn it now it saves your reputation somewhere on down the line.

And one more thing: Some of the grafics where nice. I like the one where you go south of the crossroads and you see the 2 buildings. But the other screens need improvment.

Anyways

I hope this helps. I'm hoping to release a demo of a game I'm making and would really look forward to hearing your review of my game. Although it still needs a few touches...

column1: damn hipsters and their god killing ways.☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"Though it's genre is RPG
column2: the first game from kev-san in a while is more of a cinema game. There are some RPG battle
column3: 4 or 5 I think
column4: which basically consists of each character having an attack that does  1 damage and always hits
column5:
or an attack that does 2 damage and sometimes misses. Other than that there is very little gameplay save from moving your characters through the world.

The majority of the game is in fact a spiritual catharsis your hipster heros undergo to escape from Hell. While it uses many religious and philosophical models for the world it creates
column6: it uses them rather freely to both poke fun at and make a point about specifically Judeo-Christian religions. The several diatribes the game forces you to digest can range from funny
column7: to poignant
column8: to just plain dumb. The intellegensia that your heros seem to represent (man I can't stand most hipsters) is sometimes distasteful. I sort of hoped they'd all die in the end (past already being dead and in hell). The three characters you lead are all pretty irritating. The religious elements that were used to make a plot were good
column9:
but often the ones that were used to make a point were dull and preachy. It seems quite simply that kev-san had a lot on his plate and needed to get it all out in one game.

Graphically the game holds its own. There is a wide range of colours used appropriately
column10:
and some boards make the game look like it would fit well into the trippy genre. The battle scenes are a little bland and only lightly animated.

The music is quite good. It's used frequently and almost on every board. It doesn't get repetitive and actually helps make the game feel like a complete experience.

The story (what you can cull from below all the hubbub) is pretty good actually
column11: and the writing
column12: while pendantic in most places
column13: it very well done. It some of it was not tongue in cheek
column14:
it might have become unbearable.

My only personal gripe is that there was the tree of life

column16:
but no evangelion. (omg teh rei)

This game could have been a lot bigger I think
column17: with more "game"
column18:
had kev shortened up on the words.

Still
column19: this is a fine release
column20:
and I don't think I would have typed as much as I did if it didn't do something for me. So...

column1: a winning formula☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"there is a unresolved argument in the ZZT community about the quality of the original games as made by Tim Sweeny. Similarly there are two types of ZZT games
column2: ones where everthing is what it is supposed to be
column3:
and ones where everthing is what the designer wants it to be. This game is a stunning example of the first.

On your mark
column4: get set
column5:
go get some purple keys.

This is the third game this author has made in the classic style. Then he went under the name Wong Chung Bang.

Like the previous games
column6: Castle of ZZT captures much of the feel of the originals. There has been a lot of progression over the three games
column7:
in all areas. The text is very limited and not distracting. It's appropriately light and humourous when it does appear.

Graphically the game takes a harder line than it'd predecessors. It has more of its own style than the previous games in his series. There more attention paid to patterns: with walls made from fades
column8:
to checkerboards. Colour is used appropriately to create unique atmospheres for each seperate.

Now the game itself. The castle is immedietly imposing in it's size when you begin and start to poke around the fringes of the main area. Monster scare you away from certain areas
column9: imposing puzzles in others. Mysterious areas you can see but not reach are everywhere. You'll soon discover that this place
column10: this game
column11:
is BIG. You'll think you'll never see a purple key until you're halfway through the game. You'll be almost right.

Shooting things is of course a must. The game makes use of different coloured monsters to represent different behaviour. (Blue ruffians slower
column12: dumber than purple ones.) Monsters are not overused and are placed rather tactically
column13: like tigers who jump you through a breakable wall when their shooting direction changes. Ammo and health was in abundance
column14:
but at a good balance.

Puzzles were a mix between old classics (three lakes) to newer and more clever ones. One of the best consisted of blocks that rotated around richochets upon being touched. And another
column15: the opening of the vault. In all the varity of puzzles was refreshing and the way in which they were presented made them even better. I admit I got frustrated to the point of zapping only once. Remember
column16:
save often.

As of late there have been three oldbies with returns to the ring
column17:
with three good releases. This alone qualifies this year in zzting as perhaps better than the last. Get it while it's hot.

column1:
"Millions May Object: Really Perfect Game?&qu☃"Jappy"☃"j.frederickson@hotmail.co.jp"☃"Time for Trouble (and make it double!)

Looking back
column2: it seems impossible for anyone to predict the amount of controversy
column3: delays
column4: and drama associated with Nipple Saga (hereafter ‘NipSaga')
column5: especially given it's status as Ryokarrde's flagship gaming series for well over a decade. First announced at the Bigger Nigger Corporation Conference along with Nipple
column6: and Nipple Zwei
column7: it would be another few years before the public actually saw anything specific
column8: at a special event held in England's Strood Hills. With all the major project players at hand
column9: it seemed as if a release would be pending shortly thereafter. E3 1978 hit and attendees got a chance to play a demo build. After a controversial reception given the dramatic change in combat gameplay
column10: the phallic giant went silent and the world could only guess as to the fate of this constantly belated title. Then things got even worse: Snazin Smith
column11: the “brother” of Nipple Saga
column12: left Bigger Niggers to form his own company
column13: taking his saucy trumpet (the “composer” of Nipple) with him. Hope sank to new lows when gamers learned that the project director
column14: Camera J
column15:
resigned for sodomy related reasons.

Just when an all-out cancellation seemed the next logical announcement
column16: July 2003 arrived and with it
column17: the Bigger Niggers Party. It was at this pivotal convention that the RPG giant unleashed a gauntlet of good news: NipSaga was not cancelled but instead
column18: pending release immediately; NipSaga had a theme song (now a pre-requisite for the series)
column19: NipSaga had received a new director
column20:
and NipSaga had matured in design over the years. Those in attendance were able to play a brand new demo which North American gamers would later received (slightly edited) bundled as a promotional item along with Plunger SE in November. It was fever pitch and now only a matter of time before the inevitable: the day Nipple Saga would finally release and end the litany of setbacks associated with it once and for all.

In the weeks leading up to “D-Day”
column21: NipSaga received some impressive acclaim
column22: such as a rare perfect score by the Japanese gaming publication
column23: Weekly Faggotsu. While the magazine's reviews were as emaciated as ever (offering no real whatsoever into the score)
column24: it was quite clear that something was aloof for this radically altered Nipple to earn such a coveted tally. With the game receiving high marks from competing periodicals as well
column25:
it was obvious that NipSaga was a force to be reckoned with.

The Ideal

During the development process of Nipple
column26: Bigger Niggers employees made it known that they wished to do away with random battles
column27: a de-facto “staple” of most every RPG and perhaps-to many gamers-the single most aggravating element of play. While the bastard Nipple Zwei managed to forgo the invisible encounters
column28: it seemed unrealistic that ZZT could ever handle a game as multimedia mad as a Nipple Saga and have enough power to process monsters in real time. Yet amazingly
column29: NipSaga features just that: it is by far the most beautiful game in the entire series with stunning graphics
column30: state-of-the-art CG movies
column31: loads of voice acting and cut scenes
column32: a lengthy quest
column33:
and yet…no random encounters.

Combat Crisis

As mentioned earlier
column34: if there could be one single element of NipSaga's design that has provoked the greatest controversy
column35: it would be the combat engine. Essentially a simplified version of the “hands off/AI-based” fighting in MMORPGs (like FLYFF)
column36: many players found it impossible to accept a game system that refused to include a structured
column37: turn-based system of input. In a sense
column38: you are truly a “guide” for character input during battle
column39: with the computer handling all of the actual attacking
column40: defending
column41: and
column42: if the opponent's proximity is close enough
column43: movement as well. As revolting as this idea might sound to some
column44: consider that previous Nipple installments offered the exact same properties
column45: if not even more restricted; aside from choosing options from a menu and confirming
column46:
the computer always controlled everything else-nobody should be kidding themselves into thinking that they ever had total control over anything.

Battle Basics

While wandering around in a field or dungeon
column47: you will see monsters. To initiate combat
column48: push the “Space Bar” to shoot in the direction of the target(s). Watch as a bullet line draws itself and connects with the selected foe. Use of items and magic occurs in the same fashion. An important element to note is that in Active Mode-the ideal play experience-all of this occurs in real time which means that monsters can-and will-attack you while mulling over what to do. If your have the AI set
column49:
party members will automatically attack according to the pre-set "instructions" when their bullets hit.

If things get too tough (and they will)
column50: it is possible to flee from battle
column51: however given the nature of combat
column52: that hardly means you are off the hook. As FLYFF players may know all too well
column53: enraged monsters will trail after your party hoping to slay whomever they can before you run out of their reach. While opponents that deal melee attacks prove less of a problem
column54:
those with long range and/or magical capabilities can quite easily defeat a party in crisis even when things seem safe. The best advice is to plan adequately for fights: avoid battles in heavily concentrated enemy territory if your party is low on health and/or restorative items. Don't bite off more than you can chew as jews are not all of the same level of difficulty even if they are all in the same area.

Lust for Licenses and a Chaste Challenge

With each new Nipple comes a new gameplay gimmick that serves to mix things up and prevent the adventure from feeling too close to the previous. NipSaga introduces the License Point system
column55: an innovative skill building service that combines elements of Nipple's item-based character growth and Nipple Zwei's popular Date Rape Board. While characters level up in a traditional manner (via Experience Points earned from defeating monsters)
column56: they also receive Rape Points which are used to “purchase” new abilities
column60: (etc) from a sub-screen of the main menu. Different abilities have different point requirements
column61: meaning that players will find themselves stalking monsters at all hours in an attempt to create the ideal character. Because of the fluid combat however
column62: this is far less of a hassle than were gamers forced to deal with constant combat loading and a systematic input selection process. Even better
column63: this system allows for incredible customization as players can build the character they wish to without worrying about a pre-determined “path” like so many other games opt for. Tied into this process is the dynamic of “unlocking” the ability to use more powerful equipment
column64: thus ensuring that you can not simply horde gems (they give you health!)
column65:
waltz into a shop and leave with high power offensive gear that all but eliminates any and all challenge to be had.

And what a challenge there is…many gamers have no doubt lamented over the exponentially decreasing difficulty in this genre as time passes. Whereas they use to be just plain unforgiving in the earlier day of gaming
column66: in 2006 it is not uncommon to play through an entire RPG without facing obliteration even once. This absence of difficulty all but ensures that players rarely-if ever-need to plan ahead
column67: or need to think period. Just plow through each area until reaching the next one. Obviously the manner in which equipment upgrades worked heavily factored into this matter. NipSaga on the other hand
column68: is hardly something you can breeze through. While not as bad as an MMORPG
column69:
even Leveling Up your character takes a lot of time; do not expect to jump from Level 2 to Level 10 in a span of a few meager hours. You must work for your payoffs and that adds a tremendous sense of accomplishment in the end.

Those gamers sick and tired of pathetic boss monsters that offer little to no challenge whatsoever will be absolutely thrilled to know that NipSaga is a real piece of work. Bosses can do so much
column70: really: deal incredible amounts of damage
column71: use special attacks that all but obliterate your party
column72: at times even call reinforcements all while possessing a startling amount of Hit Points ensuring that even bouts of “power leveling” may prove useless. Instead of regulating the difficulty to far-off hidden bosses that only the most adamant players ever see
column73:
Bigger Niggers opted to make each and every major opponent a fight-something that could not be more welcome in a game like this. Suffice to say that players will be facing major setbacks in progress if they don't adequately set up their buns.

Town Traveler and Dreamy Dungeons

With the exception of Nipple's lost city of Kowloon or Fort Boyard
column74: nothing much can prepare one for the impressive size and scope of the town environments in NipSaga. Spanning multiple screens and simply sprawling
column75: it is possible to spend hours talking with all the various NPCs littered about
column78: or simply marveling at how amazing the view is. When approaching a NPC whom you can speak with
column79: a small “happy face” icon appears along with the character's name. During longer conversation
column80: an option to view a “Log” appears
column81: allowing you to scroll back to earlier points in the discourse should you wish to recount important details. So large
column83:
and complex are the environments that they must actually be broken up into segments for ZZT to handle such a load.

While NipSaga takes place in its established world
column85: races and overall settings in true 2-D is an experience like no other. So many competing game companies have tried relentlessly to create this kind of virtual world yet
column87:
it seems impossible to list any that achieved this kind of success. At times you may question just how Bigger Niggers managed to pull off such feats in hardware that the industry claims is outdated and ancient.

Dungeons are simply magnificent: there is no other way to put it. Time and time again game companies craft boring looking environments with little-to-no excitement in them
column88: however every area in NipSaga is not only marvelous to look at
column89: but entertaining to explore. Many players will be shocked by the sheer size of these locations as well
column90: for they span multiple screens and can take quite some time to explore. While field locations tend to be more simplistic
column91: the actual dungeons themselves are ornate looking regions with an astonishing sense of grandeur
column93: and scope. In a very real sense
column94:
it is like ZZT SPORTS or Strood Fireworks Display but even more epic.

Clan Conquest

Those familiar with MMORPGs may already be familiar with the idea of undertaking missions/quests for rewards
column96: or helping out your clan to improve its reputation. (Additionally
column97: those familiar with Nipple will also find familiarity
column98: as well as a certain Bigelow). NipSaga features a much more open-ended vision of progression such that the player is frequently given the opportunity to undertake side-stories and quests that have little to nothing to do with the main story
column99: but which yield major benefits. Additionally
column100: as you progress throughout the game
column101: the party earns Clan Points which can be redeemed for rewards of increasing value
column102:
as well as a prominent reputation.

While the prospect of monster hunting might not be appealing to everyone
column103: the game does not always force you to partake on these extravagant search-and-destroy ventures. Players who wish to plow through the game and see little the world of Nipple has to offer can more or less do so
column104: however given the challenge at hand
column105: it is most certainly better to find “excuses” to engage in combat. The idea of working for a larger team definitely brings some of the MMORPG feel along for the ride
column107:
those gamers who dislike multiplayer experiences can feel comforted in knowing that it's all you.

Musical Madness

For those who felt that the long standing series composer
column109: could make of break a Nipple Saga game
column110: you may be surprised to learn that NipSaga fares quite well with the “meager” offerings of the gifted Dir En Grey. Very well indeed. With the Land Catz series under his belt
column111: as well as the now-classic ZZT game Electric Booby Boy
column112: Dir En Grey serves up musical melodies that work perfectly with the game's settings and environments. Perhaps more importantly however
column113: they serve to totally distance NipSaga from its ancestors with compositions that are truly original and which do not rehash key pieces of music from earlier ones; this is a totally original score that works perfectly with a totally altered game. Each track has such sophistication
column115:
such filth-hi to it; sometimes it's amazing that anyone could actually create such perfection.

Additionally
column116: voice acting is equally resplendent. Whereas so many other games adhere to immature
column118: NipSaga seems to elevate itself far above such nonsense with mature
column119:
utilizing Mew's 3D Talk Engine.

A Crisis of Character

Given the combat “woes”
column120: many skeptics immediately lodged charges that NipSaga would feature severely diminished character interaction
column122: and a de-centralised plot. The prospect of undertaking Missions as opposed to following a linear progression of events served to entrench this belief even further. Lo and behold
column124: the powers that be recognized that NipSaga is most certainly an offline game
column125: and even more importantly-a Nipple installment. No corners were cut at all and in fact
column127:
the character development and story arcs have never been as epic and rewarding.

While each of the game's main characters could easily be found in dozens of other games and settings
column128: Bigger Niggers managed to imbue them with a sense of life and tenacity that is a rare find in gaming. Aiding the writing brilliance are some of the most impressive character models seen to date-on any console. The protagonist
column131:
looks like a pilcrow yet still realistic enough to fit appropriately in the highly stylized and heavily detailed environments. It goes without saying that the “fill/autofade mode” graphical presentation used to smooth out what might otherwise be jagged polygons does some major justice to this game-it is almost tantamount to a modified version of Bigger Niggers's Bathroom SE yet presented in total package (as opposed to said game which used the toilet to tell the story).

Additionally
column132: despite the absence of Camera J (the man responsible for frightful school horrors) the artwork is positively fantastic. Featuring a more Spacecowboy-looking cast (and setting) compared to the more Businessman assortment seen in Nipple
column133: these characters are truly some of the most striking bunch in gaming. From the innocent bad-boy looks of Doktor von Bagstein to the sweet charm of Prudence to the questionable intentions of VBIRDS
column134: each of the game's central cast members is littered with detail
column136:
and attention.

War and Peace

Without giving away any specific details
column137: the story of NipSaga is truly an epic tale filled with deceit
column142: and magic. By far the most mature installment in the series
column143: the game opens with a cinema tour de force showcasing a hostile takeover
column145: and a mystery. As in real life
column146: there is much at hand when one nation decides to take over another by force; when countries are at war with one another. Somewhere in the middle of this prolonged crisis
column147: this state of eternal conflict is Nippleanus
column148: a dapper farmer in training who wishes for nothing more than to harvest dirt. Little does he know that his dream will become a reality
column149: and that his actions may very well shape history itself. Then there are the menacing VBIRDS
column152:
and prominence…the end result is a total package like no other.

Some gamers expressed concern over the prospect of party members joining so close to the game's start
column153: and gaining access to an airship so quickly; previous Nipple installments saw a staggered party membership system and no airships at all. These individuals need not fret however
column154: because although things are somewhat different than the “norm”
column155: they work wonderfully. Because NipSaga does not suffer from the “tunnel” linearity syndrome that plagued Nipple
column156: you simply must have an airship to travel to-and-from the expansive regions. In terms of story bonuses
column157: consider that having access to most every party member from the first few hours means more opportunities for character development and plot-something that has never held true for “last minute” party additions thrown in near a game's climax. Rest assured
column159: that there will be many surprises in store
column160: as NPCs can and will join your party as “Gay Characters”
column161:
ensuring that the line up remains diverse throughout the adventure.

Those gamers worried that Bigger Niggers let too much out of the bag with their PR blitzkrieg can also rest easy as-like always-their “scenario outlook” is just that-a glossing over the setting of the events that take place prior to the game's start (or immediately after) leaving out basically everything that occurs next. While it would be difficult to claim veteran RPG addicts will find anything revolutionary or astonishing about the events in NipSaga
column162:
suffice to say that this is truly a story of amazing quality and quantity which may very well be the best tale ever told in a Nipple Saga game.

Price for Perfection and Critical Controversy

As with any game
column165: can be quite unbalanced with high level monsters cruising in immediate proximity to those of weak capabilities. Cities
column167: can sometimes be a hassle to navigate through in light of loading times and size. The fact that the game's full-scale area map (accessed by pressing “Select”) always lists the goal location totally defeats any element of player exploration if viewed. Related to this
column168: many of the dungeons and environments are somewhat repetitive and consist of unrealistic paths and spaces that feel less like a natural landscape and more like a constricted location designed specifically for a videogame. Finally
column169: at times the game can get repetitive with generic fetch quests and errand running
column170:
the likes of which plague every RPG in existence.

Obviously depending on what one considers a fault
column171: there can be an unlimited number of additional grievances lodged against this product. Fighting may be too “hands off” for some gamers
column172: homosexual activity might seem out of place in what was once a traditional RPG series
column173: save points are few and far between
column174: the story might not be as benign as some would have hoped
column176:
the faults and praises are totally subjective however those listed in the proceeding paragraph detail some of the more “agreed upon” issues.

It's worth paying special heed to three particular “touchy” issues however:

1. As others have complained
column177: the game offers no Auto Run ability. For those unfamiliar with haxors
column178: many of these haxx allow the player to input a simple command sequence to initiate an automatic running process so as to alleviate the tedium with manually traversing such large environments. In crowded areas (like cities) NipSaga has no real need for this
column179: but with respect to the dungeons and “overworld” locations
column180:
some might find it tiring to have to constantly control your lead character.

2. Many gamers have been outraged by the lack of a “reversible” camera control setting. While NipSaga is not the first offline Nipple game to feature a truly 2-D world with a 100% player controlled camera (if desires)
column181:
the mapping which Bigger Niggers used to facilitate this is unnatural to most people and hence cumbersome. Many expected the game to allow players to customize the movement to their desired alignment however there is no such feature.

3. The final issue of immense controversy (at least for those who don't have the game or demo) will be the manner in which you obtain Gems (they give you health). In the past
column182: Nipple games used the unrealistic “defeated monster drop” method wherein by some otherworldly means
column184: savage beasts would apparently be in possession of stockpiles of money on their person. In NipSaga however
column185: you obtain only fun points by defeating opponents; Gems (they give you health!) must be obtained from other means (such as completing side-quests
column187: or finding it in treasure boxes). While this may seem fresh
column188:
there are times when the issue will boil down to sheer repetition and may become annoying as players search for rare and valuable items just to buy an item less they manage to undertake a Clan Mission that happens to pay off in money.

Manifest Destiny

Given the endless development process
column189: it would seem logical that NipSaga would either be absolutely enthralling or else a major disaster. Fortunately
column190: the former is most certainly the case and everyone benefits. Many wonder how NipSaga can possibly feel like a Nipple game when it seems so different. The answer
column192: is that it doesn't. Nipple Saga is so unique and inspired that it's in a universe of its own. Were this a stand alone entry in a brand new series
column193:
it would be reasonable to assume Bigger Niggers would have a major contender for a long running franchise. Put aside concerns about the gameplay “disaster” and realize that this is a dedicated single-player experience offered by a company that knows damn well how to make single-player RPGs. You can expect the world of a Nipple game and should assume no less of NipSaga.

Although the radical change in design elements and gameplay concepts may not please everyone
column194: there is little denying their polish and refinement…or their potential for fun. The best manner to approach NipSaga is with an open mind
column195: with an appreciation for the hard work of some very talented individuals
column196: and for a company that-despite falling from gaming “perfection” in recent years-still holds true to its laurels where things really count. If one considers “Nipple” to mean nothing more than a prehistoric combat system with state-of-the-art visuals
column198: this game may loose face. If one considers “Nipple” to be a name synonymous with fantastic storytelling
column203: then “yes”: This sure as hell is Nipple Saga."☃"1177682779"☃"Nipsaga.zip"☃"5"☃"172.189.138.80"

column1: A creative game.☃"JohnWWells"☃"kokolhe1@yahoo.com"☃"(Spoilers ahead
column2:
but I reveal no more than the previous review did.)

When I am told that a game is "creative
column3: " I worry. Usually this means "awful." ZZT
column4: in particular
column5:
has given us lots of stupid-creative games.

The premise of "Sugartits" - play as a drunken Mel Gibson! - looked stupid-creative
column6: but gingermuffins' Weekend of ZZT entry was good
column7:
so I gave it a shot. I'm glad I did. This game is funny and exciting and sometimes even smart-creative.

The game wades deep into stupid-creative territory
column8: with bizarre time travel and vomit
column9: but is rarely stupid. Stupid-creative humor assumes that time machines and vomit are so inherently funny that actual comedy is unnecessary. gingermuffins knows that you have to WORK to tell a good vomit joke
column10: and he does. Like everything else in the game
column11: the vomit joke is neatly executed and
column12: as far as I could tell
column13:
bug-free.

The Hell sequences are
column14: likewise
column15: clever. Stupid-creative treatments of Hell are common
column16: but gingermuffins takes the "LOL WE HAZ GUD TIEM IN HELL" jokes in an unusual direction. Like many good comedies
column17:
this game has an undercurrent of compassion. Hell is not inherently funny - it's a horrific invention - but the fear of Hell can be very funny.

I think that the game works partly because the engines are fun and replete with small details
column18: like the whizzing background of the driving scene. It doesn't hurt that the final scene is kind of exciting. But the real coup here is the performance of gingermuffins' version of Mel Gibson. By the end of the game
column19: Mel becomes a weirdly sympathetic character. Yes
column20: he's drunk
column21: anti-Semitic
column22: presumptuous
column23: loud
column24: fanatical
column25: and insanely quixotic. But he's got his reasons
column26: even if they are incredibly stupid. He really tries
column27: y'know? And that makes him fun to play as
column28:
in a way that would be impossible for a more self-conscious PC. It's also responsible for the game's funniest line.

If there's any life left in ZZT
column29: this game ought to spawn imitators. It's smarter than it has to be and consistently fun
column30: and this shows real craft on the part of its designer. There are weaknesses - the RPG segment seemed a little unbalanced
column31: and could have used a few more bosses
column32: and it would have been cool if the control scheme for the driving sequence had been a little wobbly and the cars on the other side of the freeway were visible - but they're minor. This is a very good game. "☃"1187051944"☃"SUGART.zip"☃"5"☃"128.12.137.240"

column1: Just an ordinary well.☃"gingermuffins"☃"gingermuffins@yahoo.ca"☃"This game is essentially a showpiece for a reusable RPG fighting engine. I'm pretty sure I've seen one of these in another ZZT game before
column2:
but this is definitely the best ZZT fighting engine I've seen.

Commodore has added a significant amount of variation to the engine: two characters with a handful of commands
column3: health that is stored in counters
column4: a diminishing food supply
column5: magic spells
column6: upgradeable equipment
column7: and level accumulation
column8: all spread across multiple dungeon areas and several hundreds of randomised fights. It actually feels like you're playing an RPG
column9:
and not just an interactive story with some staple fights thrown in for good measure; that's pretty hard to do in ZZT.

The art
column10: #change cycles and music are all good -- I especially like the title screen and the snowy town. Enemies are drawn with objects and look pretty fly. Most dungeons have a "fork in the road" mentality
column11: with one route being a shortcut and the other being longer and having a treasure chest. One section that made me laugh was crawling down a long hallway to get a treasure chest
column12:
only to receive the same amount of food it takes to travel there and back.

The biggest snag in the game is that if you're not lucky
column13: you will be doing a lot of restoring old files after you die. Even if you are lucky
column14:
you will still be doing a lot of restoring. But once you get to a reasonable level this becomes less of a problem and you can focus on simple strategies for keeping the characters alive.

I think this is a pretty cool addition to the archive
column15: and it deserves a small review at the very least."☃"1190118072"☃"Solarwar.zip"☃"5"☃"88.111.128.217"

column1: get away from me OLD MAN.☃"gingermuffins"☃"gingermuffins@yahoo.ca"☃"I found this game several months ago via random search
column2: and then I promptly deleted it. Afterwards
column3: I decided I wanted to look at it again
column4: but I couldn't quite remember what the game was called. This bugged me for months
column5: and I couldn't locate it on the archive. You'd think that searching for war
column6: battle
column7: fight
column8: army
column9: blind
column10: anything like that would bring it up. But no
column11:
it's called Visual Height.

This is what it's about: a blind war veteran named Frank Herbert mulls around town
column12: unappreciated by its two inhabitants CON MAN and GROCERY MAN. He sits down by the grave of a fallen comrade
column13:
and then enters a flashback. The game ends there.

The strange use of grammar and the blobby art style of the main character's portrait make me firmly believe that if this game had been finished
column14:
every last bit of it would have been as strangely enchanted as the demo itself.

This is not a good game
column15: but like a bad pop song that gets stuck in your head
column16: the premise is somehow memorable. I'll bet in five years I'll think of this game again and not remember what the hell it was called."☃"1193360414"☃"visuald.zip"☃"2"☃"156.34.206.69"

column1:

and recurring characters. It's fun!

But they aren't without their problems. Most caves are too big and confusing

but they're still annoying.

column1: ☃"OMG"☃☃"Wow
column2: a masterpiece of game design. Even if the FMV-like intro would hint toward a linear story-based game with little to no interaction
column3: Coolart actually manages to deliver a full-fledged RPG. Choices and consequences
column4: stats
column5: tens of non-linear quests: fans of big and overwhelmingly complex games
column6: rejoice! Coolart actually manages to improve its visual aspect too: some of the best graphical effects i've ever seen for a ZZT game: an animated waterfall
column7: fully animated death scenes
column8: a trial you can take part in to try to defend yourself
column9: all in pure ASCII goodness! Now you're probably asking yourself if Coolart is too difficult to be played by the average not-so-used-to-RPG player? Indeed
column10: the game might be daunting at first
column11: but its beauty is also its flexibility: it can be played as a linear choose-your-own-adventure game or a choice-responsive RPG where NPCs are actually influenced by your dialogue choices and actions. There are context-sensitive sidequests
column12: a day and night system which affect what the other characters are doing
column13: not to mention the beautiful hunger and thirst system which add a touch of realism and more interactivity. This game use an incredibly complex compression algorythm which allowed the author to include some MBs of stuff into some dozens of KBs. Yeah
column14: this might as well be one of the biggest games in ZZT history. And among the best ones too."☃"1195928826"☃"COOLART.zip"☃"5"☃"87.11.83.67"

Hercules

column1:
Good☃"Dongle"☃"rumblefish@aol.com"☃"I am glad to announce that this game is way better than the previous game I reviewed (Indigo Sprite's Inn-Turns 1-4). Nipple Saga contains a little bit of everything. It's at least got a story and multiple pics and endings. This game is by far more mature than Aigan.

Story: 10/10
The games story starts when YOU the main character
column2: Nippleanus
column3:
goes into a town for a vacation. During the Vacation wild things started to happen and from it you find the person that you loved for soo long. Its basically an EVERYOTHER man's DREAM. The creator didn't add anything unsual to this game. It follows that flot pretty good.

Game Console: 10/10
Although ZZT is cheaply made
column4:
I have to agree that the coder actually put some thoughts in it. The choices that you make in-game doesn't affect much of the CGs and ENDINGS that you will get. Usually ONLY 1 CHOICE will work and the rest just kicks u back to the same question. Feel free to randomly pick cause it will not ruin the fun.

Graphics: 7/10
The graphics for this game is the only part that I have to complain about. The artist who did the characters didn't have a great skill in drawing eyes. They lack alot of work. The coloring wasn't done with alot of care either. But the artist has a pretty good talent in drawing hands. There is plenty of Z going on the game. You will end up sleeping with everyone you know and thats FOR SURE. But the imperfect graphics kind of blows.

Sound: 10/10
The Music track that came with the game is pretty scary
column5:
I recommend all thoes who play this game to listen to the songs (FILTH HI!). I was hoping for some type of easy romantic ending but instead i got freaked and ran CTL-DEL-ALT my comp!

Overall: 10/10
I would say if you just want an easy Z game this one is the one to get. But keep in mind this game has an average number of pictures with below average looks. Recommended to all those who have too much cash. Help the creators please!

column4: the Game mode

column1: The Grandfather of Horror ZZT☃"TDP"☃"tdp@yahoo.co.jp"☃"Lately
column2: there is a fad on horror ZZT games. (For example
column3: Don't Get Cornholed
column4: Stupid RPG
column5: and Plunger SE.) The game Nipple Saga is perhaps one of the founders of this genre since it is the first horror ZZT game I have played. Aside from its genre
column6: Nipple Saga is produced by The Bigger Niggers Corporation
column7: a company known for the excellence of their games. And as with most of BNC games
column8:
Nipple Saga is not a disappointment.

The story behind Nipple Saga is that you received a love letter from a mysterious person and he told you to meet at the old farm. You got very excited about this so you went early and started to wait. Soon
column9: Dr. Frank Bigelow (your best friend)
column10: Baron von Bagstein (your enemy)
column11: and V-Birds (fan service) come in. Once everyone gets in
column12: chaos ensues. Thus begins your adventure of helping the others including yourself to escape. When you tumble through the hallways of always
column13:
you learn a lot about the other people your with including some secrets that they never revealed to anyone before.

One interesting aspect of this game is that there are three different endings. The endings are depended on the course of action you take during the game. There are two good endings and one bad ending. During the game
column14: you can befriend one of Camera J's safety crew. Your success will be awarded with a good ending and each member has his own endings. The bad ending occurs when you have not properly exercised safety in the workplace
column15:
which means you have failed your mission.

Another interesting aspect are the ZZT scenes
column16: which can only be found on secret tapes. Much like Tony Dogs
column17: these are sexual scenes between V-Birds and the harassed
column18: which Bagstein apparently has taped as the V-Birds harass their victims. These tapes are all hidden in the game and can be quit difficult to find. Thus
column19:
it is possible to complete the game without any hentai scenes if you didn't find any tapes.

Graphics: 9/10 The graphics are really nice although can be sort of bizarre for the typical ZZT games. There are a few scenes where Bagstein is "playing" with another man's penis. This is the first time I have seen man-to-man action in a ZZT game.

Overall: 9/10 This is a nice game to play. However
column20: I wouldn't recommend this game if your sole interest in ZZT games are the pictures as there isn't much sexy scenes and they requires more effort than other games to find."☃"1200062419"☃"Nipsaga.zip"☃"4.5"☃"172.201.225.121"

column1: ☃☃☃"Nadir's screenshot post about Sivion made me remember that I hadn't actually completed it despite starting a few times. Generally remembering it in a good light

I took a crack at it again this evening.

Sivion has a few neat short parts
column3: but one the whole
column4:
it's a bad game.

I started off pretty quickly
column5: although it occurred to me that I just remembered all of the beginning trades and talking sequences from the times I first tried the game in 2004. What begins as an interesting quest to stock up on arrows and gems eventually becomes deadlock without cheating. It is so fucking easy to miss some necessary items and areas and yet keep bumbling on until their absence makes the game unwinnable. In one or two parts
column6: buggy objects prohibit you from finishing without zapping. Many boss objects talk to you in blue message boxes while you're shooting them
column7: which sucks because pressing shift and arrows in a message box closes it immediately. The game
column8: which is superlocked

states in the editor that it has been beta tested and has no errors. >:(

Besides the obvious stuff

column13: and that afterwards you'll never be able to get it again. Most conversations are displayed as flashy marquee text at the bottom of the screen
column14: and two conversations have a tendency to overlap
column15: making both unreadable. (Best example of this being the prison.) Every forest area is a ping-pong path maze begging to be zapped through. Most bosses
column16: when shot
column17: wait for one idle before zapping labels
column18:
meaning you can hammer a boss with most of your bullets and only deal one hit.

The game feels like it's split into two bits: the first area which is generally crappier but more interesting
column19:
and the second area which has somewhat tighter programming but less going on.

I do like some bits in Sivion
column20: like the glinting
column21: shiny gold in the mines
column22: and the torture room. I also like how if you revisit the forum a new band will be playing. And the djinn store
column23: that part is great. But god damn if it isn't one of the most tedious ZZT games I have ever played."☃"1211767918"☃"sivion.zip"☃"3"☃"142.167.31.25"
