column1: An awe-inspiring synthesis of dramatic storytellin☃"Gamer Dude 99"☃"gamerdude99@aol.com"☃"Nipple Saga is the most technically stunning ZZT game ever made. It's also a fine example of storytelling prowess within its medium
column2: combining gameplay and narrative so slickly and beautifully that it's impossible to extricate one from the other. It's likely you will emerge awestruck from your first play-through
column3: wishing the experience would continue yet nonetheless satisfied with its conclusion. It's difficult not to sound hyperbolic when discussing NS because every part of its design seemingly fulfills its vision
column4:
without compromise. There is no halfway.

Fully realized
column5: lengthy story sequences will come as no surprise to anyone who has played a Nipple game. You'll spend a good half of NS watching cinematics
column6: but it would be a grave misinterpretation to assume that great gameplay takes a backseat to the story. Rather
column7: these two elements are tightly intertwined
column8: and this tapestry is held together by an important technical thread: Cutscenes that are rendered fully in real time within the game engine. It's impressive enough that these scenes look as good as any ZZT cinematic you've ever watched. It's even more amazing when those same scenes transition without pause into gameplay
column9: and the same Robo Doctor you watched lumber about in the cinematic is looming above you. The subtle animations
column10: the lush environments
column11: and the rich textures are the same in and out of story sequences
column12: and the effect is so seamless it may take your breath away. You can ?ZAP past the scenes if you prefer
column13:
but doing so would soften the experience. The story sequences carry more weight because of the intense gameplay that precedes them--and the gameplay feels more compelling because the story gives you powerful reasons to care about your mission. The high point of this fusion occurs in an exciting and memorable split-screen sequence that simply must be experienced.

Talking about what
column14: exactly
column15: is going on in the plot in the midst of NS grand sweeping gestures is to risk spoiling each little surprise as it emerges. Nippleanus
column16: suffering from the rapid onset of aging
column17: now must cope with stiff joints in addition to the looming specter of Von Bagstein's newest plans. This is Nippleanus's final hurrah; yet as the story reaches one height after another
column18: the juxtaposition of huge set piece battles and formidable bosses with Nippleanus's deteriorating body creates tension and gravity even beyond the series' usual pretensions. Some new plot strands emerge while others get tied up
column19: and old friends (and enemies) refuse to be forgotten. You'll also bear witness to a few reunions--some bloody
column20: some teary
column21: and some legitimately shocking. Parts of it are overblown
column22: to be sure. The musical score gets heavy-handed and the voice acting and writing are frequently dogmatic
column23: so while there are plenty of subtle moments
column24: subtlety isn't really NSs strong suit. But it doesn't need to be. After all
column25: the fate of the world hangs in the balance
column26: and judging from a few silly attempts at humor that don't work
column27:
developer Bigger Niggers were wise to err on the side of melodrama.

The gameplay proper is familiar to fans
column28: but it's been cleaned up and expanded
column29: holding as many twists and surprises as the story. For starters
column30: both gunplay and close-quarters combat are more satisfying. Regarding melee
column31: the controls have been streamlined
column32: making it less cumbersome to grab an enemy VBIRD or perform a stealthy blade kill. Shooting mechanics are even more improved
column33: so much so that shooting your way out of a pickle is just as enjoyable as snacking on it. There are a huge number of weapons to play with; so many that you'll probably finish the campaign without using many of them. Yet
column34: quality wasn't sacrificed for quantity: Every weapon feels just right
column35: from your handy ZZT bullet (best when upgraded with a silencer) to the magic powers found in the RPG battles. The standard birds-eye view is fine for the most part
column36:
because you can't gaze down the sights from a first-person perspective.

Not that you don't have all the tools for completely avoiding your enemies if you choose that route. Nippleanus's got the basics covered: crawling
column37: hugging walls
column38: peeking around corners
column39: and hanging from ledges
column40: for example. Cover mechanics are tighter than ever
column41: so you can crouch and take potshots from behind cover with ease. There are also a number of important gadgets that will make your life easier in this regard. The most obvious of these is your Robodoctor suit
column42: which takes on the texture of your surroundings when you're prone or pressed against cover. Not only does this make it simpler to avoid watchful eyes
column43: but it's also a cool visual effect. Eventually
column44: you'll be able to camouflage Nippleanus's head
column45: and a few of the available camo options are bound to stir some fans' nostalgia. The Nipple Anus is your other major tool
column46: as it expands your compass into a sonic-sensitive radar and allows you to use night vision and a tactical first-person view. These are helpful gadgets indeed
column48:
like a stirring encounter in a blinding blizzard.

Other gadgets
column49: such as portable hiding places (cardboard boxes and rusty barrels) and the Robo Doctor (a stealthed robot that you can command as a scouting device)
column50: are useful to anyone who prefers the sneaky approach. Not every gadget is a welcome addition
column52: the much-ballyhooed NipPod is a neat touch
column54: you cannot have another gadget equipped
column55: so you'll quickly forget the option even exists. But aside from these nitpicks
column56: one of the things that makes the core gameplay so enjoyable is that you're rarely strapped into a single style of play. Shooting your way through requires more thought and care than you'd put into a standard action game
column57: but you never feel as though the gun mechanics are stuffed uncomfortably into a stealth game. If you'd rather sneak
column58: you never have the impression that stealth was shoehorned into a game that's meant to be played as a shooter. Sure
column59: you're Nippleanus--you're not supposed to get caught. But if you're stuck in a jam
column60: breaking stealth isn't a death sentence
column62: facing certain enemies head-on is often a heart-pounding
column63: challenging experience. The few levels that do force you into one style
column64: such as one in which you shadow your target through Kowloon City
column66:
if not quite as impactful.

You'll need to keep an eye on Nippleanus's stress levels and psyche. Though these aspects are more peripheral than health levels
column67: they fit nicely within the plot. When Nippleanus gets stressed (if he gets cold or hungry
column69: his psyche gauge starts to deplete. The lower the gauge
column70: the slower you will move and the less quickly you replenish health. Generally speaking
column71: the psyche meter is rarely a factor
column72: and should you notice Nippleanus groaning a bit more
column73: there are items like buns you can use for a pick-me-up. Should the meter get too low
column74: you won't be able to hold up your weapon or rush for cover. This doesn't happen often though
column75: and while you'll need to keep a close eye on your health for obvious reasons
column76:
you won't need to pay too much heed to psyche.

Regardless of the tactics you use
column77: the level design and enemy artificial intelligence work in tandem to create unparalleled gameplay. If you go stealth
column78: hiding in that rusty barrel isn't a perfect solution. Your foe may look at it suspiciously
column81: so don't expect to be able to trick your way through as you might in other stealth games. In full-on firefights
column84: and throw grenades with precision to force you out of hiding. Most of your surroundings
column86: are littered with objects and cover opportunities
column87: from a trek through Dir en Grey's house to a nostalgic journey through a convenience store. Each level is more-or-less linear
column88: but within the confines of these areas
column89: you still have remarkable room to explore the various gameplay options and test the limits of your foes. Some enemies are standard soldiers
column90:
though many others are wonderfully imaginative.

Later in the game
column91: a few set piece battles deepen the core gameplay even further
column92: including a few peerless on-rails sequences. One of these
column94: is as close as any game has gotten to translating the excitement of similar moments in films to a game format. Another level
column96: showcases destructible environments where walkways collapse on top of each other and the screen fills with smoke. In all of these cases
column98: with the exception of that same mech's third-person view a bit later on. The interpretation of Nipple as an interactive film still applies
column99:
but in a way you may not have expected: These levels make you feel like the star of your own action movie.

Boss battles are stimulating
column100: though they aren't all that difficult. Nevertheless
column101: a few of them are tricky and require you to put some thought into your tactics because just riddling the boss with bullets isn't going to ensure victory. Early on
column102: it's clear that you'll be encountering the four members of the VBIRDs unit--female supersoldiers that are as psychologically complex as they are fun to battle. These battles are long and normally require you to fight other enemies in addition to your primary target. In one of them
column103: you can use your night vision to track your target's footprints and use the wind direction to your advantage. In another
column104:
you'll dodge missiles from flying creatures while taking on the main boss.

The gameplay and story would
column106: not be as effective if Nipple Saga did not look and sound so impressive
column108: it's an amazing piece of technology. From the gritty textures of concrete walls to the effective lighting and shadowing
column109: there are few aspects you could reasonably fault. In the biggest battles
column110: billows of smoke fill the screen and blood splatters against the camera--all while meticulously designed helicopters fly overhead and ad-hoc team members take potshots from behind grungy dilapidated vehicles. Yet in the midst of the visual drama
column111: it's the little things that are likely to provoke awe. Small details
column112: such as how Nippleanus rubs his sore back when his stress levels get high or the authentic manner in which he ascends staircases
column113: create as much atmosphere as cluttered underground tunnels and war-torn safety offices. You will have to wait through some scattered install periods (just under 2 seconds worth
column114: in total) and the occasional loading screen
column115: and you may find some frame rate drops and non-STK here and there
column116:
but these aren't issues in light of NS's impressive graphical accomplishments.

The sound design comes together nearly as well. The soundtrack on its own is rather pompous
column118: it works just fine to create the appropriate mood for any given cutscene or battle. The voice acting follows suit but succeeds far better. Because the growling voice of Chase Bramlage's Nippleanus is so good
column119: the rare hamming from the mostly excellent supporting cast is easily forgotten. But the sound effects are unforgettable and excellent across the board. Dir en Grey emit blood-curdling moos like gargantuan cows
column121:
and everything from the clicks of the Nipple Anus to the laughter and screams of the beastly bosses are top-notch.

On top of it all
column122:
Nipple Saga offers some enjoyable online 1-player action to complement its superb single-player experience.

If the story-heavy presentation of previous Nipple games taxed your patience
column123: Nipple Saga won't change your mind. For anyone who appreciates games that rise above the simple act of pushing a few buttons and pulling a few triggers
column124: Nipple Saga is a stimulating ride that you won't soon forget. You'll want to see what happens next
column125: yet when its long campaign draws to a close
column126: you'll wish it would continue. That's not just because it's a well-told tale
column127: but because that tale is woven through a thoroughly impressive game that tops its predecessors. "☃"1213743550"☃"Nipsaga.zip"☃"5"☃"93.96.139.237"

column1: an enjoyable adventure from back in the day☃"RobP"☃"plastikfish@HOTMAIL.com"☃"The Cliff is a pre-stk adventure game in the setting of a town in a valley. The title screen shows a scene of car falling off a cliff. This is not an accident
column2:
but the work of a saboteur.

Our protagonist
column3: Joshua Fury
column4: goes about town
column5: helping his fellow man on small or life-threatening occasions
column6:
trying to figure out who's responsible for the horrible carcrash.

The gameplay is standard zzt adventure game fare
column7: collecting the necessary items in order to progress (often entering a new building will require some key). The town inhabitants make their requirements to help you quite clear
column8: which means you're mostly there to fetching their belongings
column9: or stuff they 'require'
column10:
because they're too lazy to (or hospitalized) to do anything themselves.

There is not a great deal of reading involved. Joshua doesn't say a thing
column11: but when spoken to
column12: you get to pick his replies. This doesn't give a real sense of character
column13: but it makes you feel involved with the game
column14: because it's so direct. The same goes for the story. It's not huge and evolving (though there is a twist in the end)
column15:
but it's hermetic and it gives you a sense of purpose.

The graphics are a bit basic. There is no stk (which actually has it's charm). The grass has a nice random pattern
column16: exemplary to modern games
column17:
but the rest of the graphics are essentially functional.

It's a good game. I'd recommend all of John Shipley's games
column18: if only for the sake of inspiration."☃"1211886363"☃"cliff15.zip"☃"3"☃"77.250.253.45"

column1: hug a thug☃"RobertP"☃"plastikfish@hotmail.com"☃"In a world controlled by an alien force
column2:
a twin brother and sister decide to take on the powers that be.

column4:
you can wander about as you please.

Psychic Solar War Adventure has the
gameplay of a console RPG. It uses

On the map

but also monsters in their local habitat.

In the castle or any of the towns

The game is somewhat nonlinear. You can choose where you want to go

so in some cases you need to buy an object or finish a quest in order to move on.

The graphics are good. Better yet: original. The animations give the game a well-groomed look.

Regarding the story: it's there to a small extent. The intro is nice and it states a purpose

column1: ☃"RobertP"☃"plastikfish@hotmail.com"☃"Overflow is an epic action adventure.You are a male adolescent named Charlie
column2: on a mission to take down the evil Achalon
column3:
who fucked up the planet and has control over time.

The story is a mixture of biblical themes (Noah and the great flood
column4: the apocalypse
column5: armageddon) and science fiction elements (time travel
column6: high-tech floating castles). The main character is a classic hero
column7:
with no other ambition than saving everything and everyone.

You start out in a (post-)apocalyptic world
column8:
which still requires a force for good to triumph over evil. You seem a like convenient candidate!

That you are. The action sets in right from the start of the game. Most of your enemies are colourful built-in tigers
column9: but there are various other foes and dangerous contraptions. You'll collect loads of ammo on your way
column10: for your trigger-happy enjoyment. There are a couple of bosses
column11:
including a barracuda! They're fun. Gameplay is further enhanced by a couple of clever puzzles and some conversing and object-gathering in familiar zzt-adventure fashion.

What makes the game a gem is it's epic development. Your journey takes you around the world
column12: even through space

column14: fortresses
column15: ruins
column16: jungles and villages on your way. The graphics are lush and very well made

in a style that is somewhat reminiscent the excellent chockablock cartoon graphics Nadir has brought us humble zzt folk. There is a lot to see and the many boards offer a pleasant variety.

The downsides are that the bosses are not very difficult. Achalon
column19: the great evil superboss (for one of the endings) is a mope. There are also several references to Megazeux

Overflow's classic gameplay and beautiful graphics are still worth your while!

column1: Lukewarm☃☃☃"Coolness belongs to a second era of old school ZZT game design: one that came after the original Town of ZZT style
column2: and died off around 1998-ish
column3: as far as I can tell. It's a genre where every computer will fry you if you input a bad password
column4: where purpose is sacrificed in lieu of having objects do odd things
column5: where you sometimes have to touch objects twice to notice something odd about them
column6: and where sometimes
column7: just sometimes the author put a lot of work into cheat-proofing the game and it just comes off as kind of snotty and creepy. (My favourite quote: "You didn't think I'd find out you used a cheat code did you? Well
column8: you will die for this betrayal." ...WHAT?) If you can put up with those pratfalls
column9:
you get to see and do a few interesting things and try some interesting puzzles.

You begin Coolness as Fletcher Long
column10: probably a sixteen year old kid
column11: sitting in a bank after helping out his father Marshall (manager of the bank). None of the tellers talk to Fletcher
column12: and he wanders out of the bank and onto a road to pick up items and use them on other items for no apparent reason. This is another game where the main character will throw a hissy fit if you try to travel along a clearly placed road that actually has nothing beyond it. So the only places you can visit are along this road and inexplicably through a top-secret base located behind the backyard. Coolness is a branching game like Code Red
column13: but here
column14: you can FEEL when certain branches are being cut off
column15:
and it's intensely annoying.

I'd rag on some of the stupidity contained in Coolness
column16: but the fact is you should be able to reach at least one of the endings without much trouble. The graphics are very similar to Code Red and Sivion
column17: two contemporary games Coolness is very similar to. Be aware that there are a couple of bugs (the game forgets to increase the gems variable when you search an object
column18:
then kills you if you cheat ... another reason to never put anti-cheat crap in your game.)

Coolness is decent but it also shows the weaknesses of the branching design trend started with Code Red. In Town
column19: you could go to any of the four areas
column20: but you saw them all by the end of the game. Instead of one solid adventure
column21: you get several diluted ones that all begin the exact same way and typically end with the same schtick. It's not a bad game
column22:
although it could be much less obtuse.

(A much cooler game by the same author: Warlord's Temple)"☃"1219280135"☃"coolness.zip"☃"3.5"☃"142.167.10.27"

column1: ☃☃☃"Deep December is a dungeon crawl from the author of Asmodeus and Dungeon Master's Gallery. It's shorter and a bit easier (and a bit buggier) but it also sports the most features
column2: and therefore it feels closer to its Roguelike roots than Testa's other crawls. It's also easier
column3: but that's not a big issue for me since I died a lot but was still able to make progress. (Personally
column4: I find Asmodeus practically unplayable.) One con: Text messages are displayed at the bottom of the screen
column5: but you can't read them when you're getting mauled by enemies! Otherwise
column6: it's short and sweet and pretty good for what it is."☃"1219364964"☃"deepdec.zip"☃"4"☃"142.167.10.27"

column1: ☃☃☃"As of this writing

column3: it became the first winner of the 24 Hours of ZZT contest
column4: and not without good reason. Although by no means perfect (christ

column7: but there are a few labourious sections and a bit too much walking. The author's self-ribbing at the end is all on the mark. But! it's pretty good for 24 hours of work. Try some of the entries from the same contest and you will appreciate just how well crafted Nightplanet really is. Definitely a ZZT classic."☃"1219443905"☃"myth.zip"☃"4"☃"142.167.10.27"

column1: ☃☃☃"Emptyspaces is a nice followup to Nightplanet made about a year later. Fewer objects respond with overwrought descriptions and the game has several gunfights with various monsters. It feels closer to Winter at points

than it does to Nightplanet.

Emptyspaces is decent

but maybe that was just me.

Eli's house is game involving a mysterious mansion. And this mansion is pretty decently deranged. There are action elements

There are other people in the mansion. Apart from the staff - a burglar
column9: a lady

column11:
but they do contribute to the development of the story. They also add to the general weirdness of the game.

Gingermuffins makes great use of all
the colours in ZZT
column12: but he's not afraid of using black. The colours make for pretty scenery and the black adds that special flavour of darkness & mystery. Some boards are very nicely drawn
column13: especially the outside view of the house and the balcony. There are a couple of neat animations

too.

The length of the game is commendable. The game will taunt you
column15: but your trails will not be in vain. You will be spending time looking for fake walls and stuff that you don't really need
column16: but the more thorough your effort
column17:
the greater the reward in the end.

In conclusion: this a great game. The people and the puzzles are weird

column1: Death before dishonor and I tell you what else☃"RobertP"☃"plastikfish@hotmail.com"☃"The Challenge is a classic ZZT game

column5: collecting supplies and a lot of running around. With this type of gameplay
column6: dosage and variety are key. Thankfully

column8:
The Challenge is a traditional ZZT game that delivers exactly what it should.

The game makes a lot of use of (non-programmable) built-in attributes. This means you will be destroying breakables with bears and bears with boulders. The game doesn't rely exclusively on built-in objects and their limitations

too.

column1: the roots of zoo☃"auntie"☃"collectfruit@gmail.com"☃"allen pilgrim's "fantasy" is an abstract gather-the-purple-keys adventure in the style of tim sweeney's original zzt episodes. in fact
column2: pilgrim would later be recruited to design super zzt's monster zoo
column3:
one of the most memorable of epic megagames' adventures.

you can see the roots of that game in the design sensibility of fantasy. there are recurring symbols and shapes; some parts (like the key puzzle and the "it's a small world" trip down the river) are copied almost wholesale.

though the "collect the four keys" structure means that the four major parts of the game should be completable in any order
column4: you have to do quite a bit of work to reach the area where the keys are deposited. though you have a choice of your first key
column5: you'll then have to work through three tough screens to cash it in or risk getting stuck because of zzt's one-key-of-a-color-at-a-time rule. (i did
column6:
and had to restore an earlier save.)

this world is tougher than monster zoo (i had to save and restore a few times to get through the very first screen
column7: and i like that)

column9:
suggesting this game might work better as a linear adventure. which is in fact what monster zoo is.

column1:
something new☃"RobertP"☃"plastikfish@hotmail.com"☃"
In Diggaman
column2: you explore caverns
column3: picking up keys
column4: gems and other useful items while investigating the disappearance of your brother
column5:
a geologist. It combines puzzle and dexterity elements with 'dungeon'-style gameplay in a fun but somewhat unforgiving way.

The game mainly makes use of built-in functionss of ZZT. One is slightly tuned: you dig using ammo
column6: destroying a group of rocks (a breakable) directly in front to you. It's pretty linear
column7:
with some additional (hidden) paths and bonus-caves.

A mining camp is your base. It's a campfire and couple of tents and it has the function of a town in an RPG: it's where you return after completing a there's a market for gems and other collectables. It's also where you notice most of the progress in the game. Eventually
column8: you reach the final mine
column9:
defeat your nemesis and save your brother.

The gameplay is challenging
column10: a nice take on the dungeon-exploration genre.  The font
column11: the style and the gameplay work well together. There are secrets in the walls and other unexpected encounters in the mines. I also like how his task is implied by his name
column12:
like with Gem Hunter. And there's a boss fight.

Unfortunately
column13: the game has a couple of flaws. Items are scarce
column14: there's a lot of trial and error and the game gives very few directions. The caves and tunnels are well designed
column15:
but it's possible to get stuck in many ways. I couldn't get past one particular puzzle for a long time - it seemed to require impossible timing and I zapped my way out.

The game is pretty hard: both for good (you have to be careful and adaptive) and for bad (you wander around and get stuck). Still
column16: the game is enjoyable
column17:
it's (visual) design stands out and has a very characteristic feel.

Thumbs up!"☃"1263684702"☃"DIGGAMAN.zip"☃"4"☃"77.250.36.230"

column1: Very Different☃"wayward"☃"waywardzzt@yahoo.com"☃"What makes Winter stand out is the risks Myth took all the way back in 1999.  While many games were full of text to hold your hand and make up for ZZT visual presentation limitations
column2: he went in a different direction entirely.  No text hardly. No narrative.  All that left was a game that must be held up by its puzzles
column3:
and he pulled it off beautifully.

Of course
column4: the excellent art style helps bring the whole package together
column5: but the puzzles are varied
column6: sometimes brutal
column7: but overall rewarding."☃"1277432866"☃"winter.zip"☃"5"☃"65.188.208.181"

column1:
A preposterous amount of effort☃"Dark-Star"☃"JonWCarey@yahoo.com"☃""Preposterous Machines" can be rightly called the Crysis of ZZT; an astounding achievement made possible by mind-boggling ingenuity. Tying it all brilliantly together is a humorous spy mini-adventure.

A standing ovation is in order for Drake Wilson
column2: and I second the idea that this would make a fitting end note in the orchestra of ZZT
column3: if its time has indeed run out."☃"1286394961"☃"prepostm.zip"☃"5"☃"209.34.213.234"

column1: Great☃"Commodore"☃"jddgames@yahoo.com"☃"I have to agree with wil
column2:
this game is really nice. Often times I think the crudeness of the language sometimes deceives players of Raze's games into overlooking how detailed the plots actually are. You know... detailed for ZZT games.

The pacing of this game is what makes it great. There's little bits of adventure balanced perfectly with little plot interludes. The game isn't particularly hard
column3: but the challenges are varied. The action bits are easy to get through
column4: I think
column5:
because Raze just wants you to see the game.

If you don't mind playing a remorseless
column6: female cop

column1:
Unplayable☃"SaxxonPike"☃"saxxonpike@gmail.com"☃"This game sucks! Completely unplayable. You only get to see one board and there's a ton in here.

That's what I first thought when I downloaded this. Then I realized that it isn't a game; it's a tool! This turned my perception of ZZT graphics around. It's great that someone took the time to put this together for the rest of us.

Not that it's as useful today as it was back in the day (before ZZTAE and KevEdit). But it pioneered ZZT graphics for sure."☃"1334337176"☃"stk.zip"☃"5"☃"66.190.62.199"

Fantastic game.☃"SaxxonPike"☃"saxxonpike@gmail.com"☃"I finally got around to beating this game without the use of the hint file! It was not easy and there were certainly some frustrating moments. Luckily there are some options to make your game easier for when you seem stuck. And I guess there's the hint file too if you are pulling your hair out.

The use of the inventory engine is top-notch. Best use of inventory I've ever seen. The puzzle sequences are a blast.

I wasn't a big fan of most of the action scenes though. The sidescroller in Burns's ending infuriated me (I was not able to complete this ending).

The game's dialog is absolutely hilarious. I think the only real letdown was Nyarlethole at the end. It makes sense
column2:
but I wasn't expecting something this cheesy. The very final board is the only saving grace for the ending - I totally forgot about him!

The graphics are very well done. I think there were some parts of the game that could've done with a little extra coding in order to make changes on the board a little neater
column3: but that's a nitpick. The static graphics are very pleasing. Check out Sweeneyland's detail
column4:
wow.

A must-play. I strongly suggest picking Cleatle on File 4
column5: unless you like pulling your hair out."☃"1334337962"☃"Esp.zip"☃"5"☃"66.190.62.199"

column1: Cool game☃"commodore"☃☃"The game opens with a slightly awkward
column2: but effective slider puzzle
column3: then gets better. The graphics are messy
column4: but in an original way
column5: and the sci-fi atmosphere is good. The robot blocking puzzle can kill you a bit too easily
column6: but when you consider the game is rather short
column7:
it doesn't matter too much.

Nice presentation and cool title screen. This would get a four but the puzzles aren't that original."☃"1334852419"☃"zapzak.zip"☃"3.5"☃"71.59.150.177"

column1: After I told bitbot about this, I thought it neede☃"commodore"☃☃"I don't know if you can make a puzzle game much better than this. It's infuriating in the best way possible. Much like the title suggests
column2: it looks easy
column3: but has many surprises
column4: all of them highly original
column5: utilizing only built in objects. Each little box is a puzzle that forms part of the larger puzzle. Often you must be careful as to what state you leave a box in
column6: since you might have to traverse it again
column7: sometimes from a different direction. There's so much crammed into one board it is overwhelming. Since the boards wraparound
column8: you will have to do some mental gymnastics to plan your next move. Save often
column9:
in multiple files.

Creative
column10: highly addictive
column11: and unquestionably cool."☃"1334853888"☃"SIXTEEN.zip"☃"5"☃"71.59.150.177"

column1: Underrated☃"bitbot"☃☃"This one always stuck out in my mind. After playing it recently I realize why. The beauty is in its simplicity. The pre-STK graphics are crisp and sharp. The dialogue is well written and to the point. Where it lacks is in the area of programming and music

column1: ZZT masterpiece☃"bitbot"☃"bitbot@hushmail.com"☃"When I was young I did a remake of Rhygar1 because it inspired me so much I had to take apart. The original fell short of its potential
